The contrast Internal > External comes from an attributional decision task about causal attributions for social events (self-responsibility vs external causes). This is clearly a social processing task measuring how participants process social causal information.
The task examines causal attributions and self-responsibility, not affiliation, attachment, or bonding processes (no measures of close relationships, kinship, cooperation, or similar).
The task does not involve communicative exchanges, facial/affect recognition, or production/reception of social signals; it focuses on causal attribution of events.
Internal > External isolates self-responsibility (internal attributions), reflecting agency/self-related judgment and self-knowledge processes.
This contrast emphasizes internal (self) attributions rather than perception/understanding of others; it does not specifically measure representations about others' mental states or actions.
External > Internal derives from the same social attribution task and therefore constitutes social processing of causal attributions.
The contrast targets external attributions and does not assess affiliation, attachment, or relationship processes.
No measures of communication (facial, verbal, gaze, etc.) are involved; the task is attributional rather than communicative.

External > Internal emphasizes external/situational or other-directed attributions rather than self-focused judgments of agency or self-knowledge, so it does not specifically measure perception of self.

External attributions implicate representations about others or situational causes; the contrast External > Internal therefore measures perception/understanding of others (attributing causation externally).
The Self-serving bias contrast is derived from the social attribution task and examines how subjects attribute causation in social events, so it is social processing.
Self-serving bias concerns attributional style rather than affiliation or attachment processes; no measures of bonding or close-relationship worth are present.
The task does not involve communicative signal reception/production; it focuses on causal attributions for social events.
Self-serving bias operationalizes internal attributions for positive events (self-responsibility) and thus taps into self-related processes (agency, self-evaluation).
The self-serving bias also involves externally attributing negative events to others or situations (other-directed attributions), thus engaging perception/understanding of others as causal agents.
The Non-self-serving bias contrast comes from the same social attribution paradigm and therefore measures social processing of causal attributions.
Non-self-serving attributions are still attributional judgments, not measures of affiliation or attachment.
This contrast does not involve communication-specific processes (facial/gesture/vocal exchange), but rather attributional decision-making.
Non-self-serving attributions include instances of internal attribution for negative events (self-blame) and thus involve self-related representations (agency, self-evaluation).
Non-self-serving responses also include external attributions for positive events (crediting others/situations), engaging representations about others as causal agents.

The contrast involves faces that acquired social/moral significance through a cooperative interaction (Prisoner’s Dilemma). Subjects made judgments about these socially-tagged faces during fMRI, so the analysis directly measures social processing.

The stimuli reflect learned social valence from cooperative/defective interactions (affiliation-related learning); the task (cooperation paradigm) probes social bonds and evaluation of others, matching affiliation/attachment constructs.

The analysis uses face stimuli whose social meaning was learned and subjects made categorical judgments, engaging reception of facial social information (facial communication). Thus it measures social communication processes.

The contrasts concern perception and evaluation of other people’s moral/social status rather than self-related awareness, introspection, or self-judgments; therefore it does not measure perception/understanding of self.

The contrast indexes representations and evaluative knowledge about other individuals (cooperators/defectors) learned via interaction, directly mapping onto perception and understanding of others (traits/intentions).
Cooperator vs Neutral Faces contrasts responses to individuals labeled as cooperators (learned via interaction), which clearly taps social perception and processing.
This contrast isolates faces of cooperators (positive social partners) versus neutral faces within a cooperation paradigm, directly indexing affiliation/attachment-related processing.
Faces convey socially relevant learned information (cooperator status); the task engages reception of facial social cues, so it measures social communication.
The contrast assesses others’ social status (cooperators) rather than self-referential processes; it does not measure perception/understanding of the self.
Contrasting cooperator vs neutral faces evaluates learned traits and social value of other individuals, consistent with perception and understanding of others.
Defector vs Neutral Faces contrast examines neural response to individuals learned to be unfair/defective in social interaction, so it clearly measures social processing.

The contrast involves evaluation of negative social partners (defectors) derived from the cooperation game, probing affiliation/attachment-related learning and social bonding dynamics (avoidance/negative valuation).
Subjects perceive faces whose social meaning (defection) was learned; this engages reception of facial social signals and thus social communication processes.
The analysis concerns attitudes and memory for other individuals (defectors) rather than self-related cognition or agency, so it does not measure perception/understanding of self.
Contrasting defector versus neutral faces assesses representation and evaluation of others’ traits and moral behavior, meeting criteria for perception and understanding of others.

The contrast between intentional and nonintentional cooperator faces manipulates perceived moral responsibility/intentionality of others, a core social-cognitive process; thus it measures social processing.

Manipulating intentionality of cooperators affects attribution of social responsibility and may modulate affiliative evaluations (how one forms bonds/trust), fitting affiliation/attachment constructs in a cooperation context.
The contrast involves interpreting socially relevant facial cues and inferred intentions (reception of facial/intentional information), so it engages social communication processes.
This contrast manipulates perceptions about others’ intentionality and responsibility, not self-referential judgments or self-awareness; it therefore does not index perception/understanding of self.

The intentional vs nonintentional contrast directly probes representations of others’ agency/intentions and moral status, consistent with perception and understanding of others (mental states/intentionality).

The contrast compares observation of a social interaction (relational segment) versus observation of an individual alone/rest. This is a social-related task and directly measures social processing (perception and interpretation of social interactions). The stimulus explicitly involves social relations between two people, meeting both inclusion requirements.

The study presents passive viewing of everyday social interactions but does not explicitly probe affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation/competition, or loved-one vs stranger contrasts). The contrast investigates general social relations rather than attachment/affiliation constructs, so inclusion criteria for affiliation/attachment are not met.

Watching interactions likely engages social communicative processes (perceiving facial expressions, gestures, and other social signals). The contrast isolates interaction observation versus alone, which measures social communication aspects (reception of social cues) consistent with the inclusion criteria.

The task involves passive observation of others interacting and does not require self-reflection, judgments about the self, agency, or self-knowledge. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria for Perception and Understanding of Self.

The contrast specifically contrasts observing interactions (two persons) with an alone segment; this engages perception and understanding of others (animacy, action perception, and likely inferring mental states). It therefore meets the inclusion criteria for Perception and Understanding of Others.

The analysis contrasts cooperation vs independent play, a social-interaction task. The study explicitly investigates social processing (monitoring own/others' actions, adopting social mental sets), so the contrast measures social processing.

Cooperation is an affiliation-related context (example task listed: cooperation and competition). The contrast measures affiliation/attachment-related processes by comparing cooperative play to independent play.

Cooperative interaction involves exchange of socially relevant information and coordination; the study lists cooperation/competition as example tasks for Social Communication, so the contrast measures social communication processes.
The task requires self-monitoring and adopting a mental set (self-related processes) during cooperation vs independent play, matching the Perception/Self construct.
Cooperation requires monitoring and representing others' actions and intentions; the contrast targets Perception/Understanding of Others as described in the abstract.

The analysis contrasts competition vs independent play, a social-interaction task. The study investigates social processing (monitoring own/others' actions and social stances), so this contrast measures social processing.

Competition is listed alongside cooperation as an affiliation/attachment-related social context in the inclusion examples; the contrast measures competitive social interaction relative to independent play.
Competitive interaction involves exchange and response to social cues; the study treats competition as relevant to Social Communication, so the contrast measures these processes.
Competition requires self-monitoring and strategic self-related processes (adopting a competitive mental set) compared to independent play, fitting Perception/Self.
Competition necessitates assessing others' actions and intentions; the contrast captures Perception/Understanding of Others as described in the study.
This analysis directly contrasts cooperation vs competition, both social interaction stances; the comparison measures social processing involved in different social modes.
Cooperation vs competition contrasts affiliation-related (cooperative) versus non-affiliative/competitive interactions; this directly assesses affiliation/attachment-related processes.
Comparing cooperation and competition examines differences in social interaction and communication strategies; the study lists these tasks as examples for Social Communication.
The contrast isolates differences in self-related processing (e.g., adopting cooperative vs competitive mental sets and self-monitoring), meeting Perception/Self criteria.
Contrasting cooperation and competition explicitly engages understanding others’ actions and intentions under different social contexts, matching Perception/Others.
Competition vs cooperation is a social contrast examining different social stances; it measures social processing related to competitive interactions relative to cooperative ones.
This contrast compares competitive versus cooperative interactions, addressing affiliation/attachment dimensions (competition reduces affiliation relative to cooperation).
The analysis assesses differences in social interaction and communicative/coordination demands between competition and cooperation; fits Social Communication criteria.
Competition vs cooperation contrasts self-related processes (strategies, self-monitoring, agency) across social stances, meeting Perception/Self inclusion.
The contrast probes how participants perceive and reason about others (intentions, actions) differently in competitive vs cooperative contexts, satisfying Perception/Others.

The task involves reading sentences about guilt and embarrassment and the study explicitly discusses social cognition and Theory of Mind; it measures evaluative processes of self-conscious social emotions, satisfying social processing criteria.

The task and contrasts probe moral emotions (guilt, embarrassment) and evaluative processes, not affiliation or attachment (no measures of relationships, kinship, cooperation, or loved vs stranger contrasts).

The paradigm does not assess social communication per se (no facial/gesture/eye contact or communicative exchange tasks); it probes internal evaluative social emotions rather than reception/production of social signals.

The study investigates evaluative processes of self-conscious emotions (guilt, embarrassment), which involve self-awareness and self-evaluation, meeting the perception/understanding of self construct.
Authors explicitly link activations to social cognition and Theory of Mind and state that these emotions require representing others' mental states, satisfying perception and understanding of others.

The task explicitly involves social stimuli (self face vs familiar other) and examines self-recognition versus recognition of another person, which falls squarely within social processing. The contrast measures social processing of faces (self/other), satisfying both that the task is social-related and the contrast measures social processing.

The task contrasts self-face and a gender-matched familiar other but does not assess affiliation or attachment constructs (e.g., relationship closeness, bonding, kinship, cooperation). 'Familiar other' here is not presented as a loved one or as an attachment measure, so criteria for affiliation/attachment are not met.

This is a facial recognition task (self vs familiar other), which is a form of receptive facial communication (recognition and characterization of faces). The contrast measures social communicative processing of facial identity, meeting the criteria.

The primary question is recognition of one's own face (self-recognition), directly measuring perception and understanding of the self (self-awareness/self-knowledge). The contrast isolates self-related processing, satisfying the inclusion criteria.

The experiment includes images of a familiar other and contrasts them with self; thus the analysis addresses perception and representation of another person (familiar other), meeting criteria for Perception/Understanding of Others.
The contrast (other > self) involves social stimuli (familiar other vs self) and examines processing of social information (responses to another person versus self), so it measures social processing.

Although a 'familiar other' is used, the task does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, closeness, kinship, cooperation). The contrast does not operationalize affiliation/attachment, so it is excluded.
The contrast concerns perception of faces (familiar other > self), which is receptive facial communication (facial recognition) and thus falls under social communication.

Even in the other>self contrast, the design probes self-related processing by comparison; the paradigm centers on self-recognition versus other-recognition, so Perception/Understanding of Self is measured (self trials and their deactivations/activations are explicitly discussed in the study).

The other>self contrast explicitly identifies regions responding more to familiar others than self, directly indexing perception/representation of others; this meets the inclusion criteria for Perception/Understanding of Others.

The analysis 'Receiving aversive stimuli; parametric modulation' involves subjects being provoked by aversive stimuli within an interactive task and observing opponent suffering. This directly concerns social processing: perceiving/responding to social provocation and interaction. Matches I1 (social-related task) and I2 (measures social processing).

The task is a competitive interaction (retaliation, provocation) within a social context; competition/cooperation paradigms are listed under inclusion examples for affiliation/attachment. Although it's antagonistic rather than affiliative, the task probes social bonds/interaction dynamics and comparison with opponent, meeting I1. The contrast measures reactions to social interaction, satisfying I2.

The paradigm involves social exchange (provocation and response) and perception of opponent's suffering, which entails social communicative signals and reciprocal interaction. This fits I1 and the analysis measures social communication aspects (I2).

Retaliation and receiving stimuli involve self-related processing (deciding intensity of retaliation, monitoring one's actions/emotional responses) implicating perception/understanding of self. The parametric modulation of receiving aversive stimuli likely involves self-monitoring and internal state awareness meeting I1 and I2.

Receiving aversive stimuli and observing opponent suffering engage representation and understanding of others' emotional states (compassion, observing suffering). This directly fits perception/understanding of others per I1 and I2.
'Retaliation; parametric modulation' is a core social interaction measure (response to provocation and aggression toward an opponent), directly measuring social processing. Matches I1 and I2.

Although retaliation is competitive/antagonistic, the task is a social interaction (competition) which falls under cooperation/competition examples for affiliation and attachment constructs. The contrast measures social dynamics between players, meeting I1 and I2.

Retaliation involves exchange of socially relevant information (aggressive signals, response contingencies) and perception/production of communicative behavior within the interactive task. Thus it satisfies I1 and I2.

Selecting intensity of retaliation and correlating with dorsal mPFC activity indicates self-related decision-making and monitoring processes, constituting perception/understanding of self and meeting I1 and I2.

Retaliation and observing opponent suffering require understanding others' states/intentions—ventral mPFC activity correlated with observing opponent suffering—so it matches perception/understanding of others per I1 and I2.
The conjunction 'retaliation and watching the opponent' directly involves social interaction and processing of others' states; it is clearly a social processing measure. Meets I1 and I2.

This conjunction involves competition/interaction with an opponent, which is within the scope of affiliation/attachment constructs as it assesses social relationships and responses in social contexts (competition). Thus I1 and I2 apply.
Conjunction of retaliation and observing opponent is an exchange of social signals and interpretations, implicating social communication processes. Satisfies I1 and I2.
Conjunction includes self-related components (action selection during retaliation) and monitoring of one's responses; thus it involves perception/understanding of self, matching I1 and I2.
Watching the opponent and retaliating involves understanding others' states (suffering, intent), directly fitting perception/understanding of others per I1 and I2.

Contrast includes friend and unfamiliar others via names and thus indexes perception of others' identities and familiarity.

SELF vs baseline is an emotion attribution task involving social cognition and empathy (self-focused processing of emotional faces), meeting Social Processing.
Task involves emotion attribution and empathy for faces, not measures of affiliation/attachment (no kinship, bonding, or loved-vs-stranger contrasts).
The task requires perception and evaluation of facial expressions (receptive facial communication), directly mapping onto Social Communication.
This analysis isolates SELF-related processing (subjects focus on their own emotional response), directly targeting Perception/Understanding of Self.
This contrast is SELF-focused (own emotional response) rather than assessment of others’ states, so it does not measure Perception/Understanding of Others.
OTHER vs baseline is an emotion attribution task evaluating others’ emotional states from faces, a social cognition task.
The OTHER task assesses emotion recognition of faces rather than affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding or kinship manipulation).
Evaluating others’ emotions from facial expressions is reception of facial communication, fitting Social Communication.
The OTHER contrast focuses on others’ emotional states rather than self-related perception, so it does not index Perception/Understanding of Self.
This contrast explicitly measures perception and understanding of others’ emotional states (OTHER-task), meeting Perception/Understanding of Others.
Correlations between mirror neuron activation in SELF/OTHER tasks and empathy scores probe social cognitive processes (empathy, social perception), so Social Processing applies.
The correlations link mirror neuron activation and empathy but do not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding or relationship measures).
Mirror neuron activation during processing of facial expressions relates to reception/processing of facial social cues, which falls under Social Communication.

The analysis involves mirror neuron activation in the SELF/OTHER tasks; because SELF-related activations are included in the measure and correlated with empathy, Perception/Understanding of Self is relevant.
The analysis also includes OTHER-task mirror neuron activations and their relation to empathy, indexing Perception/Understanding of Others.
This is a gender interaction on SELF-task activations, probing social cognitive neural mechanisms of empathy — fits Social Processing.
The contrast examines gender differences in SELF-related empathy processing, not affiliation/attachment constructs like bonding or relationship status.
SELF-related processing of emotional faces implicates reception/processing of facial social cues and mirror-system recruitment, which maps to Social Communication.
Contrast is specifically the SELF-task interaction (female vs male), directly measuring Perception/Understanding of Self.
This interaction isolates SELF-related differences and does not target perception/understanding of others’ states, so Perception/Understanding of Others is not the focus.
The contrast is the reverse gender interaction for the SELF-task, addressing social cognitive differences in empathy — falls under Social Processing.
This contrast concerns gender differences in SELF-related emotion processing, not affiliation/attachment constructs.
The analysis concerns processing of facial emotional information and mirror-system engagement during SELF judgments, relevant to Social Communication.
This is a SELF-task gender interaction (male > female contrast), directly indexing Perception/Understanding of Self.
The contrast centers on SELF processing and not on perception/understanding of others’ states, so Perception/Understanding of Others is not applicable.
This is a gender interaction on OTHER-task activations (evaluating others’ emotional states), a social cognition contrast, so Social Processing applies.
The OTHER-task gender interaction assesses emotion recognition of faces, not affiliation/attachment or bonding constructs.
OTHER-task requires reception of facial emotional cues (evaluating others), which maps to Social Communication (reception of facial communication).
This interaction isolates OTHER-related processing (evaluating others’ emotions) rather than self-related perception, so Perception/Understanding of Self is not applicable.
Contrast directly measures differences in processing others’ emotional states (OTHER-task) across genders, so it indexes Perception/Understanding of Others.

Analysis P corresponds to the Pavlovian learning task (primary reinforcers) which is not a social-related task and does not measure social processing.
The Pavlovian task involves prediction of primary reinforcers (e.g., water) and does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, cooperation, or related contrasts).
The task is Pavlovian reward learning and does not measure social communication (no receptive or productive social communication tasks or contrasts).
Pavlovian learning here concerns external reward prediction, not processes of self-perception, agency, or self-knowledge.
The Pavlovian task does not involve representing or reasoning about others' actions, intentions, or emotions; it targets primary reinforcer prediction.

Analysis S is the social motor response learning task which explicitly involves social interaction and predicts motor responses required for social group interaction; it directly measures social processing.

Although the task is social, it targets prediction of motor responses and mirror-system activity rather than affiliation or attachment (no measures of bonding, cooperation, or related contrasts reported).

The social motor response learning task involves inference about others' intentions and motor responses (action/perception) rather than explicit social communication (facial or non-facial communication exchanges); it does not target communicative reception/production measures as defined here.
The task centers on predicting others' motor responses and goal states, not on self-perception, agency, or self-knowledge.

The social motor response learning task involves inferring others' intentions and motor responses (mirror-like processing in frontal operculum), directly mapping onto Action Perception/Understanding Mental States within Perception and Understanding of Others.
This analysis compares Pavlovian and social tasks; because it includes the social motor response learning condition, it pertains to social processing by contrasting social vs non-social TD signals.

The comparison isolates task differences between Pavlovian and social TD signals but the social task is not focused on affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding/cooperation contrasts), so affiliation/attachment is not measured.

Although the contrast includes a social condition, the comparison targets prediction of motor responses and TD signals rather than explicit social communication (reception/production of communicative signals), so it does not meet social communication criteria.
The contrast compares Pavlovian and social task activations and does not examine self-related processes (agency or self-knowledge).

Because the social condition involves inferring others' motor responses and intentions (action perception/understanding mental states), the Pavlovian vs social comparison engages Perception/Understanding of Others by contrasting social-specific activations.

The task directly examines mental state attribution to human-generated vs computer-generated music (inferring intentions behind products), which is a social-cognitive process. The contrast measures engagement of social-processing regions (aMFC, STS, temporal poles) and self-reported attribution of intentions, meeting social processing criteria.

The study examines attribution of intentions to artifacts (music) rather than formation or assessment of social bonds, attachment, or affiliation; it does not probe relationship or attachment constructs.
The paradigm tests attribution of mental states to products rather than receptive or productive social communication (e.g., face/gesture/voice exchange). It does not assess communication per se.
The task probes understanding of others' minds (attribution to composers) rather than self-related processing, agency, or self-knowledge, so it does not meet self-perception criteria.
The primary aim is understanding mental states behind human products (composers' intentions), which directly maps onto Perception and Understanding of Others, including Understanding Mental States.
As above: the contrast involves attributing intentions to perceived human vs computer-generated music, a social-cognitive process engaging mentalizing networks; it measures social processing.
This analysis does not assess affiliation, bonding, or attachment-related constructs; it investigates attribution of intentions to artifacts rather than relationship processes.
The task does not involve interactive or communicative exchanges (reception/production of social signals); it focuses on inferred intentions behind artifacts, not social communication.
The analysis measures understanding of others' intentions rather than self-related judgments or agency, so it does not meet perception_self criteria.
This analysis assesses attribution of mental states to composers of music (human products), which is a canonical example of Perception and Understanding of Others (Understanding Mental States).

Stories condition contains social reasoning tasks (social exchange, precautions, descriptives) and Stories>Rest contrast measures task-related activation, so it captures social processing across included story types.

Stories>Rest is collapsed across content and not specifically isolating affiliation/attachment constructs (e.g., kinship, cooperation contrasts). Although social exchange stories are present, the contrast is not specific to affiliation.
The task involves reasoning about rules and mental states rather than communicative reception/production (facial or non-facial) and the contrast is not targeting communication per se.
Contrast does not target self-related processing (self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge).

Stories include social exchange conditions that require reasoning about others' mental states (Theory of Mind). Stories>Rest captures activation from those conditions when collapsed, so it measures perception/understanding of others.
Rest>Stories reflects regions more active at rest than during stories and does not index task-driven social processing per se (does not measure social processing activation).
The contrast does not isolate affiliation/attachment processes and in fact reflects greater activity during rest, so it does not measure affiliation.
Rest>Stories does not measure social communication processes.
Contrast does not target self-related processing.
Rest>Stories does not index activation related to perceiving or reasoning about others' mental states.

Cards condition contains trials of social-exchange, precautionary, and descriptive rules; Cards>Rest measures task-related activation including social-exchange trials, therefore it captures social processing across card-based decisions.

Cards>Rest is collapsed across content and does not specifically isolate affiliation/attachment (cooperation) processes; although social exchange trials are included, the contrast is not specific to affiliation.
The card-selection task assesses reasoning about rules and mental states rather than communicative exchange; the contrast does not target communication.
Contrast does not focus on self-reflection, agency, or self-knowledge.

Card trials include social-exchange conditions that require understanding others' intentions and mental states; Cards>Rest therefore captures perception/understanding of others when collapsed across content.
Rest>Cards reflects greater activation during rest and does not index task-driven social processing.
Contrast does not isolate affiliation/attachment and in fact reflects rest-related activity rather than task-related cooperation processing.
Rest>Cards does not measure communicative processes.
Contrast does not target self-related processing.
Rest>Cards does not index perception/understanding of others' mental states.
Social Contracts > Precautions isolates social exchange reasoning (the study's social condition) and thus directly measures social processing.

Social exchange (social contracts) involves cooperative/affiliation-relevant reasoning (strategic social interaction). The contrast isolates social contract processing versus precautionary rules, matching affiliation/attachment-related constructs (e.g., cooperation).

Although social contracts involve social inference, the task focuses on rule reasoning and ToM rather than communicative reception/production; it does not target communication subconstructs specifically.
Contrast targets reasoning about others and social exchange, not self-related processes.

Social Contracts require inferring others' desires, goals, and intentions (Theory of Mind). The contrast isolates these processes relative to precautionary rules that do not need ToM, satisfying perception/understanding of others.
Social Contracts > Descriptives isolates social exchange reasoning relative to neutral/descriptive rules, directly indexing social processing.
Comparison of social contract to descriptive rules isolates cooperative/social-exchange processing relevant to affiliation/attachment constructs (cooperation), meeting the inclusion criteria.
Contrast focuses on social-exchange reasoning and mental-state inference rather than communicative expression or perception per se.
Contrast targets reasoning about others' mental states, not self-related judgments.
Social Contracts require inferring others' mental states; contrasted with descriptives this isolates perception/understanding of others (ToM) processes.
In the card-response modality, Social Contracts > Precautions isolates social-exchange reasoning during the card task, indexing social processing in decision-making context.

Card-based social contract trials require cooperative/affiliation-relevant reasoning; the contrast isolates this component versus precaution trials, matching affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.
The contrast targets inferential reasoning about social exchange rather than communicative signals or production/perception of communication.
Contrast is about reasoning about others' intentions in a decision task, not self-related processing.
Social contract card trials require ToM (understanding others' goals/intentions); Social Contracts > Precautions isolates these processes in the card task modality.
Social Contracts > Descriptives in the card-response modality isolates social-exchange reasoning during card decisions, indexing social processing.
This contrast isolates cooperative/social-exchange processing (affiliation-relevant) versus descriptive rules in the card task, meeting inclusion criteria for affiliation/attachment.
Contrast focuses on ToM and rule reasoning rather than communicative reception/production.
Contrast does not target self-awareness or self-related judgments.
Social Contracts in the card modality require inferring others' intentions; contrasted with descriptives this isolates perception/understanding of others (ToM).
Precautions > Social Contracts isolates precautionary reasoning, which the study argues does not require ToM; this contrast does not primarily index social processing.
Precautionary rules are non-social in nature and do not target affiliation/cooperation processes.
Precautionary reasoning involves conditional/deontic reasoning rather than communicative exchange.
Contrast does not target self-related processes.
Precautionary rules do not require inferring others' mental states per the study; this contrast isolates non-ToM processing.

Precautionary stories do not target affiliation/attachment or cooperation processes.
The contrast does not focus on communication processes.

Precautionary vs descriptive stories do not require mental-state inference about others (ToM) per the study, so this contrast does not index perception/understanding of others.

Contrast (STEP1+STEP2 - REST) includes footstep sounds (one and two persons) conveying social information; it measures social processing of auditory social cues.
Task involves perceiving footsteps and social identity cues but does not probe affiliation, attachment, or relationship-based processing (no kinship/attachment manipulation).

Listening to footsteps conveys social presence/identity but does not involve communicative exchange or measures of social communication per the definition (no reception/production of communicative signals or explicit communication task).
Contrast does not involve judgments or representations of the self (no self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge tasks).
Hearing one or two persons walking requires perceiving and interpreting others' actions/identity from auditory cues (action/animacy perception), fitting Perception of Others.
Contrast (NOISE1+NOISE2 - REST) reflects responses to non-social noise controls rather than social auditory stimuli; it does not measure social processing.
Noise stimuli do not probe affiliation or attachment-related processes.
Noise is non-social and does not involve communicative signals or social information exchange.
No self-related processing is probed by passive listening to noise.
Noise does not convey information about other agents' actions, identity, or mental states.

The interaction contrast ((STEP2 - NOISE2) - (STEP1 - NOISE1)) isolates social differences between two-person and one-person footsteps beyond noise, directly indexing social processing of multi-person cues.
Although the contrast targets social complexity (two vs one person), it does not assess affiliation/attachment or relational bonding constructs.
Contrast examines perception of multiple agents but does not probe communicative exchange or signaling; it is not a social communication task per se.
No self-referential or self-monitoring judgments are involved in this contrast.
This contrast directly tests perception/understanding of others (distinguishing one vs two agents and associated social cues), matching Action/Animacy Perception subconstructs.
STEP1 - NOISE1 isolates brain responses to single-person footsteps relative to noise, reflecting social auditory perception and thus social processing.
Contrast targets perception of a single person's footsteps, not affiliation or attachment processes.
Perception of footsteps conveys social presence but does not constitute social communicative exchange as defined here.
No self-related judgments are elicited by this contrast.
Isolating a single person's footsteps involves perceiving another agent's action/animacy from auditory cues, fitting Perception of Others.
STEP2 - NOISE2 isolates responses to two-person footsteps (social auditory stimuli) relative to noise, indexing social processing.
While involving two agents, the task does not manipulate or measure affiliation/attachment constructs.
The contrast assesses perception of multiple agents but not communicative signaling or interaction measures central to social communication.
No self-related processing or judgments are required by this contrast.
Two-person footsteps require perception and interpretation of others' actions/identity from sound, matching Perception of Others.
STEP2 - STEP1 compares two-person to one-person footsteps, indexing higher-order social processing related to multiple agents and social interaction cues.
This contrast addresses number of agents and social complexity rather than affiliation or attachment per se.
The contrast probes differences in perceived social complexity, not communicative exchange or explicit social communication tasks.
No self-referential processing is measured by comparing two vs one person's footsteps.
Directly compares perception of others (one vs two agents), reflecting action/animacy perception and understanding of others' presence and social configuration.

The analysis examines perception of socially relevant facial expressions (smiling) and associated facial mimicry and neural responses during social interaction, which directly taps general social processing. This satisfies inclusion criteria I1 (social-related task) and I2 (measures social processing).

Although smiling can be affiliative, the study does not specifically measure affiliation or attachment constructs (no tasks/contrasts assessing kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation, or attachment-related measures). The required inclusion criterion I1 for affiliation/attachment is not met.

The task involves perception of facial expressions and spontaneous facial mimicry (reception and production of facial communication), directly fitting Social Communication. This meets inclusion criteria I1 (social-communication task) and I2 (measures social communication).

The analysis targets perception of others' facial expressions and embodied reactions, not processes of self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge. Thus it does not meet the inclusion criterion I1 for Perception/Understanding of Self.

The analysis assesses neural responses to others' facial expressions and mimicry, which is directly about perceiving and understanding others' emotional states and actions. This fulfills inclusion criteria I1 and I2 for Perception and Understanding of Others.

The contrast compares observation of social versus individual actions, directly measuring social processing (interpreting others' actions and interactions). This fits the broad Social Processing construct.
The task contrasts social versus individual actions but does not target affiliation or attachment (no measures of bonding, cooperation/competition, loved one vs stranger, etc.).

While the contrast involves social interactions, it does not specifically manipulate or measure communicative signals (e.g., gaze/eye contact or other communicative production/reception) — that manipulation appears in other contrasts.
The analysis concerns observing others' actions and interactions, not processes of self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency.
The contrast examines perception of others' actions and social interactions (action perception and reasoning about others), fitting the Perception and Understanding of Others construct.
The main effect of gaze (gaze available vs masked) modulates processing of observed social interactions, directly reflecting social processing.
Gaze availability is manipulated, but there is no evidence the task targets affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding or relationship-specific contrasts).
Gaze (eye availability/masking) is a core communicative signal (eye contact, gaze following). The contrast directly tests effects of communicative cues, meeting Social Communication criteria.
This analysis manipulates gaze in observed agents and addresses perception of others, not self-related processes.
Manipulating gaze availability affects how observers perceive and infer others' actions and intentions, directly fitting Perception and Understanding of Others.
The interaction (type of action × gaze) addresses how gaze modulates processing of social versus individual actions, a social processing effect.
Although social context and gaze interact, there is no indication the interaction specifically measures affiliation or attachment constructs.
An interaction between action type and gaze availability implicates how communicative signals (gaze) influence perception/processing of social actions, aligning with Social Communication.
The interaction concerns perception of others' actions and gaze, not self-related judgments or self-awareness.
The interaction examines how gaze availability modulates perception and inference about others' actions/interactions, fitting Perception and Understanding of Others.

The task involves viewing animated characters approaching with happy or angry facial expressions to assess intentions, which directly measures social processing (perception and interpretation of social cues). Contrast Angry>Happy examines differential social signal processing.

Although the contrast focuses on anger, the overall task manipulates signals related to affiliation (happy) versus dominance/threat (angry). The task therefore probes affiliation-related processing by contrasting signals linked to social bonding versus threat.

The stimuli are facial expressions (happy vs angry) presented during social approach, which is a form of reception of facial communication; the contrast assesses neural responses to these communicative facial signals.
The task involves perceiving others' facial expressions and intentions, not self-related judgments, self-awareness, or self-monitoring. Thus it does not measure perception/understanding of self.
The study explicitly measures participants' perception and interpretation of others' emotional expressions and intentions during social approach, fitting perception and understanding of others.
The contrast Happy>Angry examines neural responses to affiliative (happy) versus threatening (angry) social signals during approach, directly indexing social perception and interpretation.
Happy expressions signal affiliation and affiliation-related intent; the Happy>Angry contrast specifically highlights affiliation-related processing in the task.
The contrast targets reception of facial communicative signals (happy vs angry expressions) during social approach, fitting the social communication construct (reception of facial communication).
The analysis concerns perception of others' expressions and intentions rather than any self-related processing or judgments; it does not measure self-perception.
Happy>Angry reflects participants' processing and understanding of others' emotional states and affiliative intent, matching perception and understanding of others.

The paper explicitly investigates the mirror system’s role in social cognition by measuring neural responses to observed actions after sensorimotor training. This is a social-related task probing mechanisms underlying social processing (mirror properties and action understanding), and the contrasts compare observation conditions relevant to social processing. Meets criteria I1 and I2.

The study does not examine affiliation, attachment, bonding, cooperation, or related social relationship constructs; stimuli and contrasts involve hand/foot action observation and sensorimotor training rather than attachment-related comparisons. Inclusion criteria are not met.

The task does not probe communicative exchanges, reception or production of facial/non-facial communicative signals, or other social communication constructs. It focuses on action observation and sensorimotor learning rather than communication. Inclusion criteria are not met.

The analysis measures neural responses to others' actions and changes in mirror properties following training; it does not assess self-awareness, agency judgements, or self-knowledge. Therefore it does not meet the Perception/Self inclusion criteria.

The study directly measures perception and representation of others’ actions (action observation; mirror system responses) and demonstrates altered action perception properties following sensorimotor learning. This maps onto Action Perception within Perception/Understanding of Others. Meets criteria I1 and I2.

Task involves viewing eyes and monitoring pupillary exchanges between self and others, a social task measuring processing of social cues; the contrast (main effect of viewing eyes) directly indexes social processing.
The analysis does not probe affiliation or attachment (no measures of bonding, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation, etc.).

Viewing eyes and pupillary dynamics are nonverbal social signals relevant to reception of facial/eye-based communication, so this contrast measures social communication (receptive facial communication).
Main effect of viewing eyes focuses on perception of external eye stimuli rather than explicit self-awareness or self-judgment; it does not measure perception/understanding of the self.
Analysis indexes perception/understanding of others’ facial/ocular signals (pupil size changes), matching perception-of-others criteria.
ROI analysis of viewing eyes evaluates neural responses to social eye stimuli and thus measures social processing.
ROI analysis does not target affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding or relationship comparisons).
ROI approach examines regions responding to eye-based social signals (reception of facial communication), so it maps onto social communication.
ROI analysis of viewing eyes targets perception of external stimuli rather than introspective self-related processing.
ROIs probe neural encoding of others’ pupil/eye cues, consistent with perception/understanding of others.
This analysis examines how dynamic coherence between one's and another's pupil size modulates brain activity, a social-interaction relevant process—thus social processing.
Although social, the contrast manipulates pupillary coherence/incongruence rather than measuring affiliation or attachment per se.
Monitoring another’s pupil dynamics and their relation to the observer’s pupil is a form of nonverbal social communication (receptive processing of eye-based signals).
While the analysis includes the observer’s pupil, it indexes autonomic coupling rather than explicit self-reflection or self-knowledge; it does not target self-perception constructs.
Analysis focuses on perception and interpretation of another’s pupil dynamics and how they relate to the observer, fitting perception-of-others.
ROI analysis of pupil-change effects probes socially relevant neural responses to pupil dynamics—measures social processing.
The ROI analysis targets neural correlates of pupillary dynamics, not affiliation/attachment constructs.
ROI analysis examines regions responsive to eye-based, nonverbal signals (pupil dynamics), mapping to social communication.
ROIs reflect processing of pupil coherence/incongruence rather than self-awareness or self-judgment; does not measure perception of self.
ROI targets neural encoding of another’s pupillary cues and their social salience—consistent with perception/understanding of others.
The (negative > positive) interaction examines discordance between observed and observer pupils—a socially relevant signal processing effect, so it indexes social processing.
The contrast tests concordance/discordance of pupillary dynamics, not affiliation/attachment measures (no bonding or relationship comparisons).
Discordant vs. concordant pupillary exchanges modulate processing of nonverbal ocular signals—this reflects social communication (reception of eye-based cues).
Although involving the observer’s pupil, the contrast addresses mismatch between self and other autonomic responses rather than explicit self-evaluation or self-knowledge.
This interaction highlights neural sensitivity to another’s pupil state relative to the observer, aligning with perception/understanding of others’ states.
The (positive > negative) contrast probes effects of concordant pupillary changes between self and other—part of social signal processing, so includes social processing.
Contrast examines pupillary concordance rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (no relationship/bond comparisons).
Positive correlation of pupils is a form of nonverbal social exchange and thus pertains to social communication (reception of eye-based signals).
Contrast focuses on inter-personal pupillary coupling rather than introspective self-related judgments; does not measure self-perception constructs.
Positive pupillary coherence examines sensitivity to another’s pupillary state and its social meaning—fits perception/understanding of others.
ROI analysis of regions engaged by congruence/discordance in pupillary dynamics addresses processing of social cues, meeting social processing criteria.
ROIs target neural correlates of pupillary signal coherence/incoherence rather than attachment or bonding measures.
ROI analysis examines neural substrates of eye/pupil-based signaling (nonverbal social communication), so it is within social communication.
ROI contrasts index processing of self–other pupillary relations, not explicit self-awareness or self-knowledge tasks; thus not perception_self.
ROIs probe representations of others’ pupil cues and their salience, aligning with perception/understanding of others.

Contrast compares Individualism > Collectivism in an fMRI task probing self-judgments and cultural modulation of social cognition; this is clearly a social processing paradigm (self-construal and social cognition).

The contrast tests cultural self-construal (individualism vs collectivism) during self-judgments, not measures of affiliation, attachment, kinship, or close-relationship bonding; it does not meet tasks/contrasts typical of affiliation/attachment.

The study focuses on self-judgments and cultural values, not on communication processes (facial/expressive reception or production, gaze, or exchange of information); thus it does not meet Social Communication criteria.
The contrast involves neural responses during self-judgments (general/contextual self) and relates directly to Perception and Understanding of Self (self-knowledge/self-awareness).

Although contextual judgments involve social context, the contrast assesses self-representation rather than explicit perception or reasoning about others' mental states; therefore it does not meet Perception of Others criteria.
Collectivism > Individualism contrast probes cultural modulation of social cognition during self-judgments; this is a social processing analysis.
The contrast contrasts cultural self-construal groups during self-related processing, not affiliation/attachment tasks or loved-one vs stranger comparisons.
The analysis addresses self-construal and self-judgments rather than communication exchanges or facial/non-facial communicative processes.
This contrast reflects differences in neural activity during self-judgments as a function of collectivist vs individualist orientation, directly targeting Perception/Understanding of Self.
The focus is on self-representation modulated by cultural values rather than on representations of others' mental states or traits.
General > Contextual contrast compares types of self-judgments (general self vs contextual self) within a social-cognitive framework, so it qualifies as social processing.
The contrast distinguishes general versus contextual self-judgments and does not assess affiliation, bonding, or close-relationship processes.
This is an intra-self comparison (types of self-judgment) rather than a task assessing reception/production of social communicative signals.
The contrast explicitly compares different modes of self-representation (general vs contextual), directly addressing Perception and Understanding of Self.
Although contextual judgments may reference social context, the contrast measures representations of the self rather than of others' states or traits.
Contextual > General contrast examines contextual self-judgments vs general self-judgments within a social-cognitive paradigm and therefore is social processing-related.
The contrast does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, kinship, or loved-one comparisons).
The analysis contrasts types of self-judgments and does not target communicative behaviors or recognition/production of social signals.
This contrast directly measures contextual aspects of self-representation and hence fits Perception and Understanding of Self.
The focus is on self-representation in social context rather than explicit representation or reasoning about others' mental states.

The interaction contrast [(INDgeneral + COLcontextual) - (INDcontextual + COLgeneral)] examines how cultural orientation modulates self-related processing — a social-cognitive effect, so it falls under social processing.
This interaction tests modulation of self-representation by cultural style, not affiliation/attachment behaviors or bonding measures.
The contrast concerns differing self-judgment patterns across cultural styles rather than communication/perception-production of social signals.
The interaction specifically addresses neural representations of general vs contextual self as modulated by individualism/collectivism — directly relevant to Perception/Understanding of Self.
Although cultural context is social, the analysis targets self-representation interactions and does not probe mental-state reasoning about other people.

This whole-brain correlation links contextual-general self-judgment contrast with self-construal style (COL-IND), directly examining cultural influences on social/self processing — a social processing analysis.
The analysis correlates self-judgment neural differences with self-construal scores; it does not measure affiliation/attachment or bonding tasks.
The correlation concerns self-representation vs cultural scores rather than communicative signal reception or production.
The contrast and its correlation with self-construal directly index individual differences in self-representation (contextual vs general), aligning with Perception and Understanding of Self.
The analysis targets self-judgment contrasts and self-construal measures, not explicit assessments of others' mental states or traits.

The contrast (masked sad faces > neutral) involves processing others' facial emotions, which is a social task assessing perception and response to social cues.
This analysis reports main effects of sad faces versus neutral; it does not directly measure affiliation or attachment processes (no affiliation-specific task or contrast).
The task involves reception of facial emotional expressions (masked faces), which falls under reception of facial communication.
The contrast measures responses to others' emotional faces, not self-related processing or self-reflection/agency.
The contrast indexes perception and neural representation of others' emotional states (sad faces), meeting criteria for perception/understanding of others.
The contrast (masked happy faces > neutral) involves automatic processing of others' emotional facial cues, a social processing task.
This analysis reports main effects of happy faces versus neutral and does not directly measure affiliation/attachment behavior or attachment-specific contrasts.
Reception of facial emotional expressions (happy faces) is a form of social communication (receptive facial communication).
The contrast probes responses to others' faces rather than self-related cognition or self-evaluation.
Masked happy faces require perceiving and representing others' emotional states, fitting perception/understanding of others.
This analysis links individual differences (attachment avoidance) to neural responses to masked sad faces, which concerns social processing of others' emotions.
The analysis explicitly examines correlations between attachment avoidance (an attachment trait measured by RSQ) and brain responses, directly addressing affiliation/attachment.
The brain responses are to masked facial expressions (reception of facial communication), and the analysis assesses modulation by attachment, so it fits social communication reception.
Although the analysis uses an individual-difference measure (attachment), the contrast concerns responses to others' emotions rather than self-awareness or self-evaluation processes.
The analysis assesses how attachment relates to perceiving others' negative emotional states (sad faces), fitting perception/understanding of others.
This correlation analysis links attachment avoidance to responses to masked happy faces, involving social processing of facial emotion cues.
The analysis explicitly tests relationships between attachment avoidance (RSQ) and brain responses, directly addressing affiliation/attachment.
Responses are to masked happy faces (reception of facial communication); modulation by attachment implicates social communication processes.
The focus is on perception of others' emotional faces modulated by attachment; it does not measure self-related cognition.
The analysis concerns perceiving and representing others' emotional states (happy faces) and how that varies with attachment, meeting perception-of-others criteria.
This analysis examines negative correlations between attachment avoidance and neural responses to masked happy faces, involving social processing of facial emotion.
The analysis directly tests how an attachment measure (avoidance) relates to brain responses, addressing affiliation/attachment.
The contrast examines reception of facial emotional signals (happy faces) and modulation by attachment, which is within social communication.
This analysis concerns responses to others' emotional faces and their relation to attachment; it does not probe self-awareness or self-evaluation.
The analysis focuses on perceiving others' emotional expressions (happy faces) and how that perception varies with attachment, fitting perception-of-others.

The contrast Pain > No Pain comes from an event-related task showing others in painful vs non-painful situations; this directly probes social processing (empathy for others’ pain).
The task manipulates perceived agency and social context but does not measure affiliation, attachment, or bonding (no kinship/relationship or attachment-focused manipulation).
The contrast indexes perception of others' pain rather than exchange of social information or communicative behaviors; it does not target receptive/expressive communication per se.
The contrast contrasts observed pain in others and does not target self-related processes or self-agency/ self-knowledge.
This contrast explicitly measures perception/understanding of others’ pain (observing others in painful vs non-painful situations), fitting perception-of-others constructs.
No Pain > Pain is derived from the same social/empathy task and therefore involves social processing of observed situations (even though it is the reverse contrast).
This contrast does not probe affiliation or attachment-related constructs (no measures of bonding or close-relationship processing).
The contrast contrasts non-painful vs painful stimuli and does not target communicative exchanges or facial/non-facial communication processes.
No Pain > Pain does not index self-related awareness or agency processes; it concerns perception of others’ states.
Although this is the reverse of Pain>NoPain, it still reflects neural responses to others’ states (here non-painful states) and thus relates to perception/understanding of others.
Self + Other > Self explicitly manipulates social context (presence of another person) and probes social processing mechanisms involved in perceiving social interaction.
Although the contrast involves presence of another, it does not assess affiliation or bonding (no attachment/relationship manipulation).

Comparing Self+Other vs Self focuses on representation of social interaction and processing of social contextual information, which maps onto social communication/reception of social cues in interaction contexts.
This contrast emphasizes the added social context (other present) rather than self-focused processing or self-agency judgments.
The contrast examines effects of another person’s presence on observers’ neural responses and thus indexes perception and understanding of others in social context.
Self > Self + Other is derived from the social-context manipulation and therefore concerns social processing (contrast isolates self-only context effects).
This contrast does not probe attachment or affiliative bonding; it isolates self-only vs social context rather than relationship/attachment processes.
The contrast emphasizes self-only context (reduced social presence) and does not directly index communication or exchange of social information.
Self > Self+Other isolates self-related processing by comparing self-only trials to those including another person, implicating self-related representations (agency/self-awareness relevance).
This contrast highlights self-only contexts and therefore is not primarily measuring perception/understanding of others.
The PPI (PCO > PCS) examines task-modulated connectivity related to perceived agency/social context, which is part of social processing of others’ actions/intentions.
This connectivity contrast targets agency and emotion-related modulation rather than affiliation/attachment processes.
PPI between amygdala and other areas modulated by agency reflects social-affective modulation rather than explicit communicative exchange measures.
Although the contrast concerns perceived agency, it reflects attribution of agency/intentionality in others rather than self-related agency or self-knowledge.

The PPI examines how perceived agency (intentional vs accidental actions by others) modulates connectivity, directly relating to understanding others’ intentions/emotional states (perception of others).
The complementary PPI contrast (PCS > PCO) also probes how perceived agency/social context modulates connectivity and thus indexes social processing.
This contrast addresses agency-modulated connectivity, not affiliation or bonding processes.
The contrast targets emotion- and agency-related connectivity rather than communicative signaling or production/reception of social messages.
It concerns attribution of agency in others and connectivity changes, not self-focused agency or self-knowledge processes.
This PPI contrast reflects modulation by perceived agency/intentionality of others and therefore relates to perception and understanding of others’ mental states.
Correlation of hemodynamic response with emotion contagion scores during PCS trials links neural responses to an empathy-related social measure, thus reflecting social processing.
Emotion contagion is an empathy measure and not a measure of affiliation/attachment or bonding per se.
The analysis links neural responses to trait/state emotion contagion (empathy) rather than communicative behavior or reception/production of social signals.
This correlation concerns empathy for others (emotion contagion) and not self-related processing or self-agency measures.
Emotion contagion reflects sensitivity to others’ emotional states; correlating it with neural responses during PCS trials directly indexes perception/understanding of others.
Correlations between hemodynamic responses and pain ratings during PCS trials relate neural activity to observers’ evaluation of others’ pain, a social-empathic measure.
Pain ratings reflect perceived intensity/empathy rather than affiliation or attachment constructs.
This analysis links subjective pain ratings to neural responses and does not index communicative signal reception or production.
Pain ratings concern perception of others’ pain rather than self-awareness or self-related processing.
Correlating neural responses with observers’ pain ratings during others’ pain trials directly measures perception and evaluation of others’ states.
Emotion contagion score correlations during PCO trials relate empathy-related individual differences to neural responses under a social/agency condition, thus indexing social processing.
This analysis examines emotion contagion (empathy), not affiliation/attachment measures.
The correlation pertains to empathic sensitivity rather than communicative behaviors or reception/production of social signals.
The measure links empathy (response to others) to neural activity under different perceived-agency conditions, not self-focused processes.
Emotion contagion indexes sensitivity to others’ emotions; correlating it with neural responses during PCO trials reflects perception/understanding of others’ emotional/mental states.
Pain-rating correlations during PCO trials connect subjective evaluations of others’ pain to brain activity under an agency-modulated social condition, reflecting social processing.
Pain ratings index empathic perception, not attachment or affiliative bonding.
This analysis focuses on evaluative/empathic ratings, not explicit communicative signal processing or exchange.
These correlations concern judgments about others’ pain rather than self-related cognition or agency.
Linking pain ratings to neural responses during PCO trials measures observers’ perception and assessment of others’ pain/mental states under varying perceived-agency contexts.

The 'You-rest' contrast involves direct self-appraisal, a social-cognitive task concerning self in relation to social information; it measures social processing related to self-perception and reflected perspective-taking in the study.
The 'You-rest' contrast is direct self-reflection and does not assess affiliation or attachment to others (e.g., loved one vs stranger), so it does not meet the affiliation/attachment criteria.

The task is self-appraisal rather than an exchange of social information or communicative behavior (no facial/expressive communication or reception/production measures), so it does not meet social communication criteria.
The 'You-rest' contrast explicitly measures perception and understanding of the self (direct self-appraisal), matching the Perception_Self construct.
The 'You-rest' contrast focuses on self-appraisal rather than representing or reasoning about others' mental states, so it does not meet Perception_Others criteria.
The 'Mom-rest' contrast involves reflected self-appraisal from a relevant other's perspective (mother), which is a social task measuring social processing.
Taking the mother's perspective implicates kinship/close-relationship processes (attachment/affiliation), consistent with affiliation/attachment criteria (e.g., loved one vs stranger).

Although social, the 'Mom-rest' contrast centers on appraisal from another's perspective rather than communicative exchange or reception/production of social signals, so it does not meet Social_Communication criteria.
Reflected self-appraisal from the mother's perspective directly involves perception and understanding of the self (how one is perceived by others), matching Perception_Self.
The 'Mom-rest' contrast requires taking another person's perspective (mother), engaging processes for representing others' beliefs and mental states, consistent with Perception_Others.
The 'Best-rest' contrast involves reflected self-appraisal from a close peer's perspective, a social task measuring social processing.
Taking the perspective of a 'best' friend implicates close social bonds and affiliative processes (peer attachment), consistent with affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.
The contrast focuses on internalized perspective-taking rather than communicative exchanges or perception/production of communicative signals, so it does not meet Social_Communication criteria.
Reflected self-appraisal from a close peer's perspective involves self-perception (how the self is viewed by others), matching Perception_Self.
The 'Best-rest' contrast requires representing another person's perspective (best friend), engaging understanding of others' mental states, consistent with Perception_Others.
The 'Class-rest' contrast involves reflected self-appraisal from a classmate/group perspective, which is social and taps social processing.
Although 'class' refers to a broader peer/group, it still involves social comparison and affiliation-related processes (peer relevance), meeting affiliation/attachment criteria in this study context.
The contrast centers on perspective-taking and self-appraisal rather than communicative behaviors or signal perception/production; thus it does not meet Social_Communication criteria.
Reflected self-appraisal from classmate/group perspective involves self-perception (how the self is construed by others), fitting Perception_Self.
The 'Class-rest' contrast requires taking the perspective of others (classmates), engaging processes of understanding others' viewpoints, consistent with Perception_Others.
Repeat of 'You-rest' contrast in the second table: direct self-appraisal is a social-cognitive task measuring social processing.
As with the first 'You-rest', this direct self condition does not assess affiliation or attachment to others, so it does not meet affiliation/attachment criteria.
This 'You-rest' contrast measures internal self-appraisal rather than communicative behaviors, so it does not meet Social_Communication criteria.
Direct self-appraisal explicitly taps Perception_Self processes.
The contrast does not involve representing others' mental states, so Perception_Others is not applicable.
Repeat 'Mom-rest' in second table: reflected self-appraisal from mother is a social processing task.
Taking the mother's perspective implicates kinship and attachment processes, meeting affiliation/attachment criteria.
Task focuses on perspective-taking about the self from the mother rather than communicative signal exchange; thus Social_Communication is not met.
Reflected self-appraisal from a mother's perspective involves self-perception processes.
Requires representing another's perspective (mother), engaging Perception_Others processes.
Repeat 'Best-rest': reflected self-appraisal from a close peer is a social processing task.
Perspective-taking from a 'best' friend involves close-peer affiliation processes, meeting affiliation/attachment criteria.
The contrast does not index communicative exchange or perceptual production of social signals, so Social_Communication is not applicable.
Reflected self-appraisal from a close peer involves judging the self as viewed by others, fitting Perception_Self.
Requires representation of another's perspective (best friend), consistent with Perception_Others.
Repeat 'Class-rest': reflected self-appraisal from classmate/group perspective is a social processing task.
Perspective-taking from a classmate/group implicates peer-related affiliation and social comparison processes; included under affiliation/attachment in this context.
This contrast centers on perspective-taking and self-reflection rather than communication per se, so it does not meet Social_Communication criteria.
Reflected self-appraisal from classmates involves self-perception processes (how one is viewed by others), matching Perception_Self.
Requires taking the perspective of classmates/peers, engaging processes of understanding others' mental states, consistent with Perception_Others.

Contrast compares Theory of Mind (social mental-state reasoning) vs physical inference during movie scenes, directly measuring social processing (ToM).
Task/contrast probes mental-state reasoning about characters, not affiliation/attachment or close relationship bonding.
Contrast targets mental-state attribution rather than explicit communicative reception/production (e.g., facial or verbal exchange) as the primary construct.
Contrast indexes understanding of others' mental states (ToM), not self-referential processing or self-knowledge.
ToM > physical inference directly measures perception/understanding of others' mental states (explicit mentalizing).
Silent-answer ToM > physical inference isolates mental-state reasoning in a social task (implicit/explicit ToM), so it captures broad social processing.
The contrast targets mentalizing about characters, not measures of attachment or affiliation (no loved-one/stranger or bonding manipulation).
Primary construct is mental-state inference rather than communication-specific processes (reception/production of social signals).
Contrast assesses understanding of others' mental states rather than self-related judgments or self-knowledge.
Explicit comparison of ToM versus physical inference measures representation and reasoning about others' mental states.
MC-answer ToM > physical inference contrast evaluates Theory of Mind in a social-cognitive task, reflecting broad social processing.
Contrast is about mental-state reasoning and not about affiliation/attachment or bonding comparisons.
Focus is on mentalizing rather than communicative signal reception/production per se.
Contrast indexes understanding of others (ToM) rather than self-perception or self-evaluation.
MC ToM > PI measures processes for reasoning about others' mental states, meeting perception-of-others criteria.
IC1 is a T-PICA component mediating face processing and recognition within the broader ToM/network, reflecting social information processing.
Component reflects face processing/recognition, not measures of attachment or social bonds.
Face processing and recognition map onto reception of facial communication (subconstruct of social communication).
Component is described as face/recognition processing, not self-referential processing or self-knowledge.
Face processing is a perceptual representation of others (animacy/action/facial cues) and supports understanding others.
IC2 comprises language-comprehension and temporo-frontal networks implicated in social-cognitive processing, contributing to broader social processing.
Described component supports language comprehension and related processing, not attachment or bonding measures.
Language comprehension and temporo-frontal involvement correspond to reception of non-facial social communication (verbal/social narrative processing).
Component is characterized as language/comprehension-related rather than self-referential processing.
Language and temporo-parietal contributions support representation and reasoning about others (narrative mental-state information).
IC3 includes dorsomedial PFC and precuneus and is linked to self-referential mental activity within the context of the mentalizing network, contributing to social processing.
Component is described as self-referential (dmPFC/precuneus) rather than affiliation/attachment-specific.
Component is characterized as self-referential; it does not primarily index reception/production of social communicative signals.
Authors explicitly describe this component as likely responsible for self-referential mental activity (self-perception/awareness), matching Perception/Self criteria.
Although part of the broader ToM network, this component is described as self-referential and not primarily measuring representation/reasoning about others' mental states.
