The contrast Emotional > Neutral uses drawings of people in emotional vs neutral social situations to probe automatically elicited empathy-related effects and social-cognitive processing; this directly measures social processing.
The task contrasts emotional and neutral situations but does not target affiliation or attachment constructs (no kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation, or attachment measures).
Viewing emotionally charged scenes depicting people involves receptive processing of others' emotional cues (affect recognition), which falls under social communication (receptive aspects).
The contrast measures automatic empathic and social-cognitive responses to others' emotions rather than self-reflection, self-knowledge, or agency.
The contrast assesses representations of others' emotional states (empathy-related responses), aligning with perception and understanding of others (animacy/emotion/mental-state perception).
The Neutral > Emotional contrast still involves the same social stimuli (people in scenes) and probes social processing by comparing emotional content variations, so it measures social processing.
This contrast does not target affiliation/attachment constructs or tasks (no measures of bonding, kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation, etc.).

Although the contrast is the reverse (Neutral > Emotional), it still contrasts conditions differing in emotional/social content and involves perception of social-affective cues, fitting receptive social communication processes.
Participants were instructed to watch pictures for a memory task and not to reflect on themselves; the contrast does not measure self-perception or self-related judgments.
This contrast involves perceiving and differentiating others' emotional states (even if showing reduced responses for neutral), aligning with perception and understanding of others.
The Social relation > Single person contrast manipulates number of people (two vs one) to index automatic social-cognitive processes (STS, medial PFC), directly measuring social processing.
The contrast compares one versus two persons to probe social cognitive processing, but it does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding or relationship-specific measures).

The contrast targets social-cognitive processing of social scenes (presence of multiple people) rather than explicit communication exchange or receptive/expressive communication measures; it does not specifically assess social communication subconstructs.
This contrast is designed to probe processing of others and social interactions, not self-related awareness or judgments.

Comparing stimuli with two persons vs one person elicits social-cognitive processes involved in representing others and interactions (STS and medial PFC activations), matching perception and understanding of others (mental state/interaction processing).

The Self > syllables contrast asks participants to make personality trait judgments about themselves, which is a social-related task involving self-referential social cognition and simulation. This meets criteria for social processing (task is social and the contrast measures social processing).

The contrast involves self trait judgments versus low-level control (syllables). It does not probe affiliation or attachment (no measures of bonding, close-relationship processes, or loved-one vs stranger comparisons).
The task is not about communicative exchanges, facial or non-facial communication reception/production; it is a trait judgment task. Therefore it does not meet social communication criteria.

The contrast explicitly involves making judgments about the self (self-referential trait evaluation), directly measuring perception/understanding of self (self-knowledge and self-referential processes).
This contrast focuses on self judgments (Self > syllables) and does not measure perception/understanding of others.

The Other > syllables contrast involves making personality judgments about a friend (another person), which is a social task engaging perception/understanding of others and simulation. It therefore meets social processing criteria.

Although the referent is a friend, the contrast tests trait judgments and memory rather than affiliation or attachment per se (no explicit measures of bonding or attachment). Thus it does not meet the specific affiliation/attachment criteria.
The task is trait judgment about another person and not an exchange or processing of communicative signals (faces, gaze, verbal communication), so it does not meet social communication criteria.
The Other > syllables contrast focuses on judgments about another person (friend), not self-referential processing, so it does not measure perception/understanding of self.
This contrast directly involves making trait judgments about another person (friend), which measures perception and understanding of others (traits/attributes), satisfying the inclusion criteria.

The Self > other contrast compares self-referential trait judgments to judgments about another person, directly probing social cognitive processes and differences between self and other processing; it therefore qualifies as social processing.
The contrast examines self versus friend trait judgments and associated memory, but it is not specifically assessing affiliation or attachment constructs (no bonding/attachment measures).
This contrast contrasts self and other trait judgments rather than communicative processes (facial or verbal communication), so it does not meet social communication inclusion criteria.
The Self > other contrast isolates processing related to self-referential judgments over judgments about another person, so it directly measures perception/understanding of self.
Because this contrast highlights self > other, it is focused on self-related processing rather than indexing perception/understanding of others.

The Other > self contrast isolates processing related to judgments about another person (friend) compared with self, which is clearly social processing involving representation of others and social cognition.

Although the referent is a friend, the contrast targets trait judgments (and memory) rather than constructs of affiliation/attachment specifically, so it does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.
This contrast compares trait judgments about another person to self-judgments and does not involve communicative signal processing; thus it does not meet social communication criteria.
Other > self emphasizes processing of another person over the self, so it does not measure perception/understanding of self.
This contrast isolates processing of another person (friend) greater than self, directly measuring perception/understanding of others (traits and similarity-based processing).

The task is explicitly social: participants watched a character attend to occluded stimuli and the analyses assess neural representation of what another person sees (joint attention, social inference). This directly measures social processing (representation of others’ mental content).

The task involves perceiving another’s visual focus and inferring content, not measuring affiliation, attachment, or bonding. No contrasts or measures relating to loved ones, kinship, cooperation, or attachment are present.

The paradigm involves gaze/attention of a character and representing what they see (gaze following/joint attention), which falls under nonverbal social communication processes (receptive/production aspects such as gaze following).
Analyses concern perception and representation of another person's visual experience, not self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge. The contrasts do not probe self-related processing.

The contrasts directly probe how observers represent another person's perceptual content (what the character is seeing), which matches Perception and Understanding of Others (animacy/action/mental state understanding).

Same task as above: contrasts compare neural responses when viewing another person attending to bodies vs places, directly assessing social cognition and representation of another’s perceptual content (social processing).

No measures or contrasts related to affiliation, attachment, or relationship-specific processing (e.g., loved one vs stranger) are present in this task; it manipulates object category and observed attention, not attachment.

The contrast involves another's gaze/attention to different stimulus categories; representation of another's focus and inferred content involves social communicative processes (gaze-following/joint attention), fitting the social communication construct.
The analyses target how the participant represents another person's visual experience, not introspection or self-related judgments, so perception/self constructs are not engaged by these contrasts.

The study directly examines representation of what another person is seeing (inferring their perceptual content), which is squarely within Perception and Understanding of Others (understanding mental states/attention).

Experiment 1 contrasts live interactive versus recorded cooperative games — a social interaction task assessing contingent social responding and joint attention, directly measuring social processing.

Experiment 1 used cooperative social interaction (cooperative games), which maps onto affiliation/attachment constructs (cooperation/social bonding), so the contrast assesses affiliation-related processes.

Live face-to-face interaction with contingent responding, gaze and facial exchanges involves production and reception of facial/social communicative signals (e.g., gaze following), so this contrast measures social communication.
The task contrasts examine interactive social processing and joint attention, not self-reflection, agency, or self-knowledge; thus they do not measure perception/understanding of the self.
Live vs recorded interaction engages representations about others (gaze, intentions, mental states; rTPJ/rSTS activation reported), so this contrast measures perception and understanding of others.
Although this contrast shows greater activation for Recorded>Live, it derives from the same social interaction paradigm (live vs recorded cooperative interaction) and thus measures social processing.

The underlying task is cooperative interaction which probes affiliation/attachment-related processes; even if the Recorded condition shows greater activation, the analysis pertains to affiliation-relevant social behavior.
Both Live and Recorded conditions involve facial/gaze information and social signaling; this contrast still reflects social communicative processing.
The contrast compares modes of social presentation (live vs recorded) and does not target self-related processing or self-reflection.
The contrast examines processing of another person (live experimenter vs recorded), implicating perception/understanding of others (gaze, intentions), so it meets perception_others criteria.

Experiment 2 directly manipulates Joint Attention versus Solo Attention — a core social interaction construct involving shared attention and contingent social behavior, thus indexing social processing.

Joint attention primarily probes gaze-following and shared attention/communication rather than explicit affiliation, bonding, or cooperative relationship measures, so it does not specifically measure affiliation/attachment.
Joint attention is a prototypical social communicative behavior (gaze following, shared referential communication), so the JA>SA contrast measures social communication processes.
The contrast targets joint versus solo attention to others' gaze and targets, not self-reflective or self-knowledge processes.
Joint attention requires representing others' gaze and likely their attentional/intentional states (rTPJ/rpSTS involvement), so this contrast measures perception and understanding of others.
Solo>Joint contrast still arises from the joint attention paradigm (a social task manipulating shared attention), and thus pertains to social processing even when Solo shows greater activation.
Solo Attention involves finding targets without shared attention and does not target affiliation/bonding processes specifically, so it does not meet affiliation/attachment criteria.

Both Solo and Joint conditions include communicative components (visibility of experimenter, gaze cues); the contrast reflects differences in social communicative processing (presence vs absence of shared attention).
This contrast concerns attention to others' gaze/targets rather than self-related cognition or self-reflection.
Solo>Joint contrasts processing of another person's presence and gaze behavior even when not sharing attention, implicating perception/understanding of others' actions/attentional states.

The analysis examines neural responses to warmth expectancy violations vs consistent social targets; this is a social task probing social perception and learning, directly measuring social processing.

Warmth is the primary social dimension related to affiliation (trustworthiness, warmth, intent to help), and the contrast probes expectancy violations in warmth which relate to affiliation/attachment processes.
The task involves perceiving trait-consistent or -violating individuals rather than exchanging or processing communicative signals; it does not measure social communication per the examples.
The contrast concerns perception and evaluation of others' warmth, not self-related judgments or self-referential processing.
The analysis explicitly assesses representations and evaluations of other people (warmth expectancy violations vs consistent targets), fitting perception/understanding of others.
This analysis contrasts neural activity for warmth expectancy-consistent social targets; it is a social perception task measuring social processing.
Warmth-consistent targets engage the affiliation-related dimension of social evaluation (trustworthiness/warmth), relevant to affiliation/attachment processes.
The contrast examines trait consistency in targets rather than communicative behaviors or exchange of social information; it does not measure social communication per criteria.
This analysis focuses on perception of other people (warmth-consistent targets) and not on self-related processing.
Contrasting warmth-consistent targets assesses perceptions and evaluations of others' traits and fits the perception/understanding of others construct.
This analysis probes neural responses to competence expectancy violations vs consistent social targets; it is a social task measuring social processing.
Competence relates to perceived ability/status rather than affiliation/attachment; the task focuses on competence expectancy violations which are not primarily affiliation measures.
The contrast concerns trait expectancy violations (competence) and not communicative exchange or facial/gesture communication; it does not meet social communication criteria.
The analysis targets perception of others' competence, not self-related judgments or self-awareness.
Assessing competence expectancy violations involves representing and evaluating others' traits and abilities, directly mapping onto perception/understanding of others.
This analysis contrasts neural activity for competence expectancy-consistent social targets; it is a social perception task measuring social processing.
Competence-consistent targets pertain to status/ability dimensions rather than affiliation/attachment, so this does not primarily measure affiliation processes.
The contrast examines trait consistency (competence) in targets rather than communicative behaviors or exchanges, so it does not meet social communication criteria.
The contrast concerns perception of others' competence rather than self-related processing or judgments.
Evaluating competence-consistent targets involves representation and assessment of others' traits/abilities, fitting perception/understanding of others.

The experiment required participants to imagine scenarios from self, loved-one, and stranger perspectives and the study focuses on empathy and social attachment; the reported 'effect of pain' comes from this social task and reflects engagement of the empathy/social-processing network (ACC, insula, TPJ). Therefore this analysis derives from a social-related task and measures social processing (empathic responses to others' pain).

Affiliation/attachment requires contrasts that specifically index relationship closeness (e.g., Loved one vs Stranger). This analysis reports the main effect of pain across stimuli and does not appear to be the Loved-vs-Stranger affiliation contrast, so it does not specifically measure affiliation/attachment.

Social communication relates to exchanging socially relevant information (facial/non-facial communication). The reported analysis is a main effect of pain (painful vs non-painful stimuli) and does not probe communicative processes or reception/production of social signals, so it does not meet the social communication inclusion criteria.

Perception/self-understanding annotations require contrasts directly indexing self-related processing (e.g., self vs other). The 'effect of pain' analysis is not described as a self-specific contrast and therefore does not specifically measure perception/understanding of the self.

Perception of others requires contrasts assessing understanding or reasoning about others' states (e.g., Loved vs Stranger or other-other specific contrasts). While the pain effect involves empathic pain processing, the reported analysis is a main effect of painful stimuli rather than an explicit perception-of-others contrast, so it does not clearly meet the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

The Preference condition explicitly requires subjects to make social preference judgments ('Do I like this person?') using faces, which is a social-related task and directly measures social processing related to forming social evaluations and decisions.

The task measures immediate social preference judgments for faces but does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation) or attachment-related comparisons; therefore it does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.

The task involves perception of faces and judging social preference, engaging reception of facial information relevant to social communication (affective/social cues), so it fits the social communication construct.

Making a preference judgment about another person is a self-referential evaluation ("Do I like this person?") and therefore involves perception/understanding of the self (self-related appraisal), meeting the self-perception inclusion criteria.
The Preference task requires assessing another person's attributes (likability), which involves representing and reasoning about others' social qualities, matching perception/understanding of others.

The Gender identification task involves processing social stimuli (human faces) and is part of the study's social tasks; it therefore qualifies as social processing, though less evaluative than the Preference task.

Gender identification is a perceptual categorization of faces and does not probe affiliation or attachment-related constructs or relationships, so it does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.

Gender identification requires reception of facial information (face perception and categorization), which falls under the reception subconstruct of social communication (facial communication reception).
Gender identification is not a self-referential judgment and does not involve awareness or evaluation of the self, so it does not meet the perception_self criteria.
Identifying another person's gender involves perceiving and characterizing another individual (an other-focused perceptual judgment), so it matches perception/understanding of others.

The contrast Preference > Gender isolates neural activity related to social preference evaluation (making liking judgments) beyond basic face categorization; this directly measures social processing involved in social evaluation.

Although Preference > Gender isolates evaluative social processing, it does not specifically target affiliation/attachment constructs (e.g., close relationships, kinship) or attachment-related contrasts, so it does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.

The contrast emphasizes processing of socially relevant face information in the service of a communicative/social-evaluative judgment (reception of facial/social cues), so it fits social communication
Preference > Gender captures self-referential evaluative processes (the subject's own liking judgments), aligning with perception and understanding of the self (self-evaluation/knowledge).
This contrast reflects evaluating others (likability) and thus involves representing and reasoning about others' social attributes, consistent with perception/understanding of others.

The Gender > Preference contrast isolates processes more engaged during gender identification than preference, but it still involves social stimuli (faces) and thus is within the domain of social processing.
Gender > Preference does not probe affiliation or attachment-related processes or comparisons, so it does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.
This contrast emphasizes face perception/categorization processes (reception of facial information), which falls under social communication.
Gender > Preference isolates non-self-referential perceptual categorization and does not measure self-related appraisal, so it does not meet perception_self criteria.
The contrast involves assessing attributes of other people (their gender), so it constitutes perception/understanding of others.

PPI analyses with an anterior medial frontal cortex (aMFC) seed report task-dependent coupling during the social preference task; these connectivity results directly reflect social processing related to forming preferences and network interactions underlying social evaluation.

Although the PPI examines network interactions during a social preference task, it does not specifically assess affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of bonding or relationships), so affiliation/attachment is not met.

The PPI findings describe coupling between midline structures and task-positive networks during face-based preference judgments, implicating processes that support reception/processing of socially relevant facial information and communicative evaluation.

Medial frontal regions (including aMFC) and their task-modulated connectivity are strongly implicated in self-referential processing; PPI effects tied to preference judgments indicate involvement of self-related appraisal processes.
The aMFC PPI shows network interactions when evaluating others (likability), reflecting processes of representing and reasoning about others, consistent with perception of others.

PPI analyses with a ventral medial frontal cortex (vMFC) seed describe task-dependent coupling during social preference judgments; these connectivity patterns reflect social processing during evaluative tasks.

The vMFC connectivity results relate to preference evaluation but do not specifically probe affiliation or attachment constructs (no measures of close relationships or bonding), so affiliation/attachment is not applicable.

vMFC coupling during face-based preference judgments implicates processing of socially relevant facial/affective cues and communicative evaluation, fitting within social communication (reception of facial cues).
vMFC is commonly linked to self-referential and valuation processes; task-dependent connectivity during preference judgments indicates involvement of self-related evaluation processes.
vMFC PPI effects during preference judgments reflect processing about others' likability and value, consistent with perception and understanding of others.

PPI analyses with a posterior cingulate cortex (PCC) seed report task-modulated coupling during the social preference task; these connectivity patterns are central to social processing of evaluative judgments.

While PCC connectivity is reported for preference judgments, the analyses do not explicitly assess affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding or relationship measures), so affiliation/attachment is not indicated.

PCC task-dependent coupling during face preference judgments supports processing of socially relevant information and interactions with networks involved in face and social cue processing, fitting social communication.
PCC is part of cortical midline structures implicated in self-referential processing; PPI effects during preference judgments suggest involvement of self-related evaluative processes.
PCC coupling during preference judgments indicates representation and evaluation of others (their likability), consistent with perception and understanding of others.

The Cyberball social exclusion paradigm is a social-related task that manipulates inclusion vs. exclusion, directly measuring social processing of rejection and belonging.
Cyberball operationalizes social inclusion/exclusion and therefore measures affiliation/belonging-related processes (attachment to peer group), matching the affiliation/attachment construct.

The task does not primarily probe exchange of social information (facial or verbal communication); it manipulates inclusion/exclusion rather than communication per se, so it does not meet the Social Communication inclusion criteria.

Although exclusion can influence self-related processing, the contrast (exclusion > inclusion) targets social rejection/belonging rather than explicit self-evaluation or self-knowledge tasks; it does not directly measure perception/understanding of the self per the inclusion criteria.
Interpreting exclusion requires representing others' actions/intentions (being excluded by peers), so the analysis taps perception and understanding of others' social behavior.
The inclusion > exclusion contrast is derived from the Cyberball social task and measures responses to social inclusion, a core social processing construct.
Social inclusion directly relates to affiliation and bonding with peers, matching the affiliation/attachment construct.

The contrast reflects inclusion vs exclusion but does not involve exchange of communicative signals (facial/non-facial) or communicative production/reception processes required for Social Communication annotation.

The contrast does not specifically measure self-awareness, self-evaluation, or self-knowledge; it indexes social inclusion processes rather than perception/understanding of the self per the inclusion criteria.
Experiencing inclusion involves interpreting others' pro-social actions (passing the ball), engaging perception/understanding of others' social behavior and intentions.

Contrast compares observation of painful situations (self-caused pain vs no-pain), which is a social-emotional task involving understanding others’ affective states and therefore measures social processing.
The task measures empathy/sympathy for pain and intentionality, not affiliation, bonding, or attachment processes (no measures of close relationships or kinship).
The stimuli involve perception of pain and moral/affective appraisal rather than exchange of social information or communicative signals (no facial/expressive communication or gaze following).

Although labeled ‘self’, the contrast contrasts observed painful situations caused by (a) the self versus no-pain; the task assesses perception of others’ painful states and intentionality rather than participants’ self-awareness or self-judgment.
The contrast requires representing and evaluating others’ emotional/physical states (pain) and causal/intentional information about those others, matching Perception and Understanding of Others.

This contrast directly targets empathic/sympathetic responses by comparing pain caused by others vs self, which is a core social processing task involving evaluation of others’ emotions and social intent.
The contrast concerns moral/emotional responses to pain and intentionality, not affiliation or attachment processes (no measures of bonding, kinship, or relationship closeness).
The task does not involve communicative behaviors or explicit reception/production of facial/non-facial communication; it targets affective appraisal rather than social communication per se.

The contrast contrasts pain caused by others versus pain caused by self, but it primarily assesses perception of others’ emotional/intentional states rather than introspective self-knowledge or agency judgments about the participant’s own internal states.
Comparing pain caused by others versus self requires representing and reasoning about others’ mental/affective states and intentions, fitting Perception and Understanding of Others.

The analysis does not involve self-related judgments, self-awareness, or self-knowledge; it focuses on perceiving and individuating external faces and objects rather than the self.

Identity discrimination of human faces entails perceiving and distinguishing other individuals, which aligns with Perception and Understanding of Others (representations about others’ identity/traits).

The task is explicitly social: participants view politicians paired with political views and form impressions based on affiliation and views. Retrieval of social context reflects representations of interactions with others and thus relates to perceiving/understanding others' actions/states within a social narrative context.

The self-generation contrast is directly about retrieval of self-produced versus other-produced material, reflecting self-related processing (agency/self-knowledge) and thus meets Perception/Understanding of Self criteria.

The contrast (Costly-Donation vs Noncostly-Reward) involves prosocial decisions toward family, a clearly social task assessing processes of perceiving, evaluating, and responding to social information; the study explicitly reports recruitment of social cognition (mentalizing) and self-control during these social decisions.

The task measures affiliation/attachment directly: decisions involve contributing money to one’s family (kinship/close relationship), and individual differences in family obligation preferences modulate neural responses, matching affiliation/attachment criteria.

The task involves prosocial decision-making toward family but does not involve exchange of socially relevant information, communication, or expressive/receptive signaling; it is not a communication task per se, so the Social Communication inclusion criteria are not met.

The contrast pits personal reward against costly donation to family, requiring self-control and evaluation of self-related outcomes; the study highlights self-control processes, indicating engagement of self-referential processing.

Decisions to help family require representing others’ needs and mental states (mentalizing); the abstract explicitly reports recruitment of mentalizing regions and modulation by family obligation, satisfying Perception/Understanding of Others.

This analysis identifies neural regions associated with family obligation preferences during costly family donations vs noncostly rewards — a social task probing how social preferences shape processing, matching Social Processing criteria.
The analysis explicitly tests family obligation preferences (attachment/affiliation) and their neural correlates when deciding to donate to family, directly measuring affiliation/attachment.

Although the analysis concerns family-related decisions, it focuses on preferences and neural correlates rather than communication exchange or signaling; it does not measure Social Communication per the construct definition.

Relations between family obligation preferences and neural activity during these decisions reflect self-relevant regulatory processes (self-control, valuation of self vs others), indicating Perception/Understanding of Self involvement.
Family obligation preferences modulate regions involved in mentalizing and considering others, so this analysis measures representation and reasoning about others’ states/needs.

This PPI analysis examines ventral striatum connectivity during costly family donation decisions and its relation to family obligation — a social/neuroeconomic measure of prosocial behavior and social processing.

Connectivity that correlates with family obligation preferences indicates neural mechanisms by which attachment/affiliation shapes reward processing during family-directed prosocial acts, meeting affiliation/attachment criteria.

The PPI connectivity analysis addresses coupling between reward and self-control/mentalizing regions during prosocial choice, not communicative exchange; it does not assess Social Communication processes directly.

The analysis highlights coupling of self-control and mentalizing regions with the ventral striatum during prosocial decisions, reflecting self-related control and valuation processes (self-monitoring/agency) engaged when choosing to sacrifice for family.

Stronger functional coupling with mentalizing regions as a function of family obligation indicates representation and consideration of others’ states (understanding mental states) during prosocial reward processing.

Contrast (Incongruent > Congruent) pooled across human and machine isolates executive control (Stroop effect) rather than social processing per se. Although the overall experiment includes social conditions, this contrast does not specifically measure social/ToM processes.
The task includes competition, but this contrast compares conflict (I vs C) across both human and machine partners and does not isolate affiliation/attachment or competitive social bonding processes.
The contrast targets executive conflict processing (Stroop) pooled across partner types and does not specifically index social communicative exchange or reception/production of social signals.
This contrast does not involve judgments or representations about the self (agency or self-knowledge); it indexes cognitive control demands regardless of partner type.
Although the task involves opponents, this pooled I>C contrast does not specifically probe representations or mental state inference about others (human vs machine distinction is not tested here).
The reverse Stroop contrast (Congruent > Incongruent) pooled across human and machine primarily reflects reduced executive demand; it does not specifically measure social processing or ToM.
Although the underlying task is competitive, this contrast does not isolate affiliation/attachment or competition-related social processing (it contrasts conflict level, not partner type).
This contrast addresses conflict level (C > I) across partners, not communicative exchange or processing of social signals; it does not meet the social communication inclusion.
No self-referential judgments or self-knowledge processes are targeted by this contrast.
The contrast does not compare human versus machine or otherwise isolate mentalizing about others; it reflects conflict modulation only.

This contrast compares Human > Machine competitors (collapsing task difficulty), directly isolating social (human-human) interaction effects and Theory-of-Mind related processing present in the study. It therefore measures social processing.

Contrast compares competition against a human vs a machine; competition is an example of affiliation/attachment-related social scenarios (cooperation/competition), so this contrast measures that construct.

Differentiating human from machine opponents taps social interaction/communication processes (reception/interpretation of another agent’s behavior); the contrast measures social-communicative processing.
The contrast targets perception/processing of the opponent (other) rather than self-referential or agency/self-knowledge processes.
Directly contrasts human versus machine competitors, thereby isolating processes related to understanding others’ states/intentions (mentalizing/animacy perception).

This contrast (Machine > Human) still isolates differences between human and non-human opponents, and thus probes social processing by highlighting regions more active for machine compared to human competition (reverse social effect).

Although direction is reversed, the contrast compares human vs machine competitive contexts, which are within the affiliation/attachment domain (competition/social comparison), so it measures that construct.
Contrasting responses to machine versus human opponents concerns social-interaction/communication processing (how participants process agents), so it meets the social communication inclusion.
No self-referential or agency-focused judgments are isolated by this contrast; it pertains to processing of the opponent type.
The contrast isolates processing differences related to perceiving/representing others (human vs machine), relevant to mentalizing/animacy perception.

This interaction ([Human (I>C)] > [Machine (I>C)]) identifies executive control regions specifically modulated by social (human) competition, directly indexing social processing and mentalizing in a competitive context.
The interaction isolates competition-related modulation that is specific to human opponents, thus tapping affiliation/attachment-related social adjustments in the competitive context.
By showing greater Stroop-related activation for human vs machine opponents, this contrast implicates social-interaction/communication processes (integration of social information with task demands).
The contrast reflects modulation by opponent type and conflict, not self-related judgments or self-knowledge processes.
The effect demonstrates modulation of executive control when interacting with a human opponent, implicating processes involved in understanding others (mentalizing) in the competitive context.

The reverse interaction ([Machine (I>C)] > [Human (I>C)]) still contrasts social versus non-social modulation of executive control and therefore indexes social processing differences between opponent types.

This interaction contrast isolates competition-modulated effects that differ by opponent type; despite direction, it addresses competition/social adjustment processes relevant to affiliation/attachment constructs.
The contrast reflects differences in how social vs non-social opponents modulate task-related processing, which pertains to social interaction/communication processing.
No self-specific perception or self-referential judgments are isolated by this contrast; it concerns opponent-type modulation.

By showing differential modulation for machine vs human opponents, this contrast is informative about representations of others (animacy/mental state inference) and thus meets perception-of-others criteria.

The contrast examines neural responses to social exclusion versus fair play in an interactive peer task, which directly measures social processing of exclusion events.

The task involves interactive social exchange (ball-toss) and comparisons of social interaction conditions (exclusion vs fair play), fitting the broader inclusion examples (cooperation/competition).
The contrast targets responses to social exclusion broadly and does not explicitly assess self-knowledge, agency, or self-judgment processes.
Exclusion involves processing others' (peers') actions and intentions (who excludes and how), so this contrast taps understanding of others' social behavior.
Fair play > social exclusion contrasts responses to social inclusion versus exclusion in the same interactive peer context, a social processing measure.
Fair play reflects affiliation/inclusion and thus the contrast measures affiliation-related neural responses.
The interactive nature of the task (ball-toss) examines aspects of social exchange and interaction, fitting social communication inclusion.
This contrast reflects inclusionary social context but does not directly probe self-related judgments or self-knowledge processes.
Fair play involves perceiving peers' inclusive behavior; the contrast engages processing of others' actions and intentions.
This contrast (exclusion > fair play) computed separately by gender condition examines social processing of exclusion within specific social-group contexts.

The interactive game and group-manipulation involve social exchange and group-based interaction, consistent with social communication constructs.
Although group membership is manipulated, the contrast focuses on neural responses to exclusion and not on explicit self-judgment or self-knowledge measures.
The analysis interrogates responses to actions of same- versus other-gender peers (others' behavior), engaging understanding of others' social behavior and group membership.
The same-gender > other-gender contrast examines differential social processing depending on the relation of excluders to the participant (in-group vs out-group).
Greater activation for same-gender exclusion implicates affiliation-related processes (ingroup bond threat), so the contrast measures affiliation/attachment relevance.
Comparing responses based on social-group membership involves social-interaction dynamics consistent with social communication constructs.
This contrast addresses group-based differences in responses to exclusion rather than explicit self-reflection or self-knowledge processes.
Directly contrasts responses to same- versus other-gender peers, implicating processing of others' group identity and behaviors.
Other-gender > same-gender contrast probes social processing of exclusion when excluders are out-group peers, a social cognition measure.
Responses to exclusion by other-gender peers still relate to affiliation/attachment processes (threat or lack thereof to social bonds), so the contrast is relevant.
The contrast assesses social-interaction dynamics modulated by group membership, aligning with social communication inclusion criteria.
The focus is on differential processing of others (other-gender peers) rather than explicit self-related processing.
Contrasting other- versus same-gender exclusion targets how participants represent and respond to others from different social groups, engaging perception of others.
This analysis examines how implicit gender-self associations modulate neural responses to exclusion in the same-gender condition, a social processing individual-differences analysis.
Implicit self–gender associations likely influence affiliation-related responses to same-gender exclusion; the analysis directly probes this modulation.
The modulation of interactive social exclusion responses by implicit attitudes concerns social-interaction dynamics and thus fits social communication inclusion.
This analysis uses a Gender–Self IAT (implicit self-association) as a covariate, directly indexing self-related associations; thus it measures perception/understanding of self.
Implicit gender attitudes also inform representations of others (same-gender peers) and their social relevance; the analysis therefore engages perception of others.
This analysis examines how implicit gender–self associations modulate neural responses to exclusion in the other-gender condition, a social processing individual-differences analysis.
Implicit self–gender associations may alter affiliation-related responses even when excluders are other-gender; the analysis probes affiliation modulation by IAT.
Examining how implicit attitudes modulate responses in an interactive social game implicates social-interaction processes consistent with social communication.
Because the covariate is the Gender–Self IAT, this analysis directly indexes implicit self-related associations and thus meets perception_self criteria.
Implicit gender-self associations may affect representations of out-group others and how their exclusion is processed; the analysis engages perception of others.
This analysis tests how implicit gender–good associations modulate neural responses to same-gender exclusion, an individual-differences social processing effect.
Implicit evaluations of gender (good/bad) can influence affiliation and perceived closeness with same-gender peers; correlation with exclusion responses is relevant to attachment processes.
The modulation of interactive social responses by implicit evaluative attitudes pertains to social-interaction dynamics, consistent with social communication.
A Gender–Good IAT indexes evaluative associations with gender groups rather than self-related associations, so this analysis does not directly measure perception/understanding of self.
Evaluative implicit attitudes toward gender groups inform judgments about others; the analysis tests how these attitudes modulate processing of same-gender peers (others).
This analysis looks at how implicit gender–good associations modulate neural responses to other-gender exclusion, an individual-differences social processing analysis.
Implicit evaluative associations with gender may modify affiliation-related responses to exclusion by other-gender peers; the analysis is relevant to attachment/affiliation.
The effect of implicit evaluative attitudes on responses in an interactive social game involves social-interaction mechanisms consistent with social communication.
The Gender–Good IAT assesses evaluative group associations rather than self-related associations, so the analysis does not directly probe self-perception.
Implicit evaluative attitudes about gender groups inform processing of other-gender peers; the analysis addresses perception and evaluation of others' group membership and behavior.

The ROIs were defined for real-time classification of decisions made during the ultimatum game, a social interaction task involving negotiation and prediction of a partner’s choice — this directly measures social processing.

The task involves cooperative/competitive negotiation (ultimatum game) where social bonds and strategic affiliation/competition affect decisions; ROIs were chosen to predict partner behavior in this social interaction context.

The ultimatum game entails exchanging offers and socio-evaluative signals between players; ROIs were used to classify signals predictive of those communicative decisions, meeting social communication criteria.

Predicting behavior and classifying subjective emotional/motivational states during decisions implicates self-related evaluative processes (self-monitoring/agency), so the ROIs are relevant to perception/understanding of self.

The goal was to predict the partner’s decisions and distinguish processes related to others’ motivations and intentions, indicating representation and understanding of others; thus ROIs relate to perception of others.
The discriminative volumes were identified to predict decisions in the ultimatum game — a prototypical social interaction — so the contrast measures social processing.

Offline classification of decision-related volumes pertains to cooperation/competition in the economic game context, implicating affiliation/attachment processes relevant to bargaining and social adjustment.
Volumes discriminative for decisions reflect neural patterns encoding communicated intent or responses to offers, fitting social communication constructs.
The discriminative patterns included regions associated with subjective emotional/motivational states and decision-related self-evaluation, consistent with perception/understanding of self processes.
These volumes were used to predict and distinguish partners’ forthcoming decisions and reward-related responses, indicating neural representations of others’ intentions and states.
Classification of different offer types in the ultimatum game directly probes social decision-making and perception of social offers, thus measuring social processing.
Differentiating offer types (70:30 vs 80:20) taps cooperative/competitive valuation and social fairness considerations relevant to affiliation/attachment processes in negotiation.
Offers are a form of social communication conveying intent and value; classifying offer types captures neural processing of communicative social signals between players.
Responding to and evaluating offers involves self-referential valuation and decision-related self-monitoring (subjective motivational states), so this classification implicates perception of self.
Discriminating offer types requires representing the proposer’s intentions and fairness norms, corresponding to perception and understanding of others’ actions and mental states.
Classification of 50:50 vs 65:35 offers examines neural responses to differing social-economic proposals in the ultimatum game, a social processing measure.
Differentiating near-fair (50:50) vs less-fair (65:35) offers probes social bonding and fairness considerations relevant to affiliation/attachment during negotiation.
These offer comparisons reflect communicative intent and social signal interpretation between players; classifying them addresses social communication processes.
Evaluating fairness and potential responses to offers engages self-related judgment and emotional/motivational states, so the analysis maps onto perception/understanding of self.
Distinguishing offer types requires assessing the proposer’s intentions and likely behavior, implicating perception and understanding of others’ mental states and actions.

The contrast compares biological motion (point-light displays of human locomotion) vs scrambled displays, which probes perception of socially relevant human actions and thus measures social processing broadly.

The task involves perception of biological motion and does not assess affiliation, attachment, bonding, or related social relationship constructs. It does not meet the affiliation/attachment task requirements.

The task measures visual perception of biological motion (action perception) rather than exchange of socially relevant information or communicative behaviors (receptive/expressive communication), so it does not meet social communication criteria.
The contrast examines perception of others' actions (biological motion) and not self-related processing, agency, or self-knowledge, so it does not meet self-perception criteria.

Biological motion point-light displays specifically probe action perception/animacy perception of others; the contrast directly measures perception and understanding of others' actions, matching the Action Perception subconstruct.

Seed-based connectivity analysis from left cerebellar Crus I during the biological motion task examines network interactions relevant to perceiving others' actions (connectivity with right STS), and thus pertains to social processing.
The functional connectivity analysis assesses neural coupling during biological motion perception and does not test affiliation or attachment constructs (no measures of bonding or relationship).

Although STS can be involved in social communication, this analysis focuses on perceptual processing of biological motion and cerebro-cerebellar connectivity, not on communicative exchange tasks or measures of social communication per se.
The analysis probes connectivity related to perception of others' actions, not self-related judgments or agency/self-knowledge, so it does not meet perception_self criteria.

Connectivity with right posterior STS during a biological motion task reflects neural mechanisms supporting perception and understanding of others' actions (action/animacy perception), satisfying perception_others criteria.

The contrast (neutral vs emotional prosody) directly probes social processing by requiring participants to interpret emotional states from vocal tone, meeting both criteria: it is a social-related task (I1) and the contrast measures social processing (I2).

The task assesses emotional prosody comprehension rather than affiliation/attachment constructs (e.g., bonding, loved-one vs stranger). It does not measure attachment-related processes, so inclusion criteria are not met.
Emotional prosody is a form of non-facial social communication (receptive), so the contrast directly measures social communication (reception of non-facial cues). This meets both I1 and I2.
The analyses concern perceiving others' emotions from prosody, not self-related awareness or judgments. Thus criteria for Perception/Self are not met.

Emotional prosody comprehension requires representing and inferring others' emotional states (understanding mental states), so the contrast measures Perception/Understanding of Others; both I1 and I2 apply.

The contrast (simple vs complex emotions in prosody) manipulates socio-cognitive demand in interpreting others’ emotions, so it is a social-related task and measures social processing (both I1 and I2).
This contrast differentiates emotion complexity in prosody and does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding or loved-one vs stranger comparisons), so inclusion criteria are not met.
Discriminating simple from complex emotional prosody is a receptive non-facial social communication task, satisfying both I1 and I2 for Social Communication.
The contrast targets processing of others’ emotional signals rather than self-perception or self-knowledge, so Perception/Self criteria are not met.
The manipulation targets inference about others’ emotional states (complexity increases socio-cognitive inference), so it measures Perception/Understanding of Others (I1 and I2).
The pitch-controlled contrast still examines emotional prosody comprehension (removing pitch confound) and thus remains a social-related task that measures social processing (both I1 and I2).
Controlling for pitch during simple vs complex emotion contrasts does not introduce affiliation/attachment content; task does not measure attachment, so inclusion criteria are not met.
Even when controlling for acoustic pitch, the contrast tests reception of non-facial social communication (emotional prosody), meeting I1 and I2 for Social Communication.
This control contrast continues to target perception of others’ emotional states rather than self-related processes; Perception/Self criteria are not met.
By isolating socio-cognitive aspects of prosody (controlling pitch), the analysis still measures inference about others’ emotional states (Perception/Understanding of Others), so I1 and I2 apply.

The contrast is Social > Control (conjunction across older and younger adults) and therefore clearly measures social processing across stimuli (including affiliation and isolation images); meets I1.

This analysis is a general social > control conjunction and does not specifically target affiliation/attachment versus other social categories; it does not meet the requirement that the analysis measure affiliation/attachment specifically.

The task involves pleasantness judgments of social scenes (affiliation/isolation) rather than explicit communicative behaviors (e.g., affect/facial communication, gaze, production/reception of communication); it does not meet I1 for Social Communication.

Although the study discusses self-referencing in some contrasts, this specific Social > Control conjunction is a broad social contrast and not a contrast specifically measuring perception/understanding of the self.

The Social > Control contrast involves perception of social agents and likely engages processes involved in understanding others (the task presents social scenes and theory-of-mind regions are implicated in the study), meeting I1 for perception/understanding of others.
Affiliation vs Isolation is explicitly a social perception contrast assessing social processing of affiliative versus isolative scenes, meeting I1.
This contrast directly contrasts affiliation against isolation (Affiliation - Isolation), so it specifically measures affiliation/attachment processes as required by I1.
The contrast probes affiliative vs isolative scenes via pleasantness judgments rather than explicit communicative behavior or exchange; it does not meet the Social Communication inclusion criterion.

The study reports greater precuneus recruitment (a self-referencing region) for affiliation versus isolation in older adults, indicating this contrast taps self-referential processing and thus meets I1 for perception/understanding of self.

Affiliation vs Isolation involves interpreting others' social interactions and mental states (the study discusses ToM/understanding others), so this contrast meets I1 for perception/understanding of others.
Isolation vs Affiliation is a social perception contrast involving social stimuli and thus measures social processing (I1).

Although this contrast emphasizes isolation (Isolation - Affiliation), it directly compares affiliation and isolation conditions from the same task, so the analysis is on a task that measures affiliation/attachment and meets I1.

The contrast focuses on social scene perception (isolation vs affiliation) and pleasantness judgments rather than communicative signal reception/production; it does not meet the Social Communication inclusion criterion.

The study links Isolation - Affiliation (particularly in older adults) to temporal pole recruitment related to retrieval of personally relevant memories for ToM rather than explicit self-referencing; this contrast is not primarily measuring perception/understanding of the self.

Isolation vs Affiliation engages theory-of-mind related processing (temporal pole recruitment linked to understanding others' mental states), so this contrast meets I1 for perception/understanding of others.
This age-difference contrast (Younger - Older for Affiliation - Isolation) probes social perception differences and therefore measures social processing (I1).
The contrast is an age comparison on the Affiliation - Isolation contrast, so it directly addresses affiliation-related processing and meets I1.

The contrast examines age differences in responses to affiliative vs isolative scenes during pleasantness judgments rather than explicit communicative behaviors, so it does not meet the Social Communication inclusion criterion.

Because this is an age contrast on Affiliation - Isolation and the study reports self-referencing (precuneus) effects for affiliation-related processing, this analysis is appropriate for Perception/Understanding of Self (I1).

The contrast assesses age differences in processing scenes that require understanding others' interactions/mental states (Affiliation - Isolation), aligning with perception/understanding of others and meeting I1.
Older - Younger for Affiliation - Isolation is an age-difference contrast probing social perception and therefore counts as social processing (I1).
This contrast specifically examines affiliation versus isolation across age groups (Older - Younger on Affiliation - Isolation), so it directly measures affiliation/attachment processes (I1).

The analysis concerns affiliative vs isolative scene perception and pleasantness judgments rather than communicative exchange or facial/expressive communication, so it does not meet the Social Communication inclusion criterion.

The study reports that older adults show greater precuneus recruitment for Affiliation vs Isolation (Older > Younger), implicating self-referential processing; thus this contrast meets I1 for perception/understanding of self.

Age differences for affiliation-related processing can involve theory-of-mind and understanding of others; the analysis contrasts social scenes and therefore meets I1 for perception/understanding of others.
This conjunction (Affiliation & Isolation) comparing Younger - Older involves social perception across both social conditions and thus measures social processing (I1).

The conjunction includes the affiliation condition (as well as isolation); because the analysis examines affiliation-related responses (conjoined with isolation), it is part of the task that measures affiliation/attachment and meets I1.

The conjunction addresses general social scene processing across affiliation and isolation via pleasantness judgments rather than communicative behaviors, so it does not meet Social Communication inclusion criteria.

The conjunction across affiliation and isolation still taps processes including self-referencing reported in the study (precuneus); as an age-difference conjunction on social scenes it is appropriate to annotate for perception/self processes (I1).

Because the conjunction captures processing of scenes depicting others and interactions (both affiliation and isolation), it engages perception/understanding of others (theory-of-mind related processes) and meets I1.

Contrast 'Social > non-social' directly measures neural responses during social evaluation (impression formation) versus non-social processing. The task involved forming impressions of individuals, so this analysis probes social processing.
The task involves general impression formation and social evaluation, but does not target affiliation or attachment constructs (e.g., loved one vs stranger, cooperation).

The paradigm focuses on impression formation/mentalizing rather than communication (affect recognition, facial expression production/reception, gaze, etc.), so it does not meet Social Communication criteria.
Analyses concern evaluating others and socioemotional goals, not self-related judgments or self-knowledge, so Perception/Self criteria are not met.

Impression formation and mentalizing about others directly involve Perception and Understanding of Others (understanding others' traits, mental states). The contrast compares social evaluation to non-social, so it measures perception of others.

This contrast ('Non-social > social') emphasizes non-social processing more than social processing. Although derived from a social-task experiment, the contrast specifically indexes greater non-social activity, so it does not measure social processing per se.
The contrast does not measure affiliation or attachment-related constructs; task does not target those domains.
The contrast indexes non-social > social activation and the task is not focused on communication per se, so it does not meet Social Communication inclusion.
The contrast is not about self-related processing or judgments; it contrasts non-social with social conditions, so Perception/Self is not applicable.

This contrast highlights regions more active for non-social than social evaluations; it therefore does not index Perception/Understanding of Others in the positive direction required by the inclusion criteria.

This age-comparison contrast (Older > Younger for social > non-social) specifically tests age-related differences in neural recruitment during social evaluation, and thus directly measures social processing.

Although the contrast concerns social evaluation, it does not target affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation), so inclusion criteria for Affiliation/Attachment are not met.

The contrast reflects age differences in social evaluation/mentalizing rather than communication-specific processes (facial expression reception/production or gaze), so it does not meet Social Communication criteria.
This analysis examines age-related differences in processing others (social evaluation), not self-related judgments or self-knowledge, so Perception/Self inclusion is not met.

The contrast examines age-related increases in social>non-social activation, implicating regions involved in understanding others (e.g., temporal pole, mentalizing network). This aligns with Perception/Understanding of Others.

This contrast (Older > Younger for social-meaningful > social-irrelevant) probes how socioemotional goals modulate recruitment of social evaluation networks with age, directly measuring social processing.

Although 'interpersonally meaningful' stimuli may tap socioemotional relevance, the task does not explicitly measure affiliation or attachment constructs (no bonding or relationship-specific measures), so Affiliation/Attachment criteria are not met.

The contrast examines socioemotional modulation of impression formation/mentalizing rather than communication-specific behaviors (facial/expressive communication), so Social Communication inclusion is not met.
This analysis targets processing of others under different interpersonal relevance conditions and age groups, not self-evaluation or self-knowledge, so Perception/Self criteria are not met.

Comparing social-meaningful to social-irrelevant evaluations assesses how participants represent and reason about others' traits/mental states under differing interpersonal relevance, aligning with Perception and Understanding of Others.

Contrast measures simulated-other reward prediction errors during an 'Other' task—directly assesses social cognition and modeling of another's valuation (social processing).
Task involves simulating another's decisions and value learning, but not affiliation/attachment processes (no evidence of bonding, close relationships, cooperation/competition framing).
Analysis concerns internal valuation/prediction signals for another agent rather than communicative exchange (no measures of receptive or productive social communication).
Contrast indexes simulated-other signals (other-focused), not processes of self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge.
Measures representation and prediction of another's value (understanding others' states/valuations)—directly maps onto perception/understanding of others.
Contrast measures simulated-other action prediction errors during an 'Other' task—this directly assesses social learning about another's choices and is a social cognitive process.
No indication this task probes affiliation or attachment (no bonding/cooperation/competition manipulation described).
This is about action-prediction errors for another's choices rather than communicative signaling or reception/production of social cues.
The contrast targets simulated-other action-related signals, not processes of self-perception or self-knowledge.
Action prediction errors for a simulated other reflect reasoning about others' actions and behavioral variation—fits perception/understanding of others.
Reward probability during the 'Other' task indexes representations of another's expected outcomes—this is social processing related to modeling another's valuation.
No evidence the contrast targets affiliation/attachment constructs (no relationship/bonding manipulation).
Represents other's reward probability rather than communicative behavior or cue exchange.
Contrast concerns the simulated-other's expected rewards, not self-related perception or self-knowledge.
Encoding of another's reward probability reflects understanding/prediction of others' states and outcomes—fits perception/understanding of others.
This is from the Control task (likely self or nonsocial control) measuring reward prediction errors; not explicitly a social task or about others, so does not meet social processing criteria.
No indication the control contrast probes affiliation or attachment.
Control task RPE measures valuation signals for self/non-social outcomes rather than communicative processes.

Although this likely indexes self-related reward learning (control), it measures reinforcement learning signals (RPE) rather than explicit self-awareness, agency judgments, or self-knowledge; thus does not clearly meet perception/understanding of self criteria.
Control-task RPE pertains to non-social/self outcomes and does not measure perception/understanding of others.
Reward probability in the Control task appears non-social (control/self) and does not assess social processing about others.
No evidence this contrast probes affiliation/attachment constructs.
Control-task reward probability relates to non-social reward expectations rather than communication processes.
This contrast likely reflects expected value computations for the self/control condition but not explicit self-perception or self-knowledge as defined by the annotation criteria.
This is a control (non-social) reward probability measure and does not assess perception/understanding of others.

The study examines motivational responses to power-themed films rather than explicit social communication (reception/production) processes; the contrast does not target communication per se.
This analysis relates to individual differences in motive-linked neural responses to social stimuli, not explicit self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency judgments.
Although participants view social scenes, the analysis indexes their motivational disposition (power) rather than explicit assessment or reasoning about others' mental states or actions.
Participants viewed love (affiliation) movie clips and the analysis links affiliation motive to neural responses to these social stimuli, so it measures social processing.
The contrast examines affiliation motive responses while participants viewed love stories (affiliation-related stimuli), directly measuring affiliation/attachment-related processing.

The analysis focuses on affiliation motivation during love clips rather than explicit communicative processes (reception/production of social signals); the contrast does not specifically target social communication.

The analysis explicitly models multiple social features (faces, bodies, biological motion, goal-oriented actions, emotion, social interaction, pain, and speech) derived from naturalistic movie clips and uses them as predictors in the fMRI analysis. This directly measures broad social processing across many social domains.

The study does not target affiliation or attachment processes specifically (e.g., kinship, cooperation, loved one vs stranger). Although social interaction is rated, the task and contrasts do not specifically assess affiliation/attachment constructs.
The analysis includes features directly related to social communication such as faces and speech, and examines neural responses to these communication-related signals in naturalistic stimuli.

The task involves perception of external social signals from movie clips and does not involve judgments, monitoring, or representations of the participant’s own internal states or self-related processing.

The ratings and contrasts target perception of others’ features and actions (faces, bodies, biological motion, goal-oriented actions, social interaction), which directly map onto perception and understanding of others.

The analysis models non-social stimulus features and does not involve self-related judgments or monitoring.

The analysis is centered on non-social features and explicitly includes 'people not in social interaction' as a filler feature; it therefore does not index perception/understanding of others in social contexts.

Task involves empathic perspective taking rather than communicative exchanges or recognition/production of communicative signals.
Self > Other directly probes taking the first-person perspective and processes of self-related perception/awareness during empathy.

The task involved sensorimotor training pairing geometric shapes with hand actions and measuring fMRI adaptation to shapes and actions (mirror responses). This is a visuomotor learning / mirror-neuron study, not a social-related task targeting social cognition, affiliation, communication, or perception of social cues. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion for Social Processing (I1).

The experiment did not involve affiliation or attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, kinship, cooperation, loved-one vs stranger contrasts, or similar). The task paired shapes with actions and measured mirror-like responses, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion for Affiliation and Attachment (I1).

The study did not involve social communication tasks (no measures of facial or non-facial communicative reception/production, eye contact, affect recognition, or comparable contrasts). It focused on sensorimotor learning and action observation/execution, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion for Social Communication (I1).

The analyses measured adaptation between shape observation and action execution/observation, indexing mirror-type neuronal responses. There were no tasks requiring self-reflection, agency judgments, or self-knowledge assessments, so it does not meet inclusion criteria for Perception and Understanding of Self (I1).

The analyses include action observation conditions and adaptation from shapes to observation, indicating neuronal responses to observed actions. This maps onto the Action Perception subconstruct of Perception and Understanding of Others (perception of others' actions). Thus the analysis measures perception/understanding of others (action perception) and meets the inclusion criteria.

Session 2 replicated measures of sensorimotor learning and mirror-like responses to geometric shapes and actions; the task is visuomotor and not a social-processing task. It does not meet the Social Processing inclusion criterion (I1).

Session 2 did not involve affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding, kinship, cooperation or related contrasts). It focused on shape-action training and adaptation, so it does not meet the Affiliation and Attachment inclusion criterion (I1).

Session 2 did not test social communication (no facial/non-facial communicative reception or production measures). The task measured sensorimotor and action-observation adaptation, so it does not meet the Social Communication inclusion criterion (I1).

Session 2 did not include tasks assessing self-perception, agency judgments, or self-knowledge—only action execution/observation and shape observation—so it does not meet Perception and Understanding of Self inclusion criterion (I1).

Session 2 included observation conditions and adaptation from shapes to action observation, indicating responses to observed actions. This corresponds to the Action Perception subconstruct of Perception and Understanding of Others, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Contrast compares responses to partners who said Yes (match + unrequited) vs No (rejection + disinterest) in a romantic/ social decision context (speed-dating). This is a social task measuring processing of social feedback; meets I1 and I2 for social processing.

Task involves formation/assessment of romantic interest and social bonds (deciding whether to see partner again and receiving interest/rejection feedback). The contrast distinguishes positive (Yes) vs negative (No) social outcomes relevant to affiliation/attachment.
Receiving interest/rejection constitutes social communicative signals (exchange of social information). The contrast reflects processing of communicated social intent (interest vs rejection).

Participants' own decisions and expectations about interest tie to self-perception and self-relevant evaluations; contrasts likely engage self-related processing (e.g., RMPFC responses to prediction errors about personal desirability).
Processing partners' expressed interest or rejection requires perceiving and understanding others' mental states and intentions; pSTS and mentalizing regions implicated.
Reverse contrast of analysis_0 but still reflects social processing of interest vs rejection; meets I1 and I2.
Contrast differentiates negative (No) vs positive (Yes) social outcomes relevant to affiliation/attachment.
Also involves processing communicated social signals (rejection/disinterest vs interest).
Self-relevant processing engaged when participants process being rejected or accepted; RMPFC involvement in prediction errors about desirability supports inclusion.
Understanding others' responses (rejecting/disinterested) engages perception of others' mental states; pSTS/mentalizing implicated.
Match vs unrequited contrasts different social outcomes in romantic context, reflecting social processing of mutual vs unreciprocated interest; meets I1 and I2.
Match indicates mutual affiliation/attachment potential vs unrequited lacks mutual bond; directly relates to affiliation and attachment processes.
Mutual interest vs unrequited involves communicated social intent and signals; contrast measures processing of such communication.
Unrequited outcomes involve self-relevant evaluation; participants compare their desires to reality—engages self-perception mechanisms (RMPFC prediction errors noted in study).
Understanding whether the partner reciprocated involves modeling the other's preference and mental state—engages perception of others (pSTS, mentalizing).
Rejection vs disinterest contrasts social feedback differences in romantic setting; clearly social processing of negative outcomes and cues; meets I1 and I2.
Rejection vs disinterest pertains to failure of affiliation or bonding; both relate to attachment-relevant signals.
Rejection is an explicit communicative signal; contrast measures processing of that social communication versus lack of interest.
Experiencing rejection engages self-related affect and evaluation; study notes self-relevant prediction errors—fits self-perception.
Discerning rejection vs disinterest requires assessing other's intent and mental state; implicates perception of others (pSTS).

Mismatched (rejection + unrequited) vs matched (match + disinterest) contrasts combinations of social outcomes; assesses processing of social expectation violations and interpersonal signals—meets I1/I2.
Contrast pits outcomes that impede affiliation (mismatched) vs those facilitating it (matched); relevant to attachment dynamics.
Mismatches involve communicative signals that conflict with participants' expectations; this involves processing communicated social information.
Mismatches between expectation and partner response produce self-relevant prediction errors and evaluations (as described in study), engaging self-perception processes.
Determining mismatches requires reasoning about others' preferences and mental states—perception of others relevant.
Unsigned prediction errors from an RL model of personal desirability reflect learning about social feedback (interest/rejection) in a social task; thus measures social processing.
Prediction errors about personal desirability relate to forming/adjusting social bonds and affiliation expectations when receiving romantic interest or rejection.
Prediction errors are responses to communicated social signals (partner's interest/rejection) and so involve social communication processing.
Model relates to personal desirability predictions—self-relevant evaluations mediated by RMPFC; fits perception_self.
Prediction errors arise from discrepancies between one's expectation of others' interest and their actual responses, requiring representation of others' states—perception of others included.
Contrast of partners given a yes vs no is direct social evaluation of others' romantic interest; clearly social processing.
Comparing partners based on received yes vs no pertains to affiliation potential and bonding signals; relevant to attachment.
Partners' 'yes' vs 'no' are communicative acts; contrast measures processing of those social communications.
Processing whether partners were given yes or no is related to self-evaluation in the study (personal desirability) and engages self-related processing.
Distinguishing partners based on their decisions requires perceiving and understanding others' preferences—perception of others.
Reverse of analysis_6; still a social processing contrast of partners who said no vs yes; meets I1/I2.
No vs yes affects affiliation signals and bonding relevance; relevant to attachment processes.
No vs yes contrasts processing of social communicative signals (rejection/disinterest vs interest).

Evaluating partners who said no requires inferring their intentions and preferences—perception of others included.
