The 'Intention effect' examines neural responses of message communicators when encoding ideas that they may later spread, tapping broad social processing (mentalizing and valuation related to social influence). This is a social-related task and directly measures social processing (mentalizing systems), so it meets inclusion criteria.

The study focuses on message propagation and mentalizing/reward responses rather than measures of affiliation, attachment, or close-relationship bonding. No task contrasts or measures target affiliation/attachment specifically.

The task involves communicators encoding messages they will transmit to others and examines neural predictors of message spread — an exchange of socially relevant information, fitting social communication.

Although communicators provided subjective evaluations, the primary focus is on predicting message spread via mentalizing and reward systems rather than explicit self-reflection or self-knowledge tasks; no contrasts specifically probe self-perception or agency.

Results emphasize activity in the mentalizing system (understanding others' minds) predicting successful message propagation, which directly maps onto perception and understanding of others (mental state inference).

The 'Salesperson effect' examines how individuals differ in their ability to spread views and relates these differences to neural activity in social cognition systems; this is inherently social processing (mentalizing, valuation), satisfying the criteria.
The analysis concerns persuasive communication and influence effectiveness rather than measures of affiliation, attachment, or bonding; no affiliation-related task contrasts are reported.

This analysis addresses the production and effectiveness of communicated messages (how well communicators spread ideas), which is squarely within social communication (exchange of socially relevant information).

The focus is on how communicators influence others and corresponding mentalizing activity; it does not center on self-awareness, agency, or explicit self-knowledge judgments required for perception_self inclusion.

The Salesperson effect links greater ability to spread views with increased mentalizing-system activity, indicating processes of understanding others’ mental states — a direct match to perception_others.

The 'Buzz effect' identifies neural responses predictive of which ideas become successful (generate 'buzz') and implicates social-cognitive systems; this reflects social processing during message encoding and meets the inclusion criteria.
Although 'buzz' concerns spread of ideas, it does not target affiliation or attachment constructs (no measures of bonding or close relationships), so it does not meet affiliation criteria.
Predicting which messages will 'buzz' is directly about communicative success and information transmission; the task measures communicative processes and thus fits social_communication.
The Buzz effect centers on predicting message spread via mentalizing and reward responses rather than explicit self-perception or self-knowledge judgments; no contrasts probe self-related processing.

The analysis highlights mentalizing-system activity (understanding others) as predictive of successful message propagation, satisfying perception_others criteria focused on understanding others' mental states.

Contrast compares meaningful vs scrambled videos of dyadic interactions while participants rated naturalness — this is a social-related task and directly measures social processing of nonverbal social scenes.

Stimuli/manipulations concern movement fluency/meaningfulness, not measures of affiliation, attachment, bonding, cooperation, or relationship distinctions. Thus it does not measure affiliation/attachment.

The task involves perceiving nonverbal dyadic interactions (movement-based communication). This fits reception of non-facial social communication (reception of movement cues) and the contrast assesses social communicative content (meaningful vs scrambled).
Task involves perception of others' interactions and does not involve self-referential judgments, agency, or self-knowledge, so it does not measure perception/understanding of self.
Contrast examines perception and representation of other agents' actions and interaction meaning — fits action perception/understanding of others (animacy/action/intentionality).
Contingent > Mirrored contrast isolates processing of contingent social movement patterns in dyadic interactions, a social task measuring social processing of others' actions.
Contrast manipulates contingency of movement, not affiliation/attachment or relationship/bonding variables; does not measure affiliation/attachment.

Contingency between agents' movements reflects a form of nonverbal social communication (reception of non-facial cues); the contrast measures processing of communicative/interactive movement patterns.
Contrast concerns perception of others' contingent actions, not self-related processing or judgments of one's own states/agency.
Contrast focuses on action perception and understanding others' contingent actions — directly probes perception/understanding of others (action perception, intentionality).
Mirrored > Contingent contrast is a social task comparing types of dyadic movement and thus measures social processing of observed interactions.
This contrast manipulates movement contingency but does not assess affiliation, attachment, or bonding; therefore it does not meet affiliation/attachment criteria.
Differences between mirrored and contingent movement reflect different forms of nonverbal interaction; this contrast assesses reception of non-facial communicative motion cues.
The contrast contrasts types of observed movements between agents and does not involve self-referential processing or judgments about one's own states.
Contrast examines perception of others' movement patterns (action perception), relevant to understanding others' actions and intentions.

Rigid > Smooth contrast manipulates kinematic fluency of dyadic movements while participants judged naturalness — a social task assessing processing of nonverbal social behavior and thus social processing.
Manipulation of movement fluency (rigid vs smooth) targets kinematic properties and does not measure affiliation, attachment, or social bonds.
Kinematic properties of movement convey nonverbal communicative information; the contrast probes reception of non-facial social communication (movement cues) relevant to understanding interactions.
Contrast focuses on perceiving others' movement fluency and not on self-related judgments or agency, so it does not measure perception of self.
Contrast examines perception of others' atypical vs typical kinematics (action perception and inference about intentions), fitting perception/understanding of others.
Interaction contrast tests how contingency effects differ by movement fluency in dyadic social scenes — clearly a social task measuring processing of others' interactions and inferred intentions.
Interaction concerns contingency and fluency manipulations rather than affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of bonding or relationship), so does not meet affiliation/attachment criteria.

The interaction contrast concerns how communicative contingency and kinematic fluency jointly affect perception of dyadic interaction — relevant to nonverbal social communication (reception of movement cues and inferred communicative intent).
Contrast examines observers' perception of others' movements and interactions, not self-related processing or agency judgments, so it does not measure perception of self.

Interaction probes how movement properties influence perception and inference about others' intentions and actions, directly mapping onto perception/understanding of others (action perception and mental state inference).

The contrast 'Form impression > remember order' is a functional localizer identifying regions involved in impression formation (explicit social processing). This directly measures social processing of others' traits/behavior.

The localizer contrasts impression formation versus remembering order; it targets general social impression processes rather than affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, close relationships, cooperation, or attachment were described).

The task indexes impression formation rather than communicative reception or production (facial/affective communication or explicit communicative exchanges are not the primary focus of this contrast).
The contrast concerns forming impressions of others, not self-referential processing or judgments about one's own traits/states.
Impression formation is a prototypical measure of perceiving and understanding others (representations of others' traits/behaviors), so this contrast measures perception/understanding of others.

The 'Remember order > form impression' contrast still arises from the same social task set and captures social-task-related processing (even if it emphasizes a non-impression condition), so it is part of the social processing localizer context.
This contrast emphasizes non-impression memory aspects (remembering order) and does not target affiliation/attachment constructs or bonding/cooperation measures.
The contrast is not designed to probe communicative reception or production; it contrasts memory-related processing with impression formation rather than communication per se.
The contrast does not index self-referential judgments or self-perception processes; it contrasts task demands within a social localizer.

Although this contrast emphasizes the remembering-order condition, it is derived from a task probing impression formation of others and thus is relevant to perception/understanding of others within the study context.
The main-task contrast 'Dependent > independent' directly manipulates outcome dependency during impression formation, altering social-cognitive neural dynamics; this is core social processing.

While 'dependence' involves relying on another for an outcome, the study operationalizes outcome dependency in impression formation rather than measuring attachment, bonding, or affiliation per se (no measures of affiliation/attachment were reported).
The contrast manipulates dependency in impression formation, not communicative exchange or reception/production of social signals; it does not target social communication constructs explicitly.
This contrast concerns processing of others under different dependency states, not self-reflection or self-judgments.

The manipulation affects how participants form impressions and weigh information about others (confirming vs violating information), which directly measures perception and understanding of others' traits and behavior.

The 'Independent > dependent' contrast is the complementary main-task social contrast, indexing social impression processes when participants are outcome-independent; it is central to social processing evaluation.
This contrast focuses on dependency state during impression formation but does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs such as bonding or relationship quality.
The contrast addresses impression formation differences by dependency, not communicative behaviors or recognition/production of social signals.
The contrast does not probe self-related cognitive or affective states; it compares how others are processed under outcome-independence.
This contrast measures how participants perceive and update impressions of others when not dependent on them, directly indexing perception/understanding of others.
The 'Consistent > inconsistent' contrast contrasts expectancy-confirming vs violating social information during impression formation; this is a direct measure of social processing dynamics.
This contrast targets processing of expectancy-consistent vs inconsistent information about others, not measures of attachment, bonding, or affiliation specifically.
The contrast examines expectation confirmation in impression formation rather than communicative signal reception/production.
This contrast investigates how information about others is processed (consistent vs inconsistent), not self-perception or self-related judgments.
Comparing consistent vs inconsistent information during impression formation pertains to updating and understanding others' traits/behavior, fitting perception/understanding of others.
The 'Inconsistent > consistent' contrast probes social-cognitive processing focused on expectancy violations during impression formation, clearly within social processing domain.

Although outcome dependency and expectancy violations may affect interpersonal evaluations, this contrast does not operationalize affiliation/attachment measures (no bonding or relationship quality measures).
The focus is on processing of expectancy-violating information about others in impression formation rather than communication-specific behaviors or signal processing.
This contrast addresses perception of others' information (violations) rather than self-related cognition or self-awareness.
Expectancy-violating information and how it is processed is directly relevant to understanding others' traits and updating impressions—fits perception/understanding of others.
The Dependence × consistency interaction probes how outcome dependency modulates social impression processes (interaction of two social factors), so it is central social processing.
The interaction examines cognitive mechanisms of impression updating under dependency, not explicit measures of affiliation or attachment (no bonding/relationship scale comparisons).
This interaction addresses how dependency and consistency affect impression formation rather than communication processes or signal exchange.
The interaction concerns processing of information about others under different dependency/consistency conditions, not self-referential processing.

The interaction shows how dependency alters processing of consistent vs inconsistent information about others—this directly assesses perception and understanding of others' traits/diagnostic information.

The analysis examines face-preferring responses (faces vs objects) in the right hemisphere FFA across children, which is a social-related task measuring face processing. This meets both I1 (social-related task) and I2 (contrast measures social processing: faces>objects).

The task is passive viewing of faces versus objects and does not assess affiliation, attachment, or bonding (does not measure relationships, kinship, or loved-one vs stranger contrasts). Inclusion criterion I1 for affiliation/attachment is not met.

Viewing faces engages reception of facial communication and facial recognition processes. The faces>objects contrast indexes social-communication relevant reception of facial signals, satisfying I1 and I2.
The analysis contrasts faces and objects and does not involve self-related judgments, agency, or self-knowledge. Inclusion criterion I1 for perception/self is not met.
Face perception reflects perception and understanding of others (animacy/action/emotional states). The faces>objects contrast measures perception of others and meets I1 and I2 for this construct.
Faces versus objects in the right FFA for teens is a social-related face-processing task and the contrast measures social processing (faces>objects), meeting I1 and I2.
The paradigm is simple face vs object viewing and does not probe affiliation or attachment constructs (no relationship or bonding measures). I1 not met.
Face viewing taps reception of facial communication/recognition; faces>objects indexes social-communication relevant processes, meeting I1 and I2.
No self-referential processing, judgments about self, or agency are involved in this contrast. I1 not met for self-perception.
Faces>objects measures perception of others (face recognition/animacy/emotional cues), satisfying I1 and I2 for perception_of_others.
Adults’ right FFA faces>objects analysis indexes social face processing; task is social and contrast measures social processing (I1 and I2 satisfied).
The adult FFA ROI analysis does not assess affiliation/attachment or relationship-related constructs; I1 not met.
Face perception in the FFA relates to reception of facial communication/facial recognition; faces>objects meets I1 and I2 for social communication.
No self-related task or self-judgment contrasts are present in this analysis, so I1 for self-perception is not met.
Face-preferring activation reflects perception/understanding of others (faces convey others’ states/traits); faces>objects meets I1 and I2 for this construct.
Left-hemisphere FFA ROI analysis with faces>objects involves social face processing; the contrast measures social processing (I1 and I2 satisfied).
The left FFA ROI faces>objects analysis does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding or relationship contrasts). I1 not met.
Face viewing engages reception of facial communication and recognition; faces>objects indexes social-communication-relevant processes, meeting I1 and I2.
This analysis does not involve self-related cognition or judgments; inclusion criterion I1 for perception_self is not met.
Faces>objects reflects perception of others (face recognition/animacy/emotion cues); meets I1 and I2 for perception of others.
Teens left-hemisphere FFA faces>objects analysis measures social face processing; contrast meets I1 and I2 for social processing.
No measures of affiliation/attachment or relationship-specific contrasts are present; I1 not met for affiliation/attachment.
Faces>objects taps reception of facial communication/recognition relevant to social communication; I1 and I2 satisfied.
The analysis is not self-referential and does not assess self-knowledge or agency; I1 not met for perception_self.
Face-preferential responses index perception of others (faces as social agents); faces>objects meets I1 and I2 for this construct.
Adults’ left FFA faces>objects ROI analysis indexes social face processing; it is a social-related contrast measuring faces>objects, satisfying I1 and I2.
The paradigm does not assess affiliation or attachment constructs (no relationship-based contrasts), so I1 is not met for affiliation/attachment.
Left FFA face-preferring activation relates to reception of facial communication/recognition; faces>objects meets I1 and I2 for social communication.
No self-related judgments or introspective tasks are part of this analysis; I1 for perception_self is not met.
Faces>objects reflects perception/understanding of others (faces convey information about others), meeting I1 and I2 for perception_others.
Whole-brain faces>objects analyses showing positive relationship with age index social face processing across development; the contrast is social and measures social processing (I1 and I2 met).
These whole-brain age-related face-preference analyses do not probe affiliation/attachment constructs or relationship-specific contrasts; I1 not met for affiliation/attachment.
Faces>objects and its developmental modulation concern reception of facial communication/face recognition across age; this meets I1 and I2 for social communication.
Analyses examine face-preferring responses across age, not self-referential cognition or judgments; I1 for perception_self is not met.
Faces>objects contrasts and their relationship with age index perception and understanding of others’ faces and social signals; I1 and I2 satisfied for perception_others.
Whole-brain faces>objects analyses showing negative relationship with age concern social face processing across development; the contrast is social and measures social processing (I1 and I2 met).
Negative age-related face-preference effects do not reflect affiliation/attachment measures or relationship contrasts; I1 not met for affiliation/attachment.
Faces>objects and its developmental decrease/increase relate to reception of facial communication/recognition; this meets I1 and I2 for social communication.
These analyses do not probe self-related cognition, agency, or self-knowledge; I1 for perception_self is not met.
Faces>objects contrasts and their negative relationship with age reflect perception of others (faces, emotions, animacy) across development; I1 and I2 satisfied for perception_others.

This analysis isolates social trait judgments (trustworthiness, attractiveness) relative to emotional and cognitive judgments on voices — an explicit social-evaluation task. It therefore measures Social Processing (broadly perceiving and interpreting social cues).

The task assesses trait judgments of voices (trustworthiness, attractiveness) rather than affiliation/attachment constructs (e.g., bonding, love, cooperation). It does not meet the affiliation/attachment task criteria.

Judging social traits from voices involves reception of non-facial social communication (auditory social cues). The contrasts target socially relevant information communicated via voice, meeting Social Communication criteria.
Analyses concern judgments about others' voices (traits/emotions/age), not self-related perception or self-evaluation, so Perception/Self criteria are not met.
The contrasts probe perception and understanding of others (their trustworthiness, attractiveness, emotional state, age) based on vocal cues, directly mapping onto Perception/Understanding of Others.
This conjunction examines overlap of social (TR, AT) and emotional (HA) judgments on voices — an explicit social-evaluation context, reflecting Social Processing.
The contrasts compare trait and emotional judgments of voices and do not assess affiliation/attachment (bonding, relationship processes). Thus affiliation criteria are not met.
Overlap of social and emotional vocal judgments involves reception of non-facial social communication (voice-based affective/social cues), satisfying Social Communication criteria.
The analysis pertains to judgments about others' vocal properties, not self-related processes, so Perception/Self is not applicable.
This conjunction targets how listeners perceive others’ social and emotional traits from voices, directly addressing Perception/Understanding of Others.
This conjunction examines overlap of social (TR, AT) and cognitive (AG) judgments on voices — it probes explicit social evaluation processes and thus meets Social Processing criteria.
The contrasts compare social trait and age judgments of voices and do not measure affiliation/attachment constructs like bonding or relationship behavior, so criteria are not met.
Judging social traits and age from voices is reception of non-facial social communication (auditory cues about others), so it fits the Social Communication construct.
The analysis focuses on judgments about others’ voices (traits/age), not on self-perception, therefore Perception/Self is not applicable.
Contrasts probe perception and reasoning about others’ traits (trustworthiness, attractiveness, age) from vocal cues, matching Perception/Understanding of Others.

This analysis is the main effect of emotional context across all three social conditions (Empathy, ToM, Self-reference). It therefore involves social-related tasks and measures social processing across conditions.
The study manipulates empathy, ToM, and self-reference; it does not assess affiliation or attachment processes (no measures of bonding, loved one vs stranger, cooperation, etc.).
The tasks probe internal state inference (empathy, ToM, self-reference) rather than exchange of social signals, facial/gaze communication, or communicative production/reception.
The contrast aggregates Self-reference (SRS, SRN) with empathy and ToM; because Self-reference is included, this analysis measures perception/understanding of self as part of the effect.

The contrast also includes Empathy and ToM conditions (ES, TS), which directly measure perception and understanding of others' emotional and mental states, so the analysis measures perception of others.
Empathy condition (ES-EN) is a social task probing understanding others' emotions and thus measures social processing.
The empathy contrast targets understanding others' feelings, not affiliation/attachment or bonding processes.
Empathy here involves imagining others' feelings rather than communicating or processing facial/gaze cues; it does not assess social communication per the taxonomy.
The empathy contrast focuses on others' emotional states (imagining what another person is feeling), not on self-related perception or self-knowledge.
Empathy directly measures perception and understanding of others' emotional states (other-focused inference), satisfying the criterion for perception of others.
ToM condition (TS-TN) is a classic social cognition task involving inference about others' mental states and thus measures social processing.
The ToM contrast assesses understanding what would make another person feel better, not affiliation/attachment or bonding.
This ToM manipulation concerns mental state inference rather than communicative signal processing or production, so it does not meet the social communication criteria.
ToM here is other-focused (inferring what would make another person feel better), not self-reflection or self-knowledge.
ToM explicitly involves reasoning about others' mental states, matching inclusion criteria for perception and understanding of others.
Self-reference (SRS-SRN) is a social-related task in this study (imagining how one would feel in another's situation) and is part of the social cognition battery, so it counts as social processing.
Self-reference manipulation probes self-related perspective-taking rather than attachment or affiliation processes.
The self-reference condition involves internal self-simulation rather than communicative exchange or reception/production of social signals.
Self-reference explicitly requires participants to imagine how they would feel in someone else's situation, directly assessing self-related perception and self-knowledge.

Although the scenario involves another person's situation, the task directs participants to report on their own imagined feelings rather than representing others' mental states, so it does not primarily measure perception of others.
The contrast Empathy > ToM directly compares two social-cognitive conditions and therefore indexes social processing differences between tasks.
The contrast distinguishes empathy from ToM and does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs.
This condition-level contrast contrasts modes of inferring internal states rather than communication/perceptual exchange; it does not map onto social communication subconstructs.
Both empathy and ToM are other-focused processes; this contrast does not involve the self-reference condition and therefore does not measure self-perception.
Empathy and ToM both involve understanding others' emotional/mental states; the contrast assesses differences in perception/understanding of others between these processes.
ToM > Empathy contrasts two social cognitive conditions (ToM vs Empathy), so it measures social processing differences.
This contrast concerns mode of mental-state inference rather than affiliation/attachment processes.
The contrast reflects inferential social cognition rather than communicative signal processing or production, so it does not meet social communication criteria.
ToM and Empathy are both other-focused; this contrast does not include the self-reference condition and thus does not primarily measure self-perception.
Because ToM involves reasoning about others' mental states, this contrast assesses perception and understanding of others.
Empathy > Self-reference contrasts two social conditions (other-focused empathy vs self-focused reference) and thus indexes social processing differences.
The contrast pits empathy against self-reference and does not measure affiliation/attachment.
This contrast reflects internal-state inference (other vs self) rather than communicative exchange, so it does not map onto social communication constructs.
The contrast includes the Self-reference condition (SRS, SRN), so it pertains to perception and understanding of one's own feelings; thus it measures self-related perception.
The Empathy condition is other-focused (imagining another's feelings); contrasting it with Self-reference means the analysis engages perception of others as well.
Self-reference > Empathy compares self-focused vs other-focused social conditions and thus indexes social processing differences across these tasks.
This contrast examines self vs other internal-state inference, not affiliation or attachment.
The contrast concerns internal-state inference and self/other perspective-taking rather than communicative signal reception/production, so it does not meet social communication criteria.
This contrast includes Self-reference (SRS, SRN) and therefore measures perception/understanding of self-related states.
Because the contrast pits Self-reference against Empathy, it necessarily involves representation of others' states (Empathy), so it also measures perception of others.

The task is an one-shot, anonymous prisoner's dilemma (a social decision-making task). The contrast examines neural correlates of cooperative vs defect decisions and differences between prosocials and proselfs, directly measuring social processing.

Prisoner’s dilemma cooperation/defection contrasts measure affiliation-related behavior (cooperation and competition) and formation/maintenance of social bonds; the analysis examines social value orientation in cooperative decisions, matching affiliation/attachment criteria.

Cooperation/competition tasks are listed as example tasks for Social Communication. Although interactions were anonymous and one-shot, the analysis probes exchange-related social behavior (cooperation decisions) and associated social-cognitive neural activity.

The contrast compares prosocials vs proselfs (individual differences in social value orientation) and examines internal dispositions and decision strategies, implicating self-related processes (self-related preferences/traits) during decision-making.

The abstract highlights inferring intentions of others and activation in theory-of-mind regions (TPJ, precuneus) during cooperative decisions — directly reflecting perception and understanding of others’ mental states.

This analysis examines the interaction between dispositional trust and social value orientation on neural responses during cooperative decisions in the prisoner’s dilemma — a social task measuring social processing.

Dispositional trust modulates cooperation-related brain activity; cooperation is an affiliation/attachment-related behavior (cooperation/competition), so the analysis measures affiliation/attachment constructs.
The interaction probes neural correlates underlying cooperative exchanges and trust-related modulation — fitting within Social Communication (cooperation tasks are an example).

Dispositional trust and social value orientation reflect individual differences and self-related dispositions influencing decisions; the analysis examines how these self-related traits modulate brain responses during decision-making.

The reported effects involve social-cognition regions associated with inferring others’ intentions; dispositional trust influences processing of others’ behavior in cooperative contexts, meeting perception/understanding of others criteria.

The contrast (Partner > Unfamiliar) compares neural responses to a loved one versus a stranger, which is a social-related task assessing processing of socially meaningful faces; it therefore measures broad social processing.
This contrast directly contrasts a close affiliative figure (partner) with an unfamiliar person (loved one vs stranger), matching typical measures of affiliation/attachment.
The task involves perception of faces and recognition of a partner’s face (receptive facial communication), which falls under social communication (reception of facial cues).

The contrast examines perception of another person (partner) relative to an unfamiliar face, not self-related processing or self-awareness, so it does not measure perception/understanding of the self.

Comparing partner versus unfamiliar faces assesses representations about another person’s identity/emotional/mental-state-related processing (perception and understanding of others), satisfying this construct.
The contrast (Child > Unfamiliar) contrasts a close kin/loved one (child) with a stranger, a social task probing social processing of familiar faces.
This contrast pits a primary attachment figure (child) against an unfamiliar person (loved one vs stranger), directly indexing affiliation/attachment.
Recognition of a child’s face versus an unfamiliar face involves reception of facial communication and social information, meeting social communication criteria.
The contrast concerns perception of another person (the child) rather than self-related processes, so it does not meet perception-self criteria.
Comparing child versus unfamiliar faces probes representations and inference about another person (identity/emotional significance), consistent with perception and understanding of others.
The contrast (Friend > Unfamiliar) compares a familiar social contact (friend) with a stranger, a social task measuring social processing of familiar individuals.
Contrasting a friend with an unfamiliar person captures affiliation/attachment-related processing (loved/close other vs stranger), so it fits this construct.
Differentiating a friend’s face from an unfamiliar face involves receptive facial communication and social recognition, meeting social communication inclusion.
The contrast pertains to perception of another individual (friend) rather than self-related cognition, so it does not meet perception-self criteria.
The friend versus unfamiliar contrast assesses representations and inferences about another person (identity/emotional salience), consistent with perception and understanding of others.

The study uses the ultimatum game to probe social decision-making and cooperation; contrasts comparing adults vs children directly measure social processing networks involved in interaction and cooperation.
The ultimatum game is a cooperation/competition paradigm assessing affiliation-related decisions; contrasts (Adults>Children) measure affiliation/attachment-related processing across development.

Cooperation and decision-making in the ultimatum game involve exchange of socially relevant information and responses between players, fitting Social Communication criteria; the contrast targets these processes.
The ultimatum game requires self-referential decision-making and monitoring of one’s own strategic choices (agency/self-evaluation), so contrasts compare self-related processing across groups.
Players infer others’ intentions and fairness considerations in the ultimatum game (understanding others’ mental states), so contrasts measure perception/understanding of others across development.
The ultimatum game is a social task probing cooperative/competitive decisions; the children>adults contrast measures social processing differences between age groups.
Children’s responses in the cooperation/competition paradigm reflect affiliation/attachment-related processing; the contrast isolates these developmental differences.
Decision-making in the ultimatum game requires processing and responding to socially communicated offers and intentions, so the contrast pertains to social communication.
Children’s strategic decisions involve self-monitoring and agency; this contrast examines developmental differences in self-related decision processes.
The task requires inferring others’ fairness and intentions; children>adults contrast captures developmental changes in understanding others.
Adolescents>children contrast in an ultimatum game context probes developmental change in social decision-making networks, thus measuring social processing broadly.
The cooperation/competition paradigm taps affiliation/attachment processes; adolescence vs childhood comparisons target developmental shifts in these processes.
Adolescents’ strategic responses involve interpreting and reacting to social offers—core social communication processes—so the contrast applies.
Adolescents’ decision-making likely involves self-related evaluation and agency; the contrast examines developmental changes in self-perception during social decisions.
Understanding and predicting partners’ fairness and intent is central to the task; the adolescents>children contrast measures perception/understanding of others.

The analysis examines brain activity during live reciprocal imitation (imitating condition), a clear social task probing social processing; contrasts measure social processing (activation during imitating vs observation).

The task (reciprocal imitation of hand gestures) probes action understanding and interaction dynamics but does not explicitly measure affiliation or attachment (no bonding, loved-one/stranger, cooperation metrics).
Reciprocal imitation of hand gestures is a form of non-facial social communication (production and reception of gestures), so the analysis measures social communication.

The analysis focuses on action imitation and social interaction rather than explicit self-perception, agency judgments, or self-knowledge measures; no contrasts targeting self-related processing are reported.

Imitating and being imitated require perceiving and understanding others’ actions and intentions; the involvement of the Mentalizing System and PPI connectivity analyses specifically address perception/understanding of others.
The 'being imitated' condition is a live social interaction probing social processing; contrasts measure social processing (being imitated vs observation).
Although socially relevant, the 'being imitated' condition does not explicitly measure affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding or relationship measures).
Being imitated involves reception of non-facial communicative gestures and social reciprocity, fitting social communication constructs.
The focus is on interpersonal action and response to others rather than explicit self-evaluation or agency judgments; no self-perception contrasts are reported.
Being imitated engages representations of others’ actions/intentions and recruits mentalizing processes, so it measures perception and understanding of others.
The observation condition involves perceiving social gestures and is part of the social task contrasts; it measures social processing (observation vs imitation).
Passive observation of hand gestures does not target affiliation or attachment constructs (no measures of bonding or relationship).
Observation of gestures involves reception of non-facial social communication and is relevant to the social communication construct.
Observation is focused on perceiving others’ actions rather than explicit self-related processing or agency judgments.
Observation of someone else’s gestures directly engages perception and understanding of others’ actions (action perception), aligning with this annotation.
This PPI analysis (Imitating–IFG) examines functional coupling of mirror system regions during a social imitation task, directly measuring social processing.
The connectivity analysis focuses on neural coupling during imitation, not on measures of affiliation/attachment or bonding.
IFG seed PPI during imitation assesses neural substrates of producing/understanding communicative gestures (mirror-system-mediated communication), fitting social communication.
Although IFG relates to action production, the analysis targets social coupling rather than explicit self-perception or agency assessments.
The PPI shows increased coupling between Mirror and Mentalizing systems during imitation, indicating processes related to perceiving and representing others’ actions and intentions.
This PPI analysis (Being imitated–IFG) probes neural coupling during a social condition (being imitated), directly assessing social processing.
The analysis examines connectivity during being imitated but does not explicitly measure affiliation/attachment constructs or bonding metrics.
Connectivity of IFG during being imitated relates to reception of communicative gestures and social reciprocity, aligning with social communication.
The focus is on interpersonal coupling and perception of others’ actions, not explicit self-related judgments or agency measures.
Increased IFG coupling with mentalizing regions during being imitated indicates engagement with representations of others’ intentions and actions (perception of others).
The PPI analysis (Imitating–IPL) examines IPL connectivity in an imitation social task, thus assessing social processing.
This connectivity analysis targets action-related coupling during imitation rather than affiliation/attachment measures.
IPL is part of the mirror/action perception network; its coupling during imitation relates to production/reception of non-facial communicative gestures (social communication).
While IPL contributes to action representation, the analysis does not target explicit self-perception or agency judgments.
IPL coupling with mentalizing regions during imitation reflects action perception and understanding of others’ intentions, fitting perception_others.
The PPI analysis (Being imitated–IPL) probes IPL connectivity during a social condition (being imitated), directly measuring social processing.
The analysis examines neural coupling during being imitated but does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs explicitly.
IPL connectivity during being imitated concerns perception and representation of communicative gestures (non-facial), consistent with social communication.
The analysis targets interpersonal action perception and coupling rather than explicit measures of self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge.
Being imitated engages representations of others’ actions and intentions; IPL–mentalizing coupling supports perception and understanding of others.

The analysis is from a faces vs houses fMRI task examining face processing within a study of social cognition. Face perception is a core social-related task and measures social processing (recognizing social cues in faces), so it meets the Social Processing annotation.

The faces vs houses task contrasts perceptual categories (faces vs houses) and does not assess affiliation or attachment constructs (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation). It therefore does not meet criteria for Affiliation and Attachment.

Face perception tasks index reception of facial communication (e.g., identity, affect recognition). The faces vs houses contrast therefore measures Social Communication (reception of facial communication).

The task contrasts faces and houses and does not involve judgments or processing about the self (no self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge measures). It does not meet Perception and Understanding of Self criteria.
Face perception reflects perception and understanding of others (recognizing others' faces, emotions, traits), so the faces vs houses contrast maps onto Perception and Understanding of Others.

The ANOVA examines age effects across tasks that are all social in nature (direct self, direct other, reflected self evaluations vs control), so it measures social processing broadly.

The tasks include evaluations of a close peer (best friend) and social trait domains, which tap aspects of affiliation/attachment and peer-related bonding; the age-group effect is computed across these affiliation-relevant conditions.

The task involves self- and other-evaluative judgments rather than explicit reception or production of communicative signals (faces, gaze, expressive behavior), so it does not target social communication constructs.
The study includes direct and reflected self-evaluations (self-knowledge, self-referential processing); the main effect of age group assesses differences in these self-related processes.
The design includes direct other-evaluations of a best friend and reflected self-evaluations from the friend's perspective, so the analysis probes representation/understanding of others.
This is the main effect of evaluative perspective (direct self, direct other, reflected self, control), which directly engages social processing of self and others.
Evaluative perspective includes judgments about a best friend and reflected perspectives from a close peer, tapping affiliation/attachment processes related to peer relationships.
The contrast manipulates perspective taking and self/other evaluation rather than communicative signal processing or production, so it does not meet social communication criteria.
Evaluative perspective contrasts include direct and reflected self-evaluations, which measure self-perception and self-knowledge processes.
The evaluative perspective factor includes direct other-evaluations and reflected perspectives (inferring another's view), indexing perception and representation of others.
The Age group × evaluative perspective interaction examines developmental differences in social evaluative processing, a core social processing question.

Because the interaction tests age differences in responding to perspectives including a close peer (best friend) and reflected social evaluations, it implicates affiliation/attachment-relevant processes.
This interaction concerns developmental modulation of evaluative perspective rather than communication per se, so it does not meet social communication inclusion.
The interaction specifically addresses how self-related processing (direct vs reflected self-evaluations) differs by age, meeting self-perception criteria.
The evaluative perspective factor includes direct other and reflected perspectives; the interaction with age probes representation of others and inferred perspectives across development.
The main effect of domain (academic, physical, social) concerns different social and non-social content but includes social trait domains, so it contributes to social processing assessment.
One domain is social traits (peer-related), which taps affiliation/attachment-relevant content (peer evaluation/social standing), so domain effects relate to affiliation processes.
Domain manipulations separate trait types (academic/physical/social) rather than communication signal reception/production; thus social communication is not directly measured.
Domains index different types of self-relevant trait judgments (self-knowledge across academic, physical, social traits), so the analysis measures self-perception processes.
Domain includes judgments about others (direct other-evaluations) and inferred others' perspectives, so it informs perception/understanding of others' traits.
The Age group × domain interaction examines developmental differences in processing different trait domains (including social traits), which is part of social processing.
Because one domain specifically probes social traits relevant to peer relationships, age-by-domain effects implicate affiliation/attachment-related processing across development.
This interaction compares trait domains rather than communicative behavior or signal processing, so it does not meet social communication criteria.
Age-by-domain examines how self-evaluation in different trait domains changes with age, thus indexing self-perception processes across domains.
Because domain includes social traits and direct other judgments, the interaction assesses how understanding of others' traits varies with age and domain.
Evaluative perspective × domain interaction directly tests how perspective (self/other/reflected) interacts with content domain (social/physical/academic), central to social processing.
This interaction highlights that reflected social self-evaluations (from a close peer) are especially salient in adolescence; that pattern directly implicates affiliation/attachment.
Although perspective-taking is involved, the interaction concerns evaluative content across domains rather than communicative signal processing or production, so social communication is not met.
The interaction involves self-evaluations (direct and reflected) across domains, directly assessing self-knowledge and self-perception processes.
Because the interaction includes direct other-evaluations and reflected perspectives, it measures perception and representation of others' views and traits.

The three-way Age group × evaluative perspective × domain interaction addresses developmental modulation of social evaluative processes (including reflected social self-evaluations), directly within social processing.

The study reports adolescents show greatest ventral striatum response during reflected social self-evaluations from a close peer—this three-way effect implicates affiliation/attachment and peer-related salience.

Despite perspective-taking, the three-way interaction concerns evaluative and domain differences rather than communicative signal reception/production, so it does not meet social communication criteria.
The reported three-way interaction centers on reflected social self-evaluations and self-relevant processing across domains and age, directly meeting self-perception criteria.

Because the three-way interaction involves reflected perspectives (inferring a friend's view) and direct other-evaluations across domains and ages, it measures perception/understanding of others and inferred mental states.

Task manipulates bystander group size while participants witness an emergency; this is a social influence task measuring social processing (effects on action preparation).
The contrast parametrically varies number of bystanders but does not target affiliation/attachment processes (no measures of bonding, kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation/attachment).
The analysis does not probe exchange of social information or communicative behaviors (no facial/expressive communication or communicative contrasts).
Contrast addresses perception of others and social influence on action preparation rather than self-related processing or self-awareness judgments.

Participants witness another in need and the analysis assesses effects of bystander number on neural responses—this involves perception/understanding of others (action perception/mental state inference).
Parametric increase in group size is a social manipulation assessing social influences on neural activity when witnessing an emergency; measures social processing.
The contrast examines group-size effects, not affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding or relationship-related measures).
No evidence the contrast measures communicative exchange or reception/production of facial/non-facial communication.
This contrast probes responses to others and social context, not self-related cognition or agency judgments.
Increasing bystander number modulates responses to others in an emergency context, implicating perception/understanding of others (action/mental-state perception).
Control vs bystander contrasts directly manipulate social context (presence/absence of bystanders) and assess social influence on neural activity, meeting social processing criteria.
Contrast compares control and bystander conditions but does not target affiliation/attachment (no measures of bonding or relationship-based comparisons).
The contrast is not designed to probe communicative behaviors or processing (no indication of communicative cues or exchanges).
The focus is on effects of others' presence, not on self-related judgments, agency, or self-knowledge.
Presence vs absence of bystanders alters perception of others in an emergency context and likely engages action perception/understanding of others.
Falling vs standing contrasts present actions of others in an emergency context; this is a social task involving perception of others and social influence, so it qualifies as social processing.
The contrast differentiates observed actions (falling vs standing) but does not assess affiliation or attachment processes.
This contrast examines action perception rather than communicative signals or exchanges, so it does not meet social communication criteria.
Contrast focuses on perception of others' actions, not self-related cognition, agency, or self-knowledge.
Comparing falling to standing is an action-perception contrast (animacy/action perception and likely inference about others' state), fitting perception/understanding of others.
Standing vs falling contrasts involve observing others' behavior in a social/emergency context; this is within the domain of social processing.
This contrast contrasts observed actions and does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs.
No evidence this contrast targets communicative reception or production; it's an action/perception contrast.
The contrast addresses perception of others' states/actions rather than self-related processing.
Standing > falling involves perceiving others' actions/states (action perception/understanding others), so it meets perception_others criteria.

Localizer contrast (Self > Other) uses social task contrasting self versus other moral descriptions; this measures social processing (self-reference vs other), so both I1 and I2 are met.

Localizer Self>Other is a self-referential/localizer contrast of moral descriptions, not a task measuring affiliation/attachment (no cooperation/competition or bonding manipulation), so I1 is not met.
The localizer contrasts self versus other on moral descriptions and is not a communication task (receptive/expressive communication), so it does not meet I1 for social communication.
The Self>Other contrast specifically indexes self-referential processing (mPFC response to own moral behaviors), directly measuring perception/understanding of self, so I1 and I2 are met.

Although the contrast includes 'other' as the comparison, the Self>Other contrast emphasizes self-referential processing rather than measuring perception/understanding of others, so it does not meet I2 for this construct.
Localizer Other>Self contrasts responses to others versus self in moral descriptions, a social task indexing social processing; both I1 and I2 are satisfied.
The Other>Self localizer contrast does not target affiliation/attachment (no bonding, cooperation or competition manipulation), so it fails I1 for this construct.
This contrast is about self versus other moral processing in a localizer and does not involve social communication tasks (receptive/expressive communication), so I1 is not met.
Other>Self emphasizes processing of others relative to self; it does not measure perception/understanding of the self (I2 not met for self), so excluded.
Other>Self specifically indexes processing of others (responses to others' moral descriptions), directly measuring perception/understanding of others; I1 and I2 are satisfied.

Main-experiment contrast Communication > Moral collapses across self/other in a social task context (communication vs moral content) and therefore measures social processing broadly; I1 and I2 are met.

Although the overall study involves intergroup competition, this specific contrast isolates communication content vs moral content (collapsed across self/other) and does not specifically measure affiliation/attachment (no bonding/cooperation contrast), so I1 is not met for this annotation.

The contrast explicitly compares Communication to Moral content, directly indexing social communication processes (receptive/expressive aspects of communication); it meets I1 and I2 for social communication.
This contrast is collapsed across self/other and isolates communication vs moral content, so it does not specifically measure perception/understanding of the self (I2 for self not met).

Although communication often involves others, this contrast collapses across self/other and isolates content type rather than directly measuring perception/understanding of others, so it does not meet I2 for this construct.

Main-experiment contrast Moral > Communication is a social task contrast (moral content vs communication) collapsing across self/other and thus indexes social processing broadly; I1 and I2 are satisfied.

This contrast isolates moral versus communication content and does not specifically target affiliation/attachment processes (no bonding/cooperation manipulation), so it does not meet I1 for affiliation/attachment.
Moral>Communication is the reverse of a communication contrast and is not primarily indexing social communication processes, so it does not meet I1 for social communication.
This contrast is collapsed across self/other and isolates moral content, so it does not specifically measure perception/understanding of the self (I2 for self not met).

Although moral judgments can involve others, this contrast collapses across self/other and targets content type rather than directly measuring perception/understanding of others, so it does not meet I2 for this construct.
Main-experiment Self>Other (collapsing moral/communication) directly indexes self-referential processing in a social task context (self vs other) and thus meets I1 and I2 for social processing.
The Self>Other contrast indexes self-referential processing rather than affiliation/attachment (no explicit bonding/cooperation contrast), so it does not meet I1 for affiliation/attachment.
Although the contrast is from a social experiment, Self>Other collapsed across content does not specifically index social communication processes, so I1 for social communication is not met.
This contrast specifically contrasts self versus other (collapsed across content), directly measuring perception/understanding of the self and thereby satisfying I1 and I2 for this construct.
Self>Other emphasizes self-related processing and does not measure perception/understanding of others (I2 for others not met), so excluded.
Main-experiment Other>Self (collapsing moral/communication) indexes processing of others versus self within a social task context and therefore measures social processing broadly; I1 and I2 are met.
Other>Self is focused on other-referential processing and is not an affiliation/attachment-specific contrast (no bonding/cooperation manipulation), so it does not meet I1 for affiliation/attachment.
This contrast isolates other-related processing (collapsed across content) rather than measuring communication-specific processes, so it does not meet I1 for social communication.
Other>Self emphasizes processing of others relative to self and does not measure perception/understanding of the self, so I2 for self is not met.
Other>Self directly indexes perception/understanding of others (responses to others' content vs self), satisfying I1 and I2 for the perception_of_others construct.

The study measured processing of facial color to recognize emotion and health cues in others. This is a social-related task assessing perception of social information from faces, so it meets the criteria for Social Processing (broad social processing of others' cues).

The study does not investigate affiliation or attachment constructs (no tasks assessing kinship, cooperation, loved-one vs stranger, or bonding). The contrast and task focus on facial color and emotion/health cues rather than affiliation/attachment.
The analysis concerns reception of facial communication (facial color cues used to infer emotion/health). This is directly within Social Communication (receptive facial communication).
The task does not involve self-related processing, self-awareness, or judgments about the self. It examines perceptual processing of others' faces, so Perception/Self criteria are not met.
Facial color provides information about others' emotional and health states; the analysis examines representations and perception of others, matching Perception and Understanding of Others.

Contrast compares feedback onsets: self > other during a social interaction where participants updated trait ratings after receiving feedback; this is a social processing task involving self vs other feedback processing.

Task involves face-to-face interaction and social feedback updating (social learning, conformity), which relates to affiliation/attachment processes and bonding; contrast examines feedback processing for self vs other in interaction context.
The task involves exchange of socially relevant information (feedback) in a face-to-face interaction and perception/processing of that feedback; thus measures social communication.
Contrast is explicitly self > other feedback processing, reflecting perception and understanding of self-related information (self-ratings and self-related neural activity).
Contrast contrasts self vs other feedback; even though focused on self > other, the analysis inherently involves perception of others' feedback as the other condition.
Contrast is feedback onset: other > self during social interaction; directly measures social feedback processing regarding others.
Processing feedback about others in a social interaction taps social learning and bonding aspects relevant to affiliation/attachment.
The contrast captures reception of socially relevant information (feedback) about others during face-to-face interaction, fitting social communication.
Although contrast is other > self, the design includes self condition and comparison to self perception processes; analysis pertains to both self and other processing.
Directly measures perception and understanding of others by focusing on other > self feedback processing during social interaction.
Interaction tests cultural differences in self vs other feedback processing (Germans > Chinese), a social processing question about culture and social feedback.
Cultural modulation of feedback processing in interactions may reflect differences in social learning and affiliation tendencies; the task measures conformity and bonding-related updating.
Cross-cultural interaction effects on how feedback (communication) about self vs other is processed fits social communication constructs.
Interaction focuses on self > other and cultural differences in self-related neural activity, directly assessing perception and understanding of self.
Because the contrast uses self vs other and compares between cultures, it necessarily involves processing of others as well even if emphasis is on self-related changes.
Whole-brain correlation with updates in self > other contrast ties social feedback updating/processing to neural activity, a core social processing analysis.
Correlating neural responses with conformity/updates reflects social learning relevant to affiliation and attachment processes.
The correlation links neural processing to the reception and use of social feedback (communication) about traits; meets social communication criteria.
Correlation is with relative absolute mean updates (behavioral updating) within self > other contrast, implicating self-perception and understanding processes.
Although focused on self>other, the analysis involves the other condition and updates toward others' feedback are part of the measure, so includes perception of others.
Trial-by-trial correlation of feedback rating: self > other examines social feedback processing related to self versus other during interaction; clearly a social processing analysis.
Feedback rating correlations relate to social learning and updating during interactions, relevant to affiliation/attachment processes (conformity/social learning).
Trial-by-trial feedback ratings reflect exchange and reception of social information (communication) about traits, so included.
Contrast explicitly self > other for feedback rating, measuring self-related evaluations and perception of traits.
Although focused on self, the contrast uses other condition and thus involves perception of others' trait feedback; included.
Feedback discrepancies (positive) for self and other directly measure processing of social feedback and biased updating; a social processing measure.
Positive discrepancies and updating toward desirable feedback reflect social learning and bonding-related tendencies relevant to affiliation/attachment.
Processing of feedback discrepancies involves reception of communicated social information and comparison processes; fits social communication.
Includes self trials and updating toward desirable feedback pertains to self-perception and self-evaluation mechanisms.
Includes other trials as well and examines discrepancy processing for others, so covers perception of others' traits and feedback.
Feedback discrepancies (negative) for self and other also measure social feedback processing and biased updating; a social processing analysis.
Negative feedback updating may reflect social learning and affiliation processes (avoidance of negative social feedback) relevant to bonding.
Negative discrepancy processing involves reception of communicated negative feedback and comparison processes; fits social communication.
Negative feedback in self trials pertains to self-perception and self-evaluation mechanisms; included.
Includes other trials and examines perception/processing of others' negative feedback; included.

Contrast A compares reactive-aggressive social interaction scenarios to neutral baseline; task explicitly probes empathic/social processing of interactions, so it measures social processing.
A reflects reactive-aggressive (negative) interactions rather than affiliation/positive bonding, so it does not target affiliation/attachment.
The videos depict interpersonal interactions from a first-person perspective, involving exchange of social cues; thus they engage social communication processes.
The contrast probes perception of social interactions/empathy rather than explicit self-reflection, agency judgments, or self-knowledge.
Participants evaluate/experience others' actions and emotional states (reactive-aggressive agent), meeting the criteria for perception and understanding of others.
Contrast B compares social-positive interaction scenarios to neutral baseline; directly probes social processing of affiliative interactions.
B targets social-positive (affiliative) scenarios versus neutral, which measures affiliation/attachment-related processing.
Positive social interactions involve communicative cues and exchanges; the contrast captures social communication processes.
No explicit self-evaluation or self-referential judgment is assessed; task focuses on perceiving interactions rather than self-knowledge.
The contrast requires perceiving others’ affiliative actions and emotions, meeting perception-of-others criteria.
A & B combine reactive-aggressive and social-positive interaction contrasts versus neutral, encompassing social processing across conditions.
Because this combined analysis includes the social-positive condition (B), it captures affiliation/attachment-related processing as part of the contrast set.
The combined contrast includes interpersonal exchanges from both positive and aggressive interactions, engaging social communication processes.
The combined contrast still targets perception of interactions and empathy rather than explicit self-related judgments.
Both constituent contrasts require processing others’ actions/emotions, so the combined analysis measures perception and understanding of others.
Contrast D compares a second reactive-aggressive condition to neutral; it probes social/empathic processing of aggressive interactions.
D reflects reactive-aggressive scenarios rather than affiliative/attachment-related content, so it does not measure affiliation/attachment.
Reactive-aggressive interactions include interpersonal cues and exchanges; the contrast engages social communication processes.
The contrast assesses perception of others’ actions/emotional content and motor-preparatory responses rather than self-reflection or self-knowledge.
Participants perceive and respond to others’ aggressive actions and affective states, meeting the perception-of-others inclusion criteria.
Contrast E compares a second social-positive condition to neutral and therefore probes social processing of affiliative interactions.
E isolates social-positive (affiliative) interactions versus neutral, directly measuring affiliation/attachment-related processing.
Positive interaction videos contain communicative social cues; this contrast engages social communication mechanisms.
No explicit self-related judgments are described; focus is on perceiving others and empathic processing.
E requires perceiving affiliative others’ actions and emotions, meeting perception-of-others criteria.
D & E combine aggressive and positive final-phase contrasts versus neutral, covering social processing across affective interactions.
Because the combined contrast includes the social-positive condition (E), affiliation/attachment-related processing is present in the analysis.
The combined analysis includes interpersonal exchanges from both interaction types, engaging social communication processes.
The focus remains on perceiving interactions (others’ behaviors/emotions) rather than self-evaluative processing.
Both constituent contrasts require perception and understanding of others’ emotional and action states, satisfying the perception-of-others criteria.

The analysis examines how prior social interactions and impressions (mind-holderness) modulate activity in social brain regions (TPJ, medial prefrontal cortex, etc.) during an interactive game. Although interactions can involve communication, the analysis focuses on perceptual/representational differences for incongruence rather than explicit communicative content or behavior; it does not meet Social Communication inclusion criteria.
The contrast targets perception of other agents and scene meaningfulness, not self-related processing or judgments.

Incongruent interactions elicited enhanced processing in face/body and related regions, directly reflecting perception and representation of other people and their relations, meeting Perception/Others criteria.
The Congruent Interactions > Non-Interactions contrast manipulates social scene structure (interaction vs non-interaction), probing social scene processing and thus broad social processing.

This contrast compares interacting vs non-interacting dyads but does not assess affiliation or attachment (no measures of bonding or relationship quality), so it does not meet Affiliation/Attachment criteria.

Although interactions may entail communication, the contrast tests perceptual processing of interaction presence rather than communicative exchange or recognition; it does not directly measure Social Communication per inclusion criteria.
The contrast concerns perception of others in interactive vs non-interactive scenes, not self-related processing.
Comparing congruent interactions to non-interactions directly interrogates perception and representation of other agents and their relational context, aligning with Perception/Others.
Non-Interactions > Congruent Interactions examines neural responses to social scene absence vs presence of interaction, a manipulation of social scene processing and thus broad social processing.
The contrast reflects interaction absence vs presence and does not index attachment or affiliation constructs (no bond/relationship measures), so Affiliation/Attachment is not applicable.

The contrast focuses on perceptual differences between non-interaction and interaction scenes rather than measuring communicative behaviors or signal exchange, so it does not meet Social Communication criteria.
This contrast is about perception of other agents and their relational context rather than self-related processing.
Non-interactions evoke differential processing of agent representations compared to interactions; this directly pertains to Perception/Others (animacy/action/agent representations).
Incongruent Interactions > Non-Interactions contrasts socially implausible interactions with non-interactions, probing social scene processing and representations — a social processing measure.
This contrast does not assess affiliation or attachment (no bonding/relationship measures), so it does not meet Affiliation/Attachment inclusion criteria.
The analysis emphasizes perceptual/representational effects of incongruence rather than explicit communicative exchange; it does not directly assess Social Communication per criteria.
The contrast concerns how others and their relations are represented, not self-awareness or self-knowledge.
Comparing incongruent interactions to non-interactions taps perception and representation of other agents and their actions/relations, satisfying Perception/Others criteria.
Non-Interactions > Incongruent Interactions contrasts presence vs absence/type of social interaction and therefore indexes social scene processing, meeting broad social processing criteria.
This contrast addresses interaction type (non-interaction vs incongruent interaction) but does not measure affiliation, attachment, or bonding constructs.

The analysis focuses on perceptual differences related to interaction plausibility, not explicit communicative behavior or reception/production of social signals, so Social Communication criteria are not met.
This contrast involves perception of others and scene meaningfulness rather than self-referential processing.
Contrasting non-interactions with incongruent interactions probes how other agents and their relations are represented, consistent with Perception/Others.
