Contrast A. Fear>happy+neutral examines neural responses to fearful crowds versus other emotions using videos of groups — a clear social task assessing processing of social-emotional cues at the group level.

The contrast assesses emotion perception in crowds (fear vs other emotions) rather than measures of affiliation, bonding, or attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger); it does not target affiliation/attachment constructs.

The task involves perceiving affective signals from others (dynamic group expressions), which fits reception of nonverbal/social communicative cues (affect recognition) — the contrast measures social communication.
The contrast targets perception of others' emotions, not self-related judgments, agency, or self-knowledge; it does not measure perception/understanding of self.
This analysis directly probes perception and understanding of others’ emotional states in crowds (fearful expressions), matching the perception_of_others construct.
Contrast B. Fear+happy>neutral compares emotive (fearful/happy) crowds to neutral, addressing social-emotional processing of group expressions — a social processing task.
Contrast compares emotional versus neutral crowds; it does not involve affiliation/attachment measures or relational bonding tasks.
Assessing recognition of emotional signals from groups (reception of affective communication) fits social communication inclusion criteria.
No self-reflective or self-judgment processes are being measured; contrast concerns perception of others.
Directly measures perception/understanding of others’ emotional states in group contexts (emotive vs neutral crowds).
Contrast C. Fear+neutral>happy evaluates neural responses to fearful/neutral versus happy crowds — a social-emotional perception task of group expressions.
This contrast contrasts emotional valences in crowds and does not measure affiliation or attachment between individuals.
The analysis involves perceiving emotional signals from others (group expressions), aligning with reception of social communicative information.
No measures of self-awareness, agency, or self-related judgments are present in this contrast.
Contrast probes how observers perceive others’ emotional states (fear/neutral vs happy) in crowds, meeting perception_of_others criteria.
Contrast D. Happy>fear+neutral tests responses to happy crowds versus others — a social processing contrast focused on group emotional perception.
Although happiness can relate to affiliation, the contrast is about perceiving emotional expressions in crowds rather than explicit measures of attachment or bonding.
Happy expressions in groups are communicative social signals; the contrast examines reception of these signals, fitting social communication.
The contrast does not assess self-related processing or judgments; it focuses on perceiving others’ emotions.
Directly assesses observers’ perception of others’ emotional states (happiness) in group contexts, matching perception_others.
Contrast E. Neutral>fear+happy contrasts neutral crowds against emotional ones, addressing social perception of group affect and thus social processing.
This contrast concerns emotional valence detection in crowds, not affiliation/attachment measures or bonding tasks.
Perception of neutral versus emotional group signals concerns reception of social communicative cues, aligning with social communication.
No self-related judgments or introspective measures are present; the focus is on others' expressions.
Evaluates how observers perceive others’ emotional states (neutral vs emotional crowds), fitting perception_others criteria.
Main effect of dynamics compares interactive versus individual group dynamics — a core social-processing manipulation about how social interactions change perception of crowds.
Dynamics (interactive vs individual) probe interaction salience and action preparation rather than measures of affiliation/attachment or bonding.
Interactive dynamics modulate communicative signals (nonverbal interaction cues) and the perception of those signals — fitting social communication (reception of nonverbal cues).
The manipulation concerns perception of others' interactions and does not assess self-related processes or self-knowledge.
Dynamics between people directly affect perception and understanding of others’ actions/emotions (animacy/action perception), matching perception_others.
Analysis A. Interactive fear>individual fear isolates effects of social interaction on perception of fear in crowds — a social processing contrast about group dynamics and emotion.
Contrast targets interaction-driven threat/panic perception rather than affiliation or attachment measures.
Comparing interactive vs individual fearful displays examines communicative dynamics and reception of socially transmitted emotional signals, fitting social communication.
Focus is on others’ interactions and anticipatory/action-preparation responses rather than self-related cognition.
This contrast probes how observers interpret others’ fearful interactions (action/animacy cues and emotional state), aligning with perception_others.

Analysis B. Interactive fear>individual fear + interactive happy>individual happy examines interaction effects across emotions, a social-processing assessment of how dynamics modulate emotional perception.
This contrast tests interaction by emotion rather than affiliation/attachment constructs like bonding or relationship measures.
Evaluates how interaction modulates communicative emotional signals across fear and happiness — relevant to reception of social communication cues.
No self-related processing is targeted; the contrast focuses on perceiving others’ interactions and emotions.
Directly examines perception of others’ emotional states and interactions across emotions, fulfilling perception_others criteria.

Analysis C. Interactive fear>individual fear + interactive neutral>individual neutral assesses social-interaction effects specifically for fear and neutral conditions — clearly a social processing contrast.
Contrast concerns interaction modulations of emotion perception rather than affiliation/attachment measures.
Interaction-driven changes in emotional signaling (fear/neutral) relate to reception of nonverbal social communication; the contrast measures social communicative processing.
No self-referential or introspective measures are assessed; focus is on perception of others’ dynamics and emotions.
Examines perception/understanding of others’ emotional dynamics (fearful and neutral interactions) and action cues, matching perception_others.
Analysis D. Interactive fear>individual fear + individual neutral>interactive neutral contrasts interaction effects across fear and neutral, probing social processing of group dynamics and emotion.
This contrast tests dynamics by emotion and does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs or bonding measures.
Contrasting interactive vs individual displays across emotions addresses communicative content and reception of social signals, consistent with social communication.
The analysis does not involve self-related cognition; it concerns perception of others' interactions and emotions.
Directly addresses perception and understanding of others’ emotional states and interactions in group contexts, fitting perception_others.
Analysis E. Interactive neutral>individual neutral isolates interaction effects for neutral crowds — a social-processing contrast focused on dynamics regardless of overt emotion.
This contrast focuses on interaction/dynamics with neutral expressions, not affiliation or attachment measures.
Even for neutral expressions, interactive versus individual dynamics affect communicative nonverbal signals; the contrast examines reception of those cues.
No self-related processes are measured; the contrast addresses perception of others’ interactions with neutral affect.
Assesses perception of others’ interactions and action/animacy cues even when expressions are neutral, aligning with perception_others.

The contrast examines deception in strategic social interactions (lying vs truth), a social task involving interpretation and response to others; therefore it measures social processing.

The task involves strategic deception and informational asymmetry rather than measuring affiliation, attachment, or relationship bonding; it does not probe close relationships, cooperation for bonding, or attachment processes.
Deception and message-sending are forms of social communication (exchange of socially relevant information); contrasts directly assess communicative behavior (lying, sophisticated deception).
Analyses probe the sender's intentions to deceive (self-related intentions/agency), which falls under perception/understanding of the self.
Strategic deception requires modeling the receiver's beliefs and expectations (understanding others' mental states), so the contrast measures perception and understanding of others.
Simple deception vs truth is a social task assessing behavior in interpersonal communication and thus measures social processing.
The contrast targets deceptive communication in a game-theoretic context, not affiliation/attachment processes or close-relationship bonding.
Contrasting lying vs truth directly targets production of socially relevant communicative acts (deception), fitting social communication.
Choosing to lie engages self-referential processes (intentions, agency), so this contrast involves perception/understanding of the self.
Deception implies considering the receiver's beliefs; simple deception contrasts therefore involve understanding others' mental states.
Sophisticated deception (telling truth to deceive) is inherently social and taps processes for interpreting and influencing others, meeting social processing criteria.
Although social, sophisticated deception is not about forming attachments or affiliation; it manipulates beliefs in a strategic interaction rather than measuring bonding.
Sophisticated deception is a communicative act (producing messages intended to mislead); the contrast measures communicative production and intent.
The analysis explicitly assesses the sender's veridical intention to deceive (self-related intention/agency), fitting perception of self.
Sophisticated deception requires representing what the receiver will believe and their mental states, so it measures perception/understanding of others.
Comparing sophisticated vs simple deception examines different social strategies in interaction and thus involves social processing.
The contrast compares types of deceptive strategy rather than affiliation/attachment processes related to bonding or close relationships.
This contrast differentiates communicative strategies (different forms of message production aimed at influencing others), so it measures social communication.
Distinguishing sophisticated from simple deception probes differences in intentions and self-monitoring (agency), implicating self-perception processes.
The comparison requires considering others' beliefs and expectations to select strategy, engaging understanding of others' mental states.
Contrasting truth vs deception examines behavior in social interaction and thus measures social processing.
This contrast contrasts truthful versus deceptive behavior in a strategic context; it does not probe attachment or affiliation processes specifically.
Truthful versus deceptive messaging directly concerns social communication and the production of socially relevant information.
Deciding to tell the truth versus deceive involves self-related decisions and intentions, so it measures perception/understanding of the self.
Evaluating truth vs deception requires modelling the receiver's likely beliefs and reactions, implicating perception of others' mental states.
The parametric contrast models incentive to deceive in social exchanges (sender vs receiver payoff tension), which is a social task measuring social processing.
Although involving interpersonal payoffs, the parametric contrast models incentives for deception, not affiliation/attachment or bonding processes.
Modeling incentives to deceive concerns communicative decisions to send misleading information and thus relates to social communication.
The parametric effect models the sender's decision-making and incentives (self-oriented intentions/agency), fitting self-perception processes.
The contrast explicitly models tension between sender's and receiver's payoffs, requiring representation of the other's outcomes and beliefs, so it measures perception of others.

The PORTRAIT general effect (Rules + Desires > 0) involves predicting others' behavior and updating impressions about characters, which is clearly social processing. The task is explicitly social and the contrasts measure social cognition.

The task concerns predicting unknown characters' behavior (rules vs desires) and impression updating, not measures of affiliation, attachment, close relationships, or kinship. It does not match affiliation/attachment constructs.

The paradigm tests mentalizing and deontic inference about characters' behavior rather than reception or production of communicative signals (faces, gaze, verbal exchange). Thus it does not meet social communication criteria.
Contrasts examine perception/understanding of others' behavior and impression updating, not self-related processing (agency, self-knowledge).

The contrasts directly assess representation and inference about others' mental states and behaviors (desires vs rules), which aligns with perception/understanding of others (including understanding mental states).
Conjoint effects of Rules and Desires reflect common social-cognitive processes for predicting behavior; task is social and measures social processing.
This contrast identifies shared activation for rule- and desire-based predictions, not affiliation/attachment constructs like bonding or loved-one vs stranger comparisons.
The analysis targets mentalizing/deontic inference rather than communicative signal processing or production, so does not meet social communication inclusion criteria.
The focus is on understanding others' behavior (rules/desires), not on self-related perception or judgments.
Conjoint activations for predicting others' behavior indicate processes of representing others' states/traits, matching perception/understanding of others.
Desires > Rules isolates processing related to inferring others' desires, a core social cognition operation; thus included as social processing.
The contrast distinguishes desire-based inference versus rule-based inference, not measures of affiliation/attachment or bonding.
This contrast probes mental state inference about desires rather than communicative reception/production; it does not meet social communication criteria.
Contrast targets understanding others' desires, not self-related processes.
Desire-based inference is directly about understanding others' mental states, matching perception/understanding of others inclusion criteria.
Rules > Desires isolates processing involved in predicting rule-following behavior of characters, a social cognitive operation, so included.
This contrast isolates rule-based predictions, not affiliation/attachment constructs or bonding measures.
Focus is on deontic inference and rule-following, not communicative signal reception or production.
Contrast concerns others' behavior (rule-following) rather than self-perception or self-knowledge.
Predicting rule-based behavior requires representing others' likely actions and possibly their norms, aligning with perception/understanding of others.
FEEDBACK general effect (0 > Rules + Desires) is part of the social learning process about characters' profiles; it relates to social processing (updating impressions).
Feedback contrasts reflect learning about behavior patterns, not affiliation/attachment constructs.
Feedback concerns updating beliefs about characters rather than communicative exchange or facial/gesture processing.
The feedback phase pertains to learning about others' behavior, not self-related processing.
Feedback signals update representations of others' behavior and profile, consistent with perception/understanding of others (mental state inference, trait learning).
FEEDBACK main effect Desires > Rules concerns social learning about others' desire-driven behavior; this is social processing.
The contrast isolates desire-driven feedback versus rule-driven feedback, not measures of affiliation/attachment or close relationships.
This feedback contrast is about mental state inference (desires) rather than communication per se.
Contrast pertains to perceiving others' desire-driven behavior in feedback, not self-related perception.
Desire-related feedback updates representations of others' mental states and behaviors, matching perception/understanding of others.
PORTRAIT events comparing (Rules + Desires)/2 to Neutral index social scenario processing (predicting character behavior) and thus count as social processing.
The contrast compares social scenarios to neutral but does not target affiliation/attachment constructs specifically (no bonding or close-relationship measures).

Although social vs neutral is compared, the task centers on behavioral prediction and impression updating rather than communicative signals, so it does not meet social communication inclusion criteria.
Contrast concerns processing of others' scenarios versus neutral scenes, not self-perception or self-related judgments.
Comparing social scenarios to neutral implicates representation and inference about others' behaviors and mental states, matching perception/understanding of others.
Conjoint effects (Rules > Neutral) ∩ (Desires > Neutral) reflect social scenario processing and prediction of others' behavior; fits social processing.
This conjoint contrast identifies general social scenario activation but not affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding or close-relationship comparisons).
The contrast isolates social scenario processing for behavioral prediction rather than communicative reception/production.
Conjoint social>neutral effects concern perceiving others' behaviors in scenarios, not self-related processes.
Joint increases for social scenarios indicate representation and inference about others' behaviors/mental states, aligning with perception/understanding of others.
Neutral > (Rules + Desires)/2 highlights differences relative to social scenarios but is part of the same social task and therefore still within social processing domain.
This contrast emphasizes neutral over social scenarios and does not probe affiliation/attachment phenomena.
Neutral>social does not index communicative processing; the paradigm centers on behavioral prediction and impression updating rather than communication signals.
Contrast contrasts others' scenario processing with neutral, not self-perception or self-knowledge.

Even where neutral outweighs social scenarios, the analyzed events are from a task about other characters; the contrast informs about processing of others and is therefore relevant to perception/understanding of others.
Desires > Rules in the PORTRAIT time-bins again isolates desire-driven social inference, which is social processing.
This contrast separates desire- vs rule-based predictions and does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs.
Task focuses on mental state inference rather than communication (facial/gaze/verbal) reception or production.
The contrast concerns perception/understanding of others' desires, not the self.
Desire-based processing is directly about inferring others' mental states and fits the perception/understanding of others construct.
Rules > Desires in the PORTRAIT time-bins targets rule-based social inference and impression updating, which are social processing operations.
This contrast isolates rule-based inference and does not assess affiliation or attachment-related constructs.
The analysis involves deontic inference and behavior prediction rather than communicative reception/production.
Contrast concerns others' rule-following behavior, not self-related processes.
Predicting rule-based behavior of others implicates understanding others' actions/norms and fits perception/understanding of others.
The SCENARIO × PROFILE interaction analyzes differential social inference patterns (desire vs rule profiles) and thus is social processing.
Interaction contrasts differentiate inference strategies across profiles, not affiliation/attachment measures.
This higher-order interaction concerns mental state and rule inferences across profiles rather than communicative processing.
The interaction pertains to differences in perceiving others' behavior across profiles, not self-perception.
Interactions between scenario and profile concern how participants represent and update beliefs about others, aligning with perception/understanding of others.
The complementary SCENARIO × PROFILE interaction also probes social inference and impression updating across profiles, and thus is social processing.
This interaction contrast still focuses on deontic vs mentalizing inference patterns, not attachment or affiliation measures.
Focus is on representational/inferential aspects of social cognition across profiles rather than communication per se.
Interaction examines perception/attribution about others across conditions, not self-related processing.
This interaction reflects differences in how others' mental states/behavioral tendencies are represented and updated, matching perception/understanding of others.

The study examines face-to-face dyadic social interaction and dfMRI responses to eye contact and reciprocal interaction, so the analysis clearly measures broad social processing.

The study focuses on reciprocal interaction, eye contact, and empathy/mentalization networks, but does not report tasks or contrasts specifically measuring affiliation or attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger).
The paradigm involves face-to-face interaction and explicitly mentions eye contact and reciprocal interaction, which are canonical social communication behaviors.
The paper emphasizes empathy and mentalization (other-oriented processes) and network emergence; it does not describe measures explicitly targeting self-perception or self-referential judgments.
The analyses identify empathy and mentalization networks and reciprocal interaction, which concern perceiving and reasoning about others' states — matching perception-of-others constructs.
The endogenous system analysis relates to reciprocal social interaction and mentalization; it therefore addresses broad social processing.
Although the endogenous system involves mentalization and default-mode engagement, the study does not report affiliation/attachment-specific tasks or contrasts.
Endogenous processes described (mentalization, reciprocal interaction) are integral to social communication, including eye contact and interactive signaling.
The analysis emphasizes other-related mentalization and network emergence rather than explicit self-perception measures; no self-judgment tasks are reported.
Mentalization and empathy networks identified in the endogenous system indicate processing and understanding of others' mental states, matching perception-of-others criteria.

The 'why > how' contrast targets attributional/mentalizing processes across stimulus categories, including social stimuli. This directly measures social processing (understanding others' beliefs/motives) even though nonsocial trials are included, so the analysis satisfies both being social-related and measuring social processing.

The contrast compares explanatory modes (why vs how) and is focused on attributional/mentalizing processes, not on affiliation, attachment, or bonding (no kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation/competition manipulations).

The task contrasts why vs how questions about behaviors and situations (attributional reasoning) rather than communication processes (facial or vocal communication, expressive reciprocity, gaze). It does not measure social communication per the inclusion criteria.
The contrast addresses attribution about others' mental states/causes of behavior, not self-awareness or self-judgment. It does not measure perception/understanding of the self.

The why > how contrast requires representing and reasoning about others' beliefs, motives, and intentions (understanding mental states), which fits the Perception and Understanding of Others construct (Understanding Mental States).

This contrast explicitly tests stronger activation for why>how in social versus nonsocial stimuli, directly indexing social processing and selective recruitment for social attributions. It meets both criteria for social processing.
The contrast isolates social vs nonsocial attributional processing, not affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation).

Although the contrast involves social stimuli, it targets mental-state attribution rather than communicative perception/production (faces, gaze, verbal exchange), so it does not meet the Social Communication inclusion criteria.
The contrast focuses on attributions about others (social > nonsocial); it does not probe self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency.

The social > nonsocial why>how effect isolates neural responses involved in understanding others' mental states (Understanding Mental States subconstruct), directly matching Perception and Understanding of Others.

The Incongruent > Congruent contrast indexes automatic imitation/mimicry, a social behavior sensitive to social cues; the task involves social stimuli (faces) and examines regulation of mimicry in social contexts, thus measuring broad social processing.
The study frames mimicry as an implicit affiliative signal and the contrast measures mimicry regulation (affiliative behavior), so this contrast probes affiliation-related processes.
Mimicry is a form of social communication/expressive reciprocation; the contrast captures production/reception dynamics of facially cued imitation, fitting the social communication construct.
The contrast assesses implicit imitation driven by others' faces and social cues, not self-related awareness, agency, or self-knowledge; it does not measure perception/understanding of the self.

The contrast involves perceiving others' facial expressions and group membership and inferring affiliative/threat-related responses; it therefore measures perception and understanding of others (action and emotion perception).
Happy (Incongruent>Congruent) contrast examines mimicry modulation by a social-affective cue (happy expression), indexing social processing of emotion-driven affiliation.
Happy faces were hypothesized to elicit reciprocation (affiliative response); this contrast directly tests affiliation-related modulation of mimicry.
The contrast captures production/reciprocation of facially cued mimicry in response to emotional expressions, a form of social communication (production/reception of facial signals).
This contrast targets responses to others' emotional expressions and mimicry behavior, not self-related processing or self-knowledge.
Contrasts focusing on happy faces involve perceiving and responding to others' emotional states and are therefore measures of perception/understanding of others (emotion and action perception).
Angry (Incongruent>Congruent) contrast examines mimicry modulation by an emotional threat cue (angry expression), reflecting social processing of affect and social regulation.
The study interprets mimicry toward angry faces as regulated by affiliative/appeasement goals; this contrast probes affiliation-related regulation (appeasement).
Angry-face contrasts index communicative/responsive elements of mimicry to affective facial signals, aligning with social communication (reception/production of facial signals).
The contrast concerns perception of others' angry expressions and consequent mimicry regulation, not self-referential processing or agency.
This contrast assesses perception of others' emotional states (anger) and action-related responses (mimicry), thus measuring perception and understanding of others.
Out-group (Incongruent>Congruent) contrast examines mimicry modulation by social group membership (in- vs out-group), a clear social-processing manipulation.
The contrast tests increased mimicry toward out-group faces interpreted as an affiliative/appeasement behavior toward perceived threat, directly probing affiliation/attachment processes.

Mimicry toward out-group members is a form of social communicative behavior intended to regulate social relations; the contrast measures production/reciprocation aspects of facially cued communication.
The manipulation concerns perception of others' group membership and consequent mimicry, not self-related cognition or agency.
Out-group contrasts require perceiving and evaluating others' social group membership and associated affective meaning; this fits perception/understanding of others (social trait/emotion inference).
In-group (Incongruent>Congruent) contrast assesses mimicry modulation by in-group membership, a social cue central to social processing and affiliation dynamics.
Mimicry differences for in-group faces relate to affiliation/reciprocation mechanisms; this contrast probes affiliation-related processes.
The in-group contrast captures communicative reciprocity and mimicry responses to socially relevant facial cues, aligning with social communication constructs.
This contrast focuses on responses to others categorized as in-group, not on self-awareness or self-knowledge processes.
In-group contrasts involve perceiving others' group membership and socially relevant cues, thus indexing perception and understanding of others.

The contrast 'Eye Contact > Averted Gaze' manipulates a social cue (eye contact) and examines neural responses to social interaction signals; this directly measures social processing (per Abstract: observing eye contact modulates gaze following and augments processing).

This contrast probes immediate social attention and interaction cues rather than affiliation, bonding, or attachment processes (no measures of kinship, relationship closeness, or attachment-related constructs).

Eye contact and gaze are core aspects of social communication (production/reception of facial/eye signals); the contrast assesses neural responses to communicative eye contact vs averted gaze, matching the construct.
The contrast concerns perception of others' gaze/eye contact, not self-related judgment, agency, or self-knowledge processes.
Eye contact versus averted gaze involves perceiving and interpreting others' gaze and attentional states, directly fitting Perception and Understanding of Others.

The 'Averted Gaze > Eye Contact' contrast also manipulates social gaze cues and captures social processing related to interpreting others' gaze away from interaction; thus it measures social processing.
This contrast contrasts averted gaze with eye contact but does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (no relationship or bonding measures).
Contrasting averted gaze and eye contact examines communicative aspects of gaze behavior (reception/production of facial/eye signals), fitting Social Communication.
The contrast targets perception of others' gaze rather than self-related processes or judgments.
Averted versus direct gaze pertains to perceiving others' attentional states and intentions, directly matching Perception and Understanding of Others.

'Congruent Gaze Cues > Incongruent Gaze Cues' contrasts processing of socially guided attention (gaze following congruent vs incongruent), which is a social processing measure as described in the Abstract.
This contrast focuses on gaze-following attention and congruency effects, not on affiliation, attachment, or relationship constructs.
Gaze following is a form of social communication (reception of gaze cues and orienting) — this contrast directly indexes communicative gaze processing.
This is about responding to others' gaze cues (attention to others) rather than self-perception or self-referential processing.
Congruent vs incongruent gaze cues involve perceiving and interpreting others' attentional signals and intentions, fitting Perception and Understanding of Others.
'Incongruent Gaze Cues > Congruent Gaze Cues' examines social attention when gaze cues conflict with targets — a social processing measure of how social cues influence attention.
Contrast addresses gaze congruency/conflict, not affiliation or attachment-related constructs.
Incongruent vs congruent gaze cues pertain to communicative aspects of gaze and signaling; the contrast measures reception/processing of gaze communication.
The contrast focuses on perception of others' gaze and attentional signals, not self-related cognition or self-awareness.
This contrast taps perception and interpretation of others' gaze behavior (especially when it conflicts with expected targets), fitting Perception and Understanding of Others.
The 'Eye Contact congruent > Averted Gaze congruent' interaction isolates how observed eye contact modulates congruent gaze-following — a social processing effect as framed in the Abstract.
Although eye contact can signal social bonding, this contrast probes momentary modulation of gaze-following, not attachment/affiliation measures or relationships.
This contrast examines how a communicative signal (eye contact) modulates processing of gaze cues (gaze-following congruency), directly relevant to Social Communication.
This contrast concerns perception of others' interactions and how that affects gaze processing, not self-related processes.

The contrast 'emotionally negative > neutral video' in the EmpaToM manipulates empathy (affective sharing) and thus probes social processing broadly (perception and interpretation of social-affective cues).
This contrast targets empathic responses to emotional videos, not affiliation/attachment or bonding processes (no measures of close relationships, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation, etc.).

Empathy involves representing and responding to others' emotional states, fitting the 'Perception and Understanding of Others' construct (particularly understanding emotional states).
The contrast 'ToM > nonToM question' probes Theory of Mind (understanding others' mental states), a core social processing function.

The study uses an empathy-for-pain task with experimentally created ingroup/outgroup members — a clearly social task assessing social processing (how group membership modulates empathy). The analysis (whole-study table listing corrected results) derives from this social processing paradigm.

The task manipulates minimal group membership but does not directly measure affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, attachment style, loved-one vs stranger contrasts, cooperation/competition).

The paradigm measures empathic neural responses to viewed painful/neutral situations rather than exchange or processing of communicative signals (no explicit measures of facial communication or communicative production/reception).

MG2 synchronization reflects representation and tracking of the partner’s attention/behavior, consistent with perception-of-others.
Experiment 3 MG1 synchronization again indexes dyadic shared attention and social interaction across mutual-gaze trials.

MG1 involves gaze-based interaction; inter-individual coupling reflects social communicative processes.

MG1 synchronization reflects processing of the partner’s attention and actions (perception/understanding of others).
Experiment 3 MG2 inter-subject synchronization measures shared attention and dyadic interaction, a social-processing construct.
MG2 in Experiment 3 does not measure attachment or affiliation constructs explicitly.
MG2 captures gaze-exchange and joint-attention processes, central to social communication.
Focus is on dyadic neural synchronization rather than self-related processing.
MG2 synchronization indexes representation of the partner’s attention/behavior, aligning with perception-of-others.

The analysis examines neural responses while viewing social versus nonsocial dynamic gestures and correlates activity with extraversion/sociability, directly measuring social processing.

The analysis concerns perception of others' gestures and personality correlations, not self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge judgments—so it does not measure perception/understanding of self.

Viewing and interpreting actors' social gestures (including manipulations of actor-orientation and face-visibility) targets perception and understanding of others’ actions and social intent, fitting action perception and mental-state-relevant processes.
This analysis investigates how neuroticism modulates neural responses to social gesture features (actor-orientation and face-visibility), clearly measuring social processing.

Although the analysis examines social gesture processing, it does not target affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding or relationship-specific contrasts), so affiliation/attachment criteria are not met.

The reported effects reflect responses to others' gestures and contextual features (face visibility, perspective) rather than self-related cognitions or self-judgments, so perception_self is not applicable.

The analysis manipulates actor-oriented perspective and face visibility, directly implicating perception and understanding of others (action perception and cues to mental states), meeting this construct.

The contrast examines control of interpersonal social attitudes (trust/distrust) toward faces — an explicitly social task measuring social processing.

The analyses concern attitudes toward others (trust/distrust) rather than self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency; thus it does not meet the perception/self inclusion criterion.
Participants evaluate and change trustworthiness judgments of other people’s faces, directly probing perception and understanding of others’ traits and intentions.
The Trust > Age contrast involves explicit control of interpersonal trust toward faces — a social processing task.

Although related to interpersonal evaluation, the contrast targets trust judgments rather than measures of affiliation/attachment or bonding; it does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion criterion.

This contrast concerns attitudes toward others and does not assess self-related processes (agency or self-knowledge); it does not meet the perception/self inclusion criterion.
Distrust evaluations of faces probe understanding of others’ traits/intentions, consistent with perception and understanding of others.

Although individual differences in trust can relate to bonding, the analysis specifically measures control of trust toward faces rather than explicit affiliation/attachment constructs; it does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion criterion.
The analysis examines individual differences in attitude control, not communicative behaviors or reception/production of social signals; it does not meet the social communication inclusion criterion.
The analysis concerns regulation of attitudes toward others rather than self-related judgments or self-knowledge; it does not meet the perception/self inclusion criterion.
Individual differences in controlling trust involve representations and evaluations of other people (trustworthiness), meeting perception/others criteria.

Task is an affective theory-of-mind (ToM) paradigm assessing others' emotional states and responses to emotional facial expressions (EFE); this is squarely social processing.
The paradigm tests affective ToM and responses to facial expressions, not affiliation, attachment, bonding, or related constructs (no kinship, cooperation, or loved-vs-stranger contrasts).
Analyses involve reception of emotional facial expressions (EFE) and inference of affect—this is reception of facial communication within social communication.
Analyses focus on inferring others' emotions (affective ToM) rather than self-perception, self-monitoring, or agency.
Affective ToM explicitly assesses understanding and reasoning about others' emotional states (Understanding Mental States subconstruct).
Contrast EFE > no EFE directly tests how social cues (emotional facial expressions) affect affective ToM processing—measures social processing.
Contrast isolates effects of emotional facial expressions on ToM processing; it does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs or related tasks.
EFE > no EFE isolates processing of facial emotional signals relevant to reception of facial communication.
This contrast addresses perception of others' emotions, not self-related judgments or self-awareness.
Contrast examines neural responses related to understanding others' emotions (affective ToM), matching the perception/understanding of others construct.
No EFE > EFE contrast still involves social judgments about others' emotional states and thus measures social processing.
Contrast compares presence/absence of facial expression effects on ToM but does not probe affiliation/attachment-related constructs.
Although showing absence > presence of EFE, the contrast pertains to processing of social communicative cues (EFE) and their influence on ToM.
Focus remains on inferring others' emotional states, not self-perception or self-knowledge.
Contrast addresses how perceiving (or not perceiving) facial cues affects understanding others' mental/emotional states—fits perception_others.
This correlation links differential neural responses to EFE with behavioral RT reductions during affective ToM judgments—clearly social processing.
The correlation concerns task performance and emotion inference, not affiliation or attachment measures.
Differential activation to EFE relates to behavioral facilitation; this implicates reception and processing of facial communicative cues.
The analysis examines neural-behavior relationships for inferring others' emotions, not self-related constructs.
Correlation ties neural markers to the ability to understand others' emotional states (affective ToM), fitting perception_others.
Correlation of differential activation (no EFE > EFE) with RT effects involves social judgments about others and thus social processing.
This analysis addresses effects of facial-expression absence on ToM and RTs, not affiliation/attachment constructs.
Even contrasts emphasizing no EFE relate to processing of communicative cues (or their absence) during emotion inference from others' behavior.
Focus is on perceiving and inferring others' emotional states rather than self-related processes.
Analysis concerns understanding others' mental/emotional states (affective ToM) and how neural differences relate to behavior—matches perception_others.
Interaction testing greater EFE effects during explicit affective ToM demand examines social-cognitive processing of others' emotions—social processing.
This interaction manipulates ToM demand and EFE presence; it does not probe affiliation or attachment.
The contrast tests how facial communicative cues (EFE) modulate affective ToM processing when explicitly demanded—directly relevant to social communication (reception of facial signals).
The manipulation concerns processing of others' emotions under task demand, not self-perception or self-knowledge.
Interaction addresses how perceiving facial expressions under ToM demands affects understanding others' emotional states—central to perception_others.
This complementary interaction contrast still examines social-cognitive effects of EFE under ToM demands—measures social processing.
Contrast addresses EFE × ToM demand interaction, not affiliation/attachment constructs.
Contrast pertains to processing of facial emotional cues in communicative contexts and how they affect ToM—relevant to social communication.
Contrast targets inference about others under different conditions, not self-related processing.
Analysis concerns understanding others' emotional states and how EFE presence interacts with ToM demands—matches perception_others.
PPI analyses test functional connectivity between the amygdala (EFE detector) and ToM network during affective ToM tasks—this addresses social processing networks.
PPI examines connectivity related to emotion inference and facial-expression processing, not affiliation/attachment constructs.
Connectivity between amygdala (processing facial emotion) and ToM regions during tasks involving EFE pertains to social communication (reception and integration of facial cues).
PPI focuses on inter-regional coupling for perceiving others' emotions and integrating social cues, not self-perception processes.
PPI results describe interactions between regions supporting understanding others' affective states (affective ToM), fitting perception_others.
Positive correlations between ToM matching accuracy and PPI effects relate behavioral social-cognitive performance to neural connectivity—social processing.
Analysis links ToM matching to connectivity; it does not involve measures of affiliation or attachment.
Relating matching with consensus judgments to PPI implicates processing and integration of communicative cues (including facial expressions) in social communication.
This analysis addresses accuracy in judging others and related connectivity, not self-related cognition.
Correlation between ToM matching and connectivity relates directly to understanding others' emotional states—perception_others.
Negative correlations between ToM matching and PPI effects still link social cognitive performance and connectivity—constitutes social processing.
This negative-correlation analysis does not probe affiliation or attachment constructs.
Negative relationships between matching and connectivity involve processing communicative facial cues and integration—relevant to social communication.
Analysis concerns understanding others and neural connectivity rather than self-perception or self-knowledge.
Negative correlation implicates mechanisms for understanding others' affective states and their neural coupling—fits perception_others.

The contrast (negative vs. positive performance feedback) involves social-evaluative feedback from another agent and thus engages social processing (receiving, interpreting, and responding to social information).
The contrast concerns evaluative feedback on performance rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (no explicit assessment of bonding, close relationships, cooperation, or kinship).
Performance feedback is a form of verbal social communication (reception of communicative feedback), so this contrast measures social communication processes.
Receiving performance feedback directly affects self-evaluation and emotional state (self-perception), so the contrast taps processes related to perception/understanding of the self.
Participants must process and interpret another person's evaluative feedback (the sender's behavior/intention), engaging perception and understanding of others.
Contrast compares emotional empathic vs unempathic comments — clearly a social interaction manipulation that probes social processing of empathic responses.

Although empathy can influence affiliative feelings, the contrast targets empathic vs unempathic verbal responses and does not directly measure affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding or relationship measures).
This contrast isolates effects of verbal empathic communication (reception of non-facial, verbal communicative acts), meeting social communication criteria.
Empathic comments modulate recipients' feelings and internal emotional state, indicating measurement of self-perception and self-related affect.
Processing empathic vs unempathic comments requires representing the communicator's stance/intention and thus involves understanding others' mental states/affective stance.
Contrast of unempathic > empathic comments probes social processing related to how different social responses affect recipients.
The contrast contrasts communicative styles (empathic vs unempathic) but does not explicitly measure affiliation or attachment outcomes.
Unempathic vs empathic comments are forms of verbal social communication; the contrast measures processing of these communicative differences.
Differences between unempathic and empathic comments impact recipients' self-reported feelings, indicating self-related processing is measured.
Discriminating unempathic vs empathic responses requires attributing intentions/stances to the communicator, engaging perception of others.
Contrast between cognitive unempathic and cognitive empathic comments is a social manipulation probing processing of empathic content.
This contrast isolates cognitive empathy vs its absence but does not assess affiliation or attachment per se.
Cognitive empathic comments are a form of verbal social communication (reception of content about others' mental states), so this contrast fits social communication.
Cognitive empathic vs unempathic comments affect the recipient's emotional state/feelings and self-related processing, so self-perception applies.
Cognitive empathy explicitly involves understanding another's mental states (mentalizing), so this contrast clearly engages perception/understanding of others.
Contrast of empathic (EE + CE) > high level baseline examines neural responses to empathic social comments, a social processing manipulation.
Although empathic comments can foster affiliation, this contrast compares empathic comments to baseline and does not explicitly measure attachment/bonding.
Empathic comments are verbal communicative acts; the contrast measures reception and processing of social communication.
Empathic comments modulate recipients' feelings and internal states compared to baseline, indicating self-perception processes are engaged.
Responding to empathic comments requires representing the communicator's intent and mental state, engaging perception of others.
Emotional empathic > baseline tests processing of emotionally empathic social responses, clearly within social processing.
This contrast focuses on emotional empathic responses versus baseline, not directly measuring affiliation/attachment outcomes.
Emotional empathic verbal comments are a form of social communication; the contrast measures reception and processing of such communication.
Emotional empathic comments alter recipients' feelings and internal states compared to baseline, implicating self-related perception.
Processing emotional empathy requires understanding the communicator's affective stance, involving perception of others' emotional states.
Cognitive empathic > baseline examines processing of cognitive empathic responses, a social processing manipulation.
This contrast focuses on cognitive empathic comments relative to baseline but does not explicitly measure affiliation or attachment constructs.
Cognitive empathic comments are verbal communicative acts about others' mental states; the contrast measures social communication reception.
Cognitive empathic comments influence recipients' feelings and internal appraisal compared to baseline, implicating self-related processes.
Cognitive empathy explicitly involves understanding another's mental states (mentalizing), so this contrast engages perception of others.
Comparing emotional vs cognitive comments is a social manipulation probing differential processing of two types of social communicative acts.
The contrast tests modality/content of comments (emotional vs cognitive) rather than directly measuring affiliation or attachment outcomes.
Emotional and cognitive comments are distinct forms of verbal social communication; the contrast measures reception/processing of communicative differences.
Different comment types can differentially affect recipients' emotions and self-related states, so self-perception processes are engaged.
Distinguishing emotional from cognitive comments requires representing others' communicative intent and affective stance, involving perception of others.
Emotional empathic > cognitive empathic directly compares two social-empathic comment types, probing social processing.
This contrast focuses on type of empathy (emotional vs cognitive) rather than explicit affiliation/attachment measures.
Both conditions are verbal social communicative acts; the contrast isolates differences in communicative content/style, meeting social communication criteria.
Comparing emotional to cognitive empathic comments assesses their differential effects on recipients' feelings and self-related states.
Differentiating emotional versus cognitive empathic comments requires mentalizing about the communicator's affective vs cognitive stance, engaging perception of others.
Emotional unempathic > cognitive unempathic contrasts types of unempathic comments, which still involve social communicative processing.
The contrast contrasts unempathic comment types and does not explicitly assess affiliation/attachment.
Both conditions are verbal communicative acts (unempathic comments); the contrast measures processing of communicative differences, so social communication applies.
Unempathic comments affect recipients' feelings and self-related states (likely increasing negative affect), so perception of self is engaged.
Distinguishing unempathic emotional vs cognitive comments requires representing the communicator's attitude/intent, involving perception of others.
Cognitive unempathic > emotional unempathic contrast examines processing of social communicative differences and thus taps social processing.
This contrast isolates content/style differences of unempathic comments and does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs.
Comparing cognitive vs emotional unempathic comments involves processing of verbal communicative acts, fitting social communication criteria.
Different unempathic comment types likely influence recipients' self-related feelings, so perception_self applies.
Discriminating types of unempathic comments requires understanding the communicator's intent/stance, engaging perception of others.

Task involves trustworthiness ratings of other-race faces (Black > White contrast) which is a social cognition task measuring social processing (evaluating others).

Trustworthiness ratings index social valuation relevant to affiliation/attachment (trust as a basis for social bonds); the contrast relates to racial differences in trust, meeting criteria for an affiliation/attachment measure.
Ratings are based on facial cues (reception of facial communication); the Black > White face contrast assesses reception of social/facial information.
Task assesses perception and evaluation of others (trustworthiness of faces), not self-related processes or self-knowledge/agency.
The analyses probe representations of others (perceived trustworthiness and differentiation of Black vs White faces), directly mapping onto perception/understanding of others.
Contrast examines neural responses to Black > White faces predicting greater racial trust disparity — a social cognition process (evaluating others' trustworthiness).
Effects relate to trust differences across races, which index affiliation-related valuation and potential bonding; meets affiliation/attachment criteria.
Inference about trustworthiness is based on facial information (receptive facial communication), so this contrast measures social communication.
This analysis targets evaluation of others (race-based trust disparity) rather than self-perception or self-referential processing.
The contrast assesses how faces of others (Black vs White) are perceived and differentiated in trustworthiness, directly indexing perception of others.
Connectivity between affective/perceptual regions for Black > White faces predicting less racial trust disparity reflects social cognitive processing of others' faces.
Findings relate to neural coupling predictive of reduced racial trust disparity (trust-related/affiliative behavior), fitting affiliation/attachment constructs.
Connectivity when viewing faces informs reception of facial/social cues (communication); this analysis measures reception-related processes.
This connectivity analysis concerns perception/evaluation of others (race-based trust) rather than self-related processing.
Analysis examines how observers perceive and evaluate other-race faces (trustworthiness) via neural coupling — clear perception-of-others construct.
Analysis concerns racial differentiation disparity in perceived trust from faces (Black > White), a social cognitive process evaluating others.
Differentiation in perceived trust between racial groups pertains to affiliation-related evaluations (trust informing social bonds), meeting affiliation criteria.
Perceptual differentiation of faces with regard to perceived trust involves reception of facial communication cues, fitting social communication.
The analysis targets perceptions of others' trustworthiness and differentiation, not self-referential or self-perceptual processes.
Directly measures perception/understanding of others (differences in perceived trustworthiness across racial groups), satisfying perception-of-others criteria.
Contrast identifies increased activation with less differentiation disparity between Black and White faces in perceived trust — a social evaluative process.
Reduced differentiation in perceived trust relates to affiliation/attachment processes (trust underlies social connection), so inclusion applies.
This contrast taps reception of facial cues that inform perceived trust, thus measuring social communication (facial reception).
Findings concern perception of others' trustworthiness rather than self-related cognition or self-evaluation.
Analyzes neural responses underlying perception/differentiation of other-race faces' trustworthiness, matching perception-of-others construct.
Connectivity from dorsolateral prefrontal seed predictive of less differentiation disparity in perceived trust addresses cognitive mechanisms of social evaluation — social processing.
Reduced differentiation in perceived trust (linked to controlled processing) impacts affiliative evaluations and social bonding potential, so it aligns with affiliation/attachment.
Measures neural coupling during face-based evaluations (reception of facial cues informing trust), thus social communication is applicable.
This connectivity analysis concerns perception/evaluation of others, not self-related processes or self-knowledge.

The Meaning > Physical contrast isolates attending to the social/interpretive meaning of symbolic artifacts and activated mPFC and TPJ (social cognition regions). This directly measures social processing (participants interpret others' models and social meaning), so it meets criteria for social processing.

The contrast contrasts semantic/meaning-focused processing versus physical features; it does not specifically target affiliation, bonding, cooperation, or attachment processes. Although the task is social in context, the contrast does not measure affiliation/attachment.

The contrast probes interpretation of symbolic meaning rather than explicit communicative exchange (e.g., facial/expressive or interactive communication). It does not measure social communication per the defined subconstructs.
Meaning > Physical addresses interpretation of artifact meaning and engages social cognition, but it does not target self-related processing or agency/self-knowledge specifically.

While the contrast involves social meaning which may involve others, the contrast does not specifically measure representation or reasoning about others' mental states or actions (animacy/action/mental-state perception) as defined by this annotation.

The Physical > Meaning contrast emphasizes attention to physical/perceptual properties rather than social or interpretative meaning. Although the overall study is social, this specific contrast does not primarily measure social processing.
This contrast focuses on physical properties of artifacts and does not target affiliation, bonding, or relatedness processes.
No explicit communicative exchange or reception/production of social signals is manipulated by the Physical > Meaning contrast; it measures perceptual/physical processing instead.
The contrast does not probe self-related representations or agency/self-knowledge; it isolates perceptual/physical aspects of the stimuli.
The contrast does not specifically measure representations or reasoning about others' mental states or actions; it focuses on object physical properties.

Own > Other (in the meaning-related task) directly contrasts self-related versus other-related processing of socially meaningful artifacts; this contrast engages social-cognitive regions (precuneus, mPFC) and therefore measures social processing.

The Own > Other contrast indexes self-versus-other processing and agency/autobiographical memory, but it does not specifically manipulate or measure affiliation/attachment (e.g., bonding, cooperation).
The contrast distinguishes self versus other representations of artifacts rather than testing communicative reception/production; it does not meet criteria for social communication.

Own > Other contrasts stimuli associated with the participant versus others and elicited activations in regions linked to autobiographical memory and agency (precuneus), meeting the definition for perception/understanding of self (agency/self-knowledge).

Although the contrast involves others in the comparison, the specific contrast Own > Other emphasizes self-related processing and does not specifically index representations or reasoning about others' mental states (the Other>Own direction would be more direct for this annotation).

The interaction Own > Other × Collective > Individual implicates social-cognitive processes related to self/other and group (collective) representations and showed activations in social/affective regions (rostral ACC, IFG, insula). This contrast clearly measures social processing.

The interaction involves Collective > Individual and is linked in the study to individual differences in feelings of relatedness (affiliation) predicting insula variability. This directly taps affiliation/attachment-related processes (group bonding/relatedness).

While the interaction engages social and affective processing related to group membership, it does not specifically manipulate communicative exchange or reception/production of social signals as defined for social communication.

The interaction includes an Own > Other factor and thus indexes self-related processing (agency/autobiographical/self-knowledge) in the context of collective versus individual models, meeting the perception_self criteria.

Although the interaction contrasts self and other and collective versus individual contexts, the available contrasts emphasize self and group-related affective processing; there is no direct manipulation isolating representations or reasoning about others' mental states specifically, so this annotation is not assigned.

The contrast (toss - button press) in a virtual ball-toss game directly measures social interaction and responses to social reward; this meets the broad Social Processing construct (task is social and assesses processing of social interactions).

The high-frequency toss condition reflects increased positive social interaction (receiving more tosses) and is interpreted as a social reward that promotes affiliation/attachment; the task measures affiliation-related behavior.
The ball-toss game is an interactive social exchange (a form of social communication/cooperation), so the contrast captures aspects of social communicative interaction between players.

The reported activation in the precuneus is interpreted by the authors as representing positive self-image; the task contrast therefore involves self-related representation/awareness in the social context.
The task requires monitoring others’ tossing behavior (who tosses to whom) and thus involves perception/understanding of others’ actions/intentions; the contrast captures this component.
Right ventral striatum activation for the high-frequency toss condition reflects processing of social reward during an interpersonal interaction task, meeting Social Processing criteria.
Ventral striatal response to receiving more tosses indexes the rewarding value of positive social interaction and thus relates to affiliation/attachment processes.

While primarily a reward region, ventral striatum activation occurs in the context of a social exchange (ball-toss game), so the analysis relates to social communicative interaction/reward from reciprocal exchanges.
Authors report that ventral striatal activation covaried with individual interaction preference (a self-related trait), indicating a link to self-relevant valuation processes during the task.

The ventral striatum response is driven by others’ increased tosses to the participant, implicating processing of others’ actions and their social consequences; thus it relates to perception/understanding of others.

The contrast Social-Reg > Social-Look directly tests a socially-induced emotion regulation task (a psychotherapist instructs reappraisal). This is clearly a social-related task engaging social cognition processes and DMN regions, so it measures social processing broadly.

The Social-Reg task involves a psychotherapist delivering regulation instructions and the study explicitly measured attachment security (Adult Attachment Scale) and reported correlations with Social-Reg success, indicating relevance to affiliation/attachment processes.

Social-Reg entails communicative interaction (the therapist communicates reappraisal instructions) and thus involves social communication processes (reception of instructions/intent). The contrast isolates neural responses during this socially-mediated communication.

Social-Reg engages DMN nodes (precuneus, medial PFC) associated with self-referential processing and the study compares Social-Reg with Self-Reg, indicating involvement of self-related perception/processing during the task.

The task requires processing of another agent's (therapist's) intent and guidance and likely involves mentalizing/understanding others; activations include TPJ and other regions of mentalizing network, supporting inclusion.

This conjunction identifies areas common to Social-Reg and Self-Reg. Because it includes the Social-Reg condition, it reflects social-related task components and thus relates to social processing broadly.

The conjunction isolates shared regulation regions between social and self contexts and is not specific to affiliation/attachment processes; there is no contrast explicitly comparing attachment-related conditions (e.g., loved one vs stranger).

The conjunction captures general regulation-related activity common to Social- and Self-Reg and does not specifically index communicative exchanges or reception/production of social signals; thus it does not meet the social communication criterion.
Because the conjunction includes Self-Reg, common areas likely reflect self-referential/regulatory processes (DMN involvement). Thus this analysis captures perception/understanding of the self.

The conjunction emphasizes overlap between Social- and Self-Reg and therefore likely reflects domain-general regulation rather than processes specific to representing others' mental states; no specific other-focused contrast is isolated here.

This contrast isolates areas more strongly recruited by Social-Reg than Self-Reg, i.e., social-specific regulation processes; it directly probes social processing related to therapist-mediated regulation.

Areas specifically recruited by Social-Reg are likely to reflect aspects of social bonding/attachment given the therapist interaction and the study's reported links between attachment security and Social-Reg effectiveness; the contrast isolates social-affiliative-specific neural responses.

Social-specific activations (e.g., TPJ, precuneus) likely index communicative/mentalizing processes invoked by therapist instructions; this contrast captures neural substrates of social communication inherent to the Social-Reg condition.

This contrast emphasizes regions more active during Social-Reg than Self-Reg, so it is by definition not isolating self-perception processes (which would be more prominent in Self-Reg); thus it does not meet the Perception/Self criterion.

Social-Reg–specific activations are likely to reflect understanding of others (therapist intentions/advice) and mentalizing; regions implicated (TPJ, precuneus) support attribution of mental states to others, meeting the perception/others criterion.

This contrast isolates areas more strongly recruited by Self-Reg than Social-Reg; it focuses on self-regulatory processes rather than social task components, so it does not constitute a social-processing analysis.
The Self-Reg > Social-Reg contrast does not target affiliation or attachment processes; it isolates self-focused regulation and is not an affiliation/attachment measure.

The contrast highlights self-regulation-specific regions and not communicative exchanges or reception/production of social signals; therefore it does not meet the social communication inclusion criteria.

This contrast identifies regions preferentially recruited during Self-Reg relative to Social-Reg, directly indexing self-related perception/processing and self-referential regulatory mechanisms (meets Perception/Self criteria).

Because this contrast isolates Self-Reg–specific activity (greater than Social-Reg), it does not primarily probe processes for perceiving/understanding others and thus does not meet the Perception/Others criterion.

Contrast directly measures aggressive reactions to a provoking versus non-provoking opponent — a social interaction task assessing responses to social provocation (retaliation). Thus it indexes social processing.
The task examines aggression/retaliation and provocation, not positive affiliation, bonding, or attachment-related processes.
The contrast involves interaction with opponents and responses to social provocation, which entails exchange of socially relevant signals (competitive/provocative communication).
The contrast focuses on behavioral reaction to others’ provocation rather than on self-reflection, agency, or self-knowledge.
Detecting and responding to a provoking opponent requires representing others’ actions/intentions and emotional states (perception/understanding of others).
Contrast compares non-aggressive reaction to non-provoking opponent versus aggressive reaction to provoking opponent — a social interaction contrast relevant to social processing.
Contrast contrasts aggression levels and provocation; it does not assess affiliation, bonding or attachment.
Involves social interactions and responses to an opponent’s behavior; thus taps aspects of social communication/interaction.
Focus is on behavioral responses to others, not on self-evaluation or agency.
Requires understanding the opponent’s provocation and intentions, implicating perception of others.
Won > lost contrasts outcomes in interactions with opponents; these are social task outcomes and part of social processing.
Outcome contrasts (win vs loss) reflect competitive interaction and reward/loss processing, not affiliation or attachment.
Winning and losing against an opponent occur within social interaction/competition and involve social signaling and response, consistent with social communication.
This contrast indexes outcome processing rather than self-reflection or self-knowledge.
Win versus loss against an opponent involves representing others’ actions and competitive behavior, implicating perception of others.
Lost > won is an outcome contrast within social competition and reflects social processing related to interactions with an opponent.
This contrast concerns competitive outcomes and does not probe affiliation or attachment processes.
Losing vs winning in an interactive game entails social exchange and competitive signaling; therefore relevant to social communication.
Contrast pertains to outcome-related processing rather than self-awareness or agency judgments.
Losing relative to winning involves interpreting the opponent’s behavior and intentions, engaging perception/understanding of others.
Contrast compares wins against provoking versus non-provoking opponents, assessing responses in different social contexts — a social processing measure.
This analysis contrasts responses to different opponents in a competitive/aggressive context, not affiliation or bonding.
Differential responses to provoking vs non-provoking opponents reflect socially relevant exchanges and signaling between players.
Focus is on interaction/contextual opponent differences rather than introspective self-evaluation.
Contrasting responses to provoking vs non-provoking opponents depends on perceiving the opponent’s provocation and intentions, implicating perception of others.
Won against non-provoking > won against provoking compares social context effects on outcomes, reflecting social processing.
This contrast examines competitive outcomes across opponent types, not affiliation or attachment.
Different opponent behaviors (provoking vs non-provoking) alter social interaction and signaling, relevant to social communication.
This contrast does not probe self-knowledge or agency, but outcome differences in social contexts.
Distinguishing responses to non-provoking versus provoking opponents requires perceiving others’ behavior and intentions.
Lost against provoking > lost against non-provoking assesses social-context modulation of losing in opponent interaction — a social processing contrast.
This analysis concerns competitive/aggressive contexts (provocation effects on losing) rather than affiliation/attachment.
Differential loss responses depending on opponent provocation reflect social signaling and interaction dynamics, consistent with social communication.
Focus is on external social context and outcome, not self-reflective processes.
Understanding why a loss occurred against a provoking versus non-provoking opponent requires perceiving the opponent’s behavior/intentions.
Lost against non-provoking > lost against provoking contrasts social outcome processing across opponent types and is part of social processing.
This is an outcome/provocation contrast in a competitive setting, not assessing affiliation or attachment.
Contrasts of loss across opponent types reflect interactive social behavior and signaling, relevant to social communication.
This analysis addresses responses to opponents, not self-perception/agency.
Distinguishing losses against different opponent types involves perceiving others’ actions and provocation, implicating perception of others.
PARAMETRIC MODULATIONS likely index modulation of brain activity by degree of aggression/retaliation in social interactions — a social processing measure.
Parametric modulation of aggression reflects intensity of retaliatory behavior, not affiliation/attachment processes.
Parametric modulation by aggression levels arises from interacting with opponents and social provocation, implicating communicative/social exchange aspects.
These modulations concern aggression-related response intensity rather than introspective self-knowledge or agency.
Parametric changes tied to aggression relate to how subjects perceive and respond to opponents’ provocation, involving perception of others.
Retaliation independent of opponent is explicitly a social response measure (aggressive behavior in social interaction), so it indexes social processing.
This analysis isolates retaliation per se and does not probe affiliation or bonding.
Retaliation involves socially relevant signaling and behavioral exchange toward an opponent, aligning with social communication constructs.
Focus is on retaliatory behavior rather than self-reflective processes or self-knowledge.
Retaliation involves assessing others’ provocations and intentions, implicating perception/understanding of others.
Retaliation interacting with provoking opponent is a direct measure of social processing in response to provocation.
This targets aggressive retaliation in response to provocation, not affiliation or attachment.
Interaction with a provoking opponent entails socially meaningful exchanges and signals (provocation and response), fitting social communication.
This contrast concerns reactive behavior toward another rather than self-perception or agency.
Responding to a provoking opponent requires perceiving and interpreting the opponent’s provocation and intentions, so perception of others applies.
Retaliation interacting with non-provoking opponent still indexes social behavior and responses in interaction contexts and is therefore social processing.
The focus is retaliatory behavior even when opponent is non-provoking; not assessing affiliation or attachment.
Even retaliation with a non-provoking opponent involves social signals and interactional dynamics relevant to social communication.
This analysis addresses behavioral retaliation rather than introspective self-related processes.
Retaliation toward a non-provoking opponent still involves perceiving and interpreting the opponent’s behavior and intentions (or absence thereof).
Won is an outcome during interactions with an opponent; as part of the interactive paradigm it indexes social processing related to competitive outcomes.
Simple win outcomes reflect competition/reward rather than affiliation or bonding.
Winning in an opponent-based task occurs within social interaction/competition and involves social signaling aspects.
This contrast indexes outcome-related processing not self-reflection or agency.
Winning against an opponent involves representing the opponent’s behavior and actions, implicating perception of others.
Won against provoking opponent isolates outcomes in a provocation context and thus reflects social processing in interactions.
This contrast focuses on competitive outcome under provocation rather than bonding or attachment measures.
Winning against a provoking opponent involves responding to social provocation and exchange, relevant to social communication.
This is outcome/interaction-focused rather than probing self-knowledge or agency.
Outcomes against a provoking opponent depend on perceiving and interpreting the opponent’s provocative behavior, implicating perception of others.
Won against non-provoking opponent is an interactive outcome measure in the social task and thus reflects social processing.
This contrast reflects competitive outcome with a non-provoking opponent and does not target affiliation or attachment.
Winning against a non-provoking opponent still occurs within social interaction and involves social signaling relevant to social communication.
Focus is on outcome in an opponent interaction rather than self-reflection or agency.
This contrast involves representing the opponent’s actions/behavior even when non-provoking, implicating perception of others.
