Contrast compares Social scenarios requiring contextual adjustment vs Physical scenarios without contextual adjustments (SocAdj > PhyConf). This is a canonical ToM / social cognition contrast and thus measures social processing (mental state inference and contextual adjustment).

The contrast examines theory-of-mind (mental state inference and contextual adjustment) rather than affiliation, bonding, or attachment processes; no measures of close relationships or attachment are present.

The task manipulates mental-state inferences and contextual adjustments (ToM) rather than communicative behaviors (facial/expressive or non‑facial communication); therefore it does not target social communication per the annotation definition.
The contrast targets understanding of others' mental states and context-driven adjustments, not self-referential processing or self‑knowledge/agency.
The contrast isolates social/ToM processing (mental-state inference and contextual adjustments) versus physical inference, directly probing understanding and reasoning about others' mental states.
Same contrast as analysis_0 (SocAdj > PhyConf) but during the response period; still a classic social/ToM contrast measuring social processing.
Focus is on ToM/contextual adjustment, not affiliation or attachment processes.
Contrast does not assess communicative reception or production; it assesses mental-state inference and contextual adjustment.
No self-related judgments or self‑referential processing are involved in this contrast.
During the response period this contrast continues to probe inference about others' mental states and contextual modulation of those inferences, meeting the perception_of_others criteria.
Manipulation contrast (Soc > Phy) directly compares social (mental-state) vs physical inferences, a core social processing measure.
Contrast contrasts social vs physical inference broadly (ToM) but does not probe affiliation, bonding, or relationship-specific constructs.
The Soc > Phy contrast measures mental-state inference rather than communicative behaviors or exchange of social signals specifically.
The contrast is about inferring others' states rather than self-perception or self-knowledge.
Soc > Phy isolates processing related to understanding others' mental states (classic ToM contrast), satisfying perception_others inclusion criteria.
Manipulation (Soc > Phy) at Time-point 2 compares social vs physical inference and therefore indexes social processing.
No measures of affiliation/attachment or relationship-specific processing are present in this contrast.
The contrast targets ToM/mental-state inference rather than communication per se.
This contrast does not involve self-referential judgments or self-knowledge.
Soc > Phy at Time-point 2 probes understanding of others' mental states, meeting the perception_others criteria.
Manipulation (Soc > Phy) during the response period contrasts social vs physical inference, indicating social processing.
Contrast does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs (no relationship-specific tasks).
Contrast assesses mental-state inference rather than communicative behaviors or reception/production of social signals.
No self-referential processing is targeted in this contrast.
Response-period Soc > Phy continues to probe understanding and reasoning about others' mental states (perception_others).

Manipulation (Adj > Conf) indexes contextual adjustments of inferences. Within this REMICS ToM task these adjustments are a core component of social/ToM processing (the study explicitly investigates contextual adjustments in ToM), so this contrast is relevant to social processing.
Adj > Conf assesses contextual adjustment demands rather than affiliation/attachment or bonding-related processes.
Adj > Conf contrasts adjustment demands and does not target communicative reception/production specifically.
The contrast reflects contextual adjustment of inferences rather than self-referential processing or self-knowledge.

Because the study's Adj > Conf manipulation is applied in the context of ToM (contextual adjustments of mental-state inferences), this contrast probes processes related to understanding and adjusting inferences about others, meeting perception_others criteria.
Adj > Conf during the response period captures contextual adjustment demands within the REMICS ToM task and thus indexes social processing related to ToM adjustments.
This contrast does not probe attachment or close-relationship constructs.
The contrast pertains to contextual adjustment of inferences rather than communicative behaviors.
No self-referential judgments are targeted by Adj > Conf in this task.
Adj > Conf in the REMICS task relates to adjusting mental-state inferences about others; therefore it meets the perception_others inclusion criteria.
Condition SocAdj is a social scenario requiring contextual adjustment (explicitly social), so it indexes social processing.
SocAdj refers to social mental-state inferences with contextual adjustments, not affiliation/attachment or bonding constructs.
This condition involves ToM/contextual adjustment rather than communicative signal processing or production.
The condition targets inference about others rather than self-related processes.
SocAdj explicitly involves inferring and adjusting inferences about others' mental states, satisfying perception_others criteria.
Condition SocConf is a social scenario (social inference without contextual adjustment); it measures social processing related to mental-state inference.
SocConf involves ToM inferences but not affiliation/attachment constructs or relationship-specific measures.
This condition focuses on mental-state inference rather than communicative behavior or signal processing.
No self-referential or self-knowledge judgments are targeted by SocConf.
SocConf involves representing/understanding others' mental states (ToM), meeting perception_others inclusion criteria.
Condition PhyAdj is a physical scenario with contextual adjustment; it does not index social processing or mental-state inference (it is a physical inference condition).
PhyAdj is a physical inference condition and does not probe affiliation or attachment.
PhyAdj does not involve communicative reception or production; it is a physical inference condition.
PhyAdj concerns physical inference and adjustment demands, not self-referential processing.
PhyAdj involves physical inferences/adjustments, not understanding others' mental states, so it does not meet perception_others criteria.

Contrast Angry > Joyful compares viewing actors in angry vs joyful social situations, directly measuring social processing of others' emotional states and social context.
The task manipulates emotional context (anger vs joy) during observed actions; it does not assess affiliation, attachment, or relationship/bonding constructs.
The contrast involves recognition/processing of others' emotional expressions and social signals (angry vs joyful), which maps onto reception of social/affective communication.
The contrast addresses perception of others and situational emotion, not self-related judgments, agency, or self-knowledge.
Angry vs joyful viewing requires representing and understanding others' emotional states and actions, matching the Action/Emotion perception subconstructs.
Grasping > Faces contrasts action-oriented social stimuli with face stimuli; both are social in nature and the contrast probes social perceptual processing.
This contrast isolates action perception vs face viewing and does not probe affiliation or attachment constructs.
The contrast emphasizes action (grasping) over facial communication; it does not primarily target reception/production of facial or other communicative signals.
The contrast concerns perception of observed actions/people rather than self-related processing.
Grasping stimuli probe action perception/understanding of others' actions (an Action Perception subconstruct), so this fits Perception of Others.
Faces > Grasping contrasts facial stimuli (social communicative signals) with actions; it addresses social perceptual processing of others.
The faces vs actions contrast does not investigate affiliation/attachment or close relationships.
Faces > Grasping emphasizes reception of facial communication/affective expression, directly mapping onto social communication (reception of facial signals).
This contrast focuses on perceiving others' faces rather than self-related processing.
Face perception involves understanding others' emotional states and traits (Perception of Others), so this contrast qualifies.
An interaction between grasping and neutral grasping examines how social/emotional context modulates perception of actions, a social processing question.
The interaction contrasts action conditions (emotional vs neutral) and does not assess affiliation or attachment.
This interaction targets differences in action processing (emotional modulation) rather than exchange of communicative signals like facial communication per se.
The analysis focuses on perception of others' actions under different contexts, not self-related judgments or agency.
The interaction probes how emotional/neutral context alters action perception of others (Action Perception subconstruct), fitting Perception of Others.
ROI/PPI Angry > Joyful run examines connectivity while viewing angry vs joyful social scenes; this directly targets social processing of others' emotions and context.
The PPI analysis contrasts emotional contexts but does not test affiliation or attachment constructs.
Connectivity differences during angry vs joyful contexts reflect processing of others' affective signals and social meaning, consistent with social communication (reception of affective cues).
This connectivity analysis focuses on social/emotional perception of others rather than self-related processing.
PPI contrasts during angry vs joyful runs probe neural representations of others' emotional states and action-related processing (Perception of Others).
Angry grasping > Joyful grasping contrasts actions performed in different emotional contexts, directly addressing social processing of others' affective actions.
This contrast manipulates emotional context of actions but does not probe affiliation/attachment or bonding measures.
Differences between angry and joyful grasping reflect reception of affective signals conveyed through actions (non-facial social communication), fitting the social communication construct.
The contrast assesses perception of others' actions in emotional contexts rather than self-related processes.
This contrast targets action perception and understanding of others' emotional states via their actions (Action Perception / Understanding Others).
PPI seed in right insula assesses connectivity changes related to processing angry vs joyful social scenes; insula–STG interactions are central to social-emotional processing described in the study.
The connectivity analysis examines emotion-related modulation of networks, not affiliation/attachment constructs.

Right insula connectivity changes with STG in emotional contexts reflect processing of socially relevant affective signals and their communication; this maps onto social communication (reception of social/affective cues).
Although insula is involved in interoception, the analysis as described focuses on interpersonal/affective processing rather than explicit self-judgments or self-knowledge.
Insula–STG effective/functional connectivity modulation by anger concerns representation and understanding of others' emotional/action-related signals (Perception of Others).

Contrast compares Prisoner’s Dilemma (cooperation) vs Ultimatum Game (fairness) — both are social decision-making tasks probing social processing. The study explicitly manipulates sociality and measures neural responses, so the contrast measures social processing.
Prisoner’s Dilemma is a cooperation task (affiliation/attachment-related construct); the contrast contrasts social interaction contexts and thus measures affiliation/attachment-related processes.
Cooperation and bargaining tasks involve exchange of socially relevant information and coordination; PD vs UG contrasts probe aspects of social communication relevant to decision-making.
Economic decision tasks (cooperation/competition) require self-related evaluation and monitoring (agency/choice); the contrast involves self-related decision processes during social interactions.
PD and UG require reasoning about others’ intentions and outcomes (theory of mind/assessment of others); the contrast therefore probes perception and understanding of others.
Contrast compares Ultimatum Game vs Prisoner’s Dilemma — both social decision tasks; study manipulates sociality and measures neural responses, so this contrast measures social processing.
Ultimatum Game involves fairness and social evaluation relevant to affiliation/attachment processes; contrast assesses affiliation-related processing between game contexts.
UG involves negotiation and signaling fairness; contrast probes communicative and interactive aspects of social decision-making.
UG decisions require self-evaluation of offers and fairness considerations (self-related decision processes), so the contrast engages perception/understanding of self.
UG requires inference about others’ fairness intentions and likely responses, engaging perception/understanding of others; contrast probes these processes.

High vs Low sociality contrast directly manipulates social context (acquaintance vs random) and measures changes in neural activation/connectivity during social decision-making — clearly measures social processing.
Contrast manipulates degree of social bond (acquaintance vs stranger), directly probing affiliation/attachment-related processes and their neural correlates.
Differences between high and low sociality conditions affect interpersonal signaling and interaction dynamics; contrast assesses communication-related aspects of social interaction.
Sociality manipulation likely alters self-related processing during decisions (e.g., self-monitoring in front of acquaintance), so contrast engages perception/understanding of self.
High vs Low sociality requires assessing the acquaintance’s intentions and mental states more than a stranger, engaging perception/understanding of others; contrast measures these processes.
Low vs High sociality contrast still addresses social context differences in decision-making; although reversed, it measures social processing related to reduced social bonds or anonymity effects.
Contrasting low sociality (random individual) against high sociality probes reduced affiliation/attachment processes and their neural signatures.
Low vs High sociality comparisons reflect changes in interpersonal signaling and communicative dynamics when social bond is weak; thus the contrast measures social communication.
Decisions in low sociality versus high sociality contexts engage self-related evaluations differently (e.g., anonymity effects), so the contrast involves perception/understanding of self.
Comparing low to high sociality involves reduced need to infer others’ intentions; the contrast therefore probes perception and understanding of others under decreased social connection.

The contrast 'S-performance' indexes participants' own ability estimates within a cooperative/competitive social task. This is clearly a social processing measure (self-other estimation in social interaction), meeting I1.

The study manipulates cooperation and competition and examines how interacting with high/low performers affects own estimates — a task directly probing affiliation/attachment-related processes (cooperation/competition), satisfying I1.

Cooperation and competition paradigms examine exchange and comparison of socially relevant information between agents; the S-performance contrast arises from such a social-interaction task and therefore meets the social communication inclusion criterion (I1).

'S-performance' explicitly tracks one's own performance and self-estimates (perigenual ACC tracking own performance as described), so it directly measures perception/understanding of self, meeting I1.

The S-performance contrast specifically indexes participants' own performance/estimates; although the study discusses self–other mergence, this contrast does not primarily measure perception/understanding of others and thus does not meet the inclusion criterion for perception of others.
The contrast 'O-performance' indexes others' performance and how it influences self/other estimates in cooperative/competitive contexts — a social processing measure, satisfying I1.
O-performance is derived from cooperation/competition interactions and assesses social comparison and influence between agents, directly mapping onto affiliation/attachment constructs (I1).
The O-performance contrast stems from a task involving exchange and evaluation of social information (cooperation/competition), fitting the social communication inclusion example (I1).

The O-performance contrast primarily indexes others' performance/estimates; while the study reports self–other integration, this contrast does not primarily measure self-perception and therefore does not meet the perception_self inclusion criterion.

O-performance directly measures others' performance and representations (dorsomedial frontal area 9 tracks others' performances), so it clearly measures perception/understanding of others, satisfying I1.

The analysis examines neural responses during a social task (one-shot prisoner's dilemma) contrasting mutual cooperation (CC) with other outcomes; this directly measures social processing.

The contrast involves participants’ own choices and outcomes (mutual cooperation vs others), engaging self-related evaluation processes during social decision outcomes.
Mutual cooperation vs other outcomes necessarily involves representing the partner’s choice and intentions (understanding others), so this analysis taps perception/understanding of others.
This contrast (A vs CC) is from the same prisoner's dilemma social task and measures social processing related to non-cooperation versus cooperation.

The contrast concerns interpersonal interaction outcomes in a cooperation paradigm, engaging social communicative processes.
Contrasting outcomes where the participant does not mutually cooperate vs mutual cooperation engages self-evaluative processing about one’s own choices and outcomes.
This contrast implicates processing of the partner’s behavior (cooperative vs non-cooperative), thus involving perception and understanding of others.
This analysis examines main effects of context (Gain vs Loss) during the social cooperation task, so it relates to social processing under different motivational contexts.
Context modulation (gain vs loss) of responses during cooperation pertains to affiliative/attachment processes modulated by reward/punishment context.
Context effects on cooperative interactions influence interpersonal information exchange and are relevant to social communication constructs.
Gain vs loss contexts alter participants’ evaluation of their own outcomes and decisions in the social task, engaging self-related processing.
Contextual differences (gain vs loss) change how participants interpret partners’ choices and intentions, implicating perception/understanding of others.

Loss versus gain context modulates cooperative/affiliative responses and thus is relevant to affiliation and attachment processes.
Contextual modulation of cooperative interactions affects interpersonal dynamics relevant to social communication.
Loss vs gain context changes self-evaluative and affective responses to cooperation outcomes, engaging self-perception processes.
Context effects will influence how participants perceive and infer partners’ behavior under loss vs gain, involving perception of others.

The contrast probes contextual modulation of cooperative interaction signals, relevant to social communication during interpersonal exchange.
The interaction assesses how self-related reward responses to mutual cooperation vary by context, implicating self-perception and evaluation.
The interaction reflects changes in how participants represent partners’ cooperative behavior across contexts, involving perception of others.
This interaction ((CC-A) Loss - (CC-A) Gain) also tests contextual modulation of social cooperation-related neural responses and thus measures social processing.
The contrast examines how affiliative neural responses to mutual cooperation are relatively stronger in loss than gain context, relevant to attachment/affiliation.
Contextual differences in cooperative outcome processing affect interpersonal exchange and are within the scope of social communication.
This interaction measures how participants’ self-related processing of cooperative outcomes differ by context, implicating self-perception mechanisms.
The contrast captures context-dependent representations of partners’ cooperative behavior, thus involving perception/understanding of others.

The contrast compares mentalizing with dissimilar versus similar others, which is a social cognition task (mentalizing/understanding others). This directly measures social processing related to understanding others' mental states and how similarity affects social responses, so it meets the social processing definition.

The study manipulated perceived similarity between participant and target and reported effects on affiliation ratings and affiliation-related behavior. Although the contrast is Dissimilar > Similar, the task and manipulation are directly relevant to affiliation/attachment constructs (social bonding and affiliation biases), so this analysis is relevant to affiliation/attachment.

The contrast concerns mentalizing (inferring others' thoughts/beliefs) rather than exchange of social signals or communicative behavior (facial/expressive reception/production). It does not target social communication per se, so it does not meet the Social Communication inclusion criterion.

The task focuses on representing others' mental states (mentalizing with similar vs dissimilar targets) rather than on self-awareness, self-evaluation, or judgments about one's own traits/states. Thus it does not meet Perception/Self inclusion criteria.

Mentalizing is precisely the Perception and Understanding of Others (understanding mental states). This contrast directly probes differences in representing others (similar vs dissimilar), fitting the 'Understanding Mental States' subconstruct.

The working memory maintenance analysis was performed within a study that explicitly manipulated social context (competitive vs noncompetitive learning). Even if the maintenance contrast may be pooled across conditions, the task context is social and the reported activations (mPFC, precuneus/PCC) are linked to social processes, so this analysis relates to social processing.

The experiment manipulated competition (an affiliation/attachment-related social context). Maintenance-related effects were observed in regions implicated in social interaction and task distraction during the competitive task, so the analysis is relevant to affiliation/attachment processes tied to competition.

Competition and social comparison are examples cited under the social_communication inclusion criteria. The maintenance analysis occurs within that competitive social task context and engages regions (mPFC/precuneus) linked to social cognition, supporting inclusion.

mPFC engagement and social-referencing mentioned in the study implicate self-related processing during task periods; the maintenance analysis therefore relates to perception/understanding of the self within the social task context.

Competitive contexts require assessing others and social comparison; regions reported (precuneus/PCC) are linked to off-task thoughts and social cognition about others, making this analysis relevant to perception/understanding of others.

This analysis is a parametric modulator of performance within the no-competition (noncompetitive) condition. Because it is restricted to the noncompetitive environment, it does not directly measure social processing or social-context effects.

Affiliation/attachment is operationalized here via competition/cooperation contrasts. A parametric modulator within the no-competition condition does not probe affiliation or attachment processes tied to social competition.

Social communication constructs (e.g., competition/cooperation) are not being engaged in this analysis because it is limited to the noncompetitive condition; therefore it does not measure social communication.
This analysis examines performance modulation within the noncompetitive condition and does not specifically assess self-related social processing or self-referential responses in a social context.
Because the contrast is confined to the no-competition environment, it does not probe representations of others or social-cognitive evaluation of others that are tied to competitive social contexts.
This analysis is a performance parametric modulator within the competition condition, directly engaging the social manipulation (competition) and therefore measures social processing.
The analysis explicitly examines performance-related modulation during competition (an affiliation/attachment-related social context), meeting the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.
Competition is an example task under social_communication inclusion; this analysis probes neural responses during a competitive social interaction, so it maps onto social communication constructs.
Competition invokes self-referential and performance-evaluation processes (mPFC involvement noted), so a parametric effect during competition is relevant to perception/understanding of the self.
Competing requires representing others' actions/states; performance-related modulation during competition likely engages processes for understanding others (social comparison), supporting inclusion.

Event-related feedback analyses highlighted greater activation in mPFC and precuneus/PCC while competing; feedback during competition is a direct social-context manipulation and measures social processing.
Feedback in a competitive social environment relates to affiliation/attachment-like processes (social evaluation, motivation to win), so this analysis maps onto affiliation/attachment.
Feedback during competition conveys socially relevant information and engages social-referencing processes; thus this event-related feedback analysis probes social communication-relevant processing.
mPFC activation during feedback while competing implicates self-referential and social-evaluative processes, so this analysis is relevant to perception/understanding of the self.

Feedback in a competitive context involves assessing others and social outcomes; activations in precuneus/PCC and relations to later recall suggest engagement of processes related to representing others, fitting perception/others.
The Competition > No competition contrast directly tests social-context effects (competition versus noncompetition) and therefore measures social processing.
This contrast directly indexes competitive social contexts (an affiliation/attachment-related construct) by comparing competition to no competition.
Competition vs no competition is an explicit social communication/comparison contrast; thus it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.
Comparing competition to no competition implicates self-referential processing (e.g., social-evaluative responses), justifying inclusion for perception/understanding of self.
Competition inherently involves considering others (opponents, social comparison); the contrast tests neural responses tied to understanding others in social contexts.
The No Competition > Competition contrast is the inverse social-context comparison and therefore directly pertains to social processing by comparing social and non-social conditions.
This contrast evaluates differences between noncompetitive and competitive social contexts, which is relevant to affiliation/attachment constructs (competition/social comparison).
No Competition > Competition contrasts social contexts and thus engages social communication/comparison processes; it meets the inclusion examples (competition/social comparison).

Differences favoring no-competition over competition likely reflect reduced social-evaluative/self-referential processing; the contrast therefore informs perception/understanding of self in social contexts.
Comparing noncompetitive to competitive contexts sheds light on how representations of others and social comparison processes differ across conditions, supporting inclusion.

Table 1 documents ROIs and voxel counts for face-responsive regions used in analyses that involved attending to facial aspects (age, emotional valence). This is part of a study explicitly measuring social processing of faces, so it meets the criteria for Social Processing.

The table reports ROI extents and peak coordinates but does not involve any measures of affiliation or attachment (no tasks or contrasts involving relationship, bonding, loved one vs stranger, cooperation, etc.).

The study measures reception of facial communication (emotional expressions and age cues) in face-responsive cortex; the table supports those analyses by listing ROIs, so it is relevant to Social Communication (receptive facial communication).
The table and associated analyses concern perception of facial features and emotions in others, not self-referential processing or judgments about one’s own traits or internal states.
The ROIs and voxel counts support analyses that decode others’ facial attributes (age, emotional valence), which are directly measures of Perception and Understanding of Others.
This contrast (negative vs positive, averaged over tasks) directly probes representation of emotional valence in faces — a core social processing function, satisfying the social processing criteria.

The contrast compares emotional valence (negative vs positive) of faces and does not assess affiliation or attachment-related constructs (no measures of bonding, relationships, loved one vs stranger, cooperation, etc.).
Decoding emotional valence from facial stimuli is an instance of receptive facial communication (recognizing affect), meeting the Social Communication inclusion criteria.
The contrast concerns perception of others’ emotional expressions, not self-related judgments or self-awareness processes.
Negative vs positive valence contrasts measure representation of others’ emotional states, directly mapping onto Perception and Understanding of Others.
Emotion task contrast (negative vs positive) explicitly measures how emotional valence of faces is represented while attending to emotion — clearly a social processing operation.
The emotion task contrasts valence of facial expressions but does not assess affiliation or attachment constructs (no relational/bonding measures).
This contrast assesses recognition/representation of facial emotion (receptive facial communication), directly matching the Social Communication construct.
The contrast targets perception of others’ emotional valence rather than self-related processing or judgments.
Decoding emotional valence in the emotion task is a measure of understanding others’ emotional states and therefore fits Perception and Understanding of Others.

Although labeled as the age task, the contrast reported (negative vs positive) examines emotional valence responses to faces when attention is directed to age — still probing social processing of facial emotion representations and attentional modulation, meeting Social Processing criteria.
The age task contrast isolates emotional valence but does not probe affiliation or attachment constructs (no relationship/bonding measures).
Even when attention is directed to age, the negative vs positive contrast assesses representation of facial emotion (receptive facial communication), fitting the Social Communication construct.
The contrast concerns perception of others’ facial attributes/emotions rather than self-referential processes.
The analysis examines how others’ emotional valence is represented (even when unattended during the age task), aligning with Perception and Understanding of Others.

The task involves social interaction (telling jokes, eliciting listener responses) and the contrast directly compares self vs other social actions, so it measures social processing broadly (self/other social distinction).
The task examines humor and contingency of listeners' responses, not affiliation, bonding, or attachment processes (no measures of close relationships, kinship, cooperation/competition).

The paradigm requires production of communicative acts (telling jokes) and reception of communicative signals (laughter). The SELF vs OTHER contrast involves communicative exchange, fitting social communication.

The contrast is explicitly SELF minus OTHER, directly indexing self-related processing (agency/self-relevance) and the abstract notes mPFC self-related activation — it measures perception/understanding of self.

Although the contrast emphasizes SELF, it directly contrasts against OTHER conditions (others' actions/responses), and the task includes perceiving listeners' laughter (auditory processing of others), so it involves perception of others.
This contrast examines listener responses (Group vs No Laughter) across self/other conditions and therefore probes social processing of others' responses and their affective consequences.
The contrast isolates responses to laughter magnitude but does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding or relationship-specific measures).
The contrast indexes reception of communicative signals (group laughter vs none), which is a form of social communication (receptive non-facial communication).

This contrast examines listener responses across both self and other conditions combined (group vs no laughter) and does not isolate self-related processing; therefore it does not specifically measure perception/understanding of the self.
The contrast directly manipulates listener responses (laughter), engaging auditory/sensory processing of others' reactions and thus measures perception/understanding of others.
Single laughter vs no laughter contrasts examine social responses from listeners, engaging social perception and affective reactions—so it measures social processing.
The contrast concerns presence of single laugh vs none; it does not target affiliation or attachment constructs or relationship-based measures.
This contrast concerns reception of an auditory communicative signal (single laughter) and thus indexes receptive non-facial social communication.
As with the group vs no contrast, this analysis pools self and other conditions and focuses on listener responses, not on self-related processing specifically.
The contrast isolates perception of another's response (single laughter), engaging auditory cortex and processes for perceiving others' reactions, meeting criteria for perception of others.
Comparing group vs single laughter examines graded social responses from others and associated processing, so it addresses social processing of communicative outcomes.
This contrast differentiates magnitudes of laughter but does not assess affiliation/attachment-specific constructs like bonds or relationship status.
The contrast differentiates types/intensity of communicative signals (group vs single laughter), fitting the social communication construct (reception of non-facial communication).
This contrast focuses on differences in others' responses (group vs single) independent of self vs other identity, so it does not specifically index self-perception.
Directly contrasts different magnitudes of others' laughter, engaging perception and evaluation of others' responses (auditory/social), thus measuring perception of others.

This interaction contrast [(SELF_Group - SELF_No) - (OTHER_Group - OTHER_No)] explicitly tests action-outcome contingency in social interactions (self vs other), addressing social processing and contingency signaling.
Although social, the contrast targets contingency and reward processing rather than affiliation/attachment or bonding measures.

Action-outcome contingency here depends on communicative exchange (producing jokes and perceiving laughter); the interaction tests how communicative responses to one's actions are processed, consistent with social communication.

This contrast isolates how self-generated actions and consequent others' responses produce contingency signals (self-specific), explicitly measuring self-related processing and agency in social outcomes (supports mPFC involvement).

The interaction includes processing of others' responses as the outcome (Group vs No) and how those are differentially linked to self vs other actions, thus involving perception and understanding of others' responses.
This interaction for single-laugh contingency tests social action-outcome contingency and thus measures social processing related to perceiving and evaluating others' responses to actions.
The contrast focuses on contingency for single laughter and reward processing rather than affiliation/attachment constructs.
The contrast concerns communicative outcomes (single laughter) in response to actions, indexing production-reception dynamics in social communication.
This contrast measures self-specific contingency (self single-laugh outcome vs other single-laugh outcome), indexing self-related processing and agency in social outcome evaluation.
It examines perception of others' responses (single laughter) and how those are contingent on self vs other actions, therefore measuring perception of others.

Physio-physiological interaction seeded on right auditory cortex and mPFC examines integration of self-related and sensory signals during social interactions, addressing social processing of communicative outcomes.
The PPI examines connectivity between mPFC and auditory regions related to contingency/integration, not measures of affiliation or attachment.

The analysis probes interactions between sensory regions processing others' communicative signals (auditory cortex) and mPFC (self-related processing), directly relating to social communication (reception and integration of non-facial communicative cues).
Seeding on mPFC (associated with self-processing) investigates how self-related signals modulate connectivity, therefore directly addressing perception/understanding of self in the network context.
Seeding on auditory cortex (processing others' laughter) assesses how representations of others' responses interact with self-related signals, thus measuring perception of others in network dynamics.
Left-auditory-cortex/mPFC PPI assesses integration of self-related and sensory signals in processing others' responses, so it addresses social processing broadly.
This connectivity analysis focuses on contingency/integration of sensory and self signals, not on affiliation or attachment constructs.

The analysis targets interactions between sensory processing of communicative signals (auditory cortex) and mPFC (self-related), which is central to social communication (reception/integration of non-facial cues).
Because mPFC is explicitly included and the analysis examines how that self-related region interacts with auditory cortex, it measures self-related processing in network context.
Seeding on auditory cortex examines processing of others' laughter and its integration with self-related signals, thus indexing perception of others in network dynamics.

The Select > content contrast involves a social-related task (decisions about selecting articles, within a study about sharing and social valuation). It measures social processing broadly (self-reflection and social valuation tied to selection decisions).

Select > content centers on choosing articles to read personally rather than interacting or bonding with others; the task does not specifically assess affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, cooperation, loved one vs stranger).
Selecting articles for personal consumption is not primarily an act of exchanging information with others; the contrast does not target communicative behavior.
The study reports self-related processing associated with selection decisions; Select > content captures self-related evaluation and reflection about reading preferences.
Select > content focuses on personal selection rather than perspective-taking about others; the contrast does not principally measure perception/understanding of others.

Share > content explicitly involves decisions about sharing with other people and is clearly a social task; it measures social processing broadly (value, self-reflection, perspective-taking in sharing).
Sharing with others and the study emphasis on connecting with other people taps affiliative motives and bonding-related processes; the contrast measures behaviors relevant to affiliation/attachment.
Sharing articles is an act of social communication (exchange of information); the Share > content contrast measures communicative behavior and its neural correlates.
The abstract reports self-related processing associated with sharing decisions; Share > content elicits self-reflection and self-related value processes.
The study indicates engagement of regions involved in taking the perspective of others during sharing; Share > content measures perception/understanding of others (considering recipients).
Share > select directly contrasts sharing versus selecting, emphasizing social facets of sharing; it measures social processing (greater engagement when sharing).
Share > select highlights increased activity when sharing (connecting with others) compared to selecting for self, tapping affiliative/attachment-related processes as discussed in the study.
This contrast isolates the communicative act (sharing) relative to non-communicative selection; it therefore measures social communication processes.
The authors report greater self-related processing when sharing compared with selecting, so this contrast measures self-perception and self-reflection differences.
Share > select shows increased engagement of regions involved in perspective-taking for others when sharing vs selecting, indicating measurement of perception/understanding of others.

The Select (modulation by preference) analysis examines how neural activity during selection decisions (a social-context task in this study) is modulated by preference ratings; it remains within social processing scope.

Modulation of Select-related activity by preference pertains to individual valuation and self-reflection rather than explicit measures of affiliation/attachment; the analysis does not target affiliative bonding.
The Select (preference-modulation) analysis concerns personal selection and preference, not communicative exchange; it does not measure social communication per se.

The modulation analysis reports that activity scaled with preferences for selecting articles; given the study's findings linking selection to self-related processing, this analysis measures perception/understanding of self.

Preference-related modulation during selection pertains to individual preferences and self-evaluation rather than representing others' states; this analysis does not primarily measure perception of others.

The Share (modulation by preference) analysis tests how neural activity during sharing decisions is modulated by preferences; because sharing is inherently social in this study, it measures social processing broadly.
Preference-related modulation of sharing-related activity taps into the value of connecting with others and affiliative motivation emphasized in the study, so it relates to affiliation/attachment.
Modulation of neural activity when deciding to share (based on preference) pertains to communicative behavior—sharing information with others—so it measures social communication processes.
The study reports self-related processing during sharing; the modulation analysis shows activity scaling with preferences for sharing, reflecting self-related evaluation.
Sharing decisions involve considering recipients and taking others' perspectives; the preference-modulated sharing activity therefore measures perception/understanding of others.

The 'Gave $0' condition in the Trust Game is a social interaction reflecting reciprocity/response to a partner; it involves perceiving and responding to social cues and is part of social processing. Matches I1 (social task) and I2 (contrast measures social processing).

Refusing to give (Gave $0) in a cooperative exchange taps affiliation/attachment-relevant processes (cooperation, bonding, social learning about partners) within the Trust Game context and thus measures affiliation/attachment. Matches I1 and I2.

The decision to give or not in the Trust Game constitutes a form of social exchange/communication (cooperation/competition signals). The Gave $0 condition reflects communicative social behavior, meeting I1 and I2.

Choosing to give nothing involves self-referential decision-making (agency, self-monitoring, moral judgments). The task and contrast probe self-related processes as noted in the study (self-referential engagement), satisfying I1 and I2.
The Gave $0 choice is made with consideration of the partner’s actions/intentions (evaluating others’ behavior), so it involves perception/understanding of others and meets I1 and I2.
'Gave $1.5 After Receiving' is a reciprocal/prosocial response in the Trust Game, inherently social and involving processing of social feedback; it therefore indexes social processing (I1,I2).
Giving after receiving reflects cooperative/affiliative behavior and social bonding tendencies in the Trust Game, so the contrast measures affiliation/attachment (I1,I2).
Returning funds after being trusted is a communicative social act (signals cooperation/reciprocity); this contrast captures social communication aspects of the interaction (I1,I2).
Deciding to reciprocate after receiving engages self-referential processes (moral decision-making, agency), consistent with perception/self understanding (I1,I2).
Reciprocation depends on evaluating the partner’s prior action and intentions; this contrast measures perception/understanding of others (I1,I2).

'Gave $1.5X After Not Receiving' captures behavior in response to a social slight (not receiving) and subsequent choice to give; this is a social process reflecting reciprocity and social decision-making (I1,I2).
This condition probes affiliative vs non-affiliative responses following a partner’s non-cooperation, relevant to attachment and relationship-building dynamics in social exchange (I1,I2).
Choosing to give after not receiving still conveys social signals (e.g., forgiveness, reputational concerns); the contrast indexes communicative aspects of the interaction (I1,I2).
The decision to give after being not trusted involves self-reflection, moral choice, and agency (self-referential processes), so it meets perception/self criteria (I1,I2).
This choice requires evaluating the partner’s past action and intentions and thus engages perception/understanding of others (I1,I2).

The contrast 'Altruistic choices (Gave $1.5X After Not Receiving - Gave $0 After Not Receiving)' isolates prosocial behavior after non-receipt and directly indexes social processing related to reciprocity and altruism (I1,I2).

This contrast specifically contrasts altruistic giving versus withholding following a partner’s non-cooperation, tapping affiliation/attachment-related motives (cooperation, bonding), satisfying I1 and I2.
The contrast isolates communicative social behavior (altruistic signal vs withholding) in cooperative exchange contexts, so it measures social communication (I1,I2).
Comparing altruistic giving to withholding after not receiving emphasizes self-related moral and agency processes (self-monitoring, self-knowledge) implicated in the decision, meeting I1 and I2.
This contrast reflects decisions made based on models of the partner’s behavior/intentions (understanding others), so it meets perception/others criteria (I1,I2).

The Fremdscham analysis examines participants' social-emotional responses to another person's social integrity threat (empathic cringing). This is clearly a social-related task and measures social processing (understanding others' emotions and social cognition).

The task probes empathic embarrassment (fremdscham) rather than affiliation, attachment, or formation of social bonds. It does not assess attachment styles, kinship, cooperation, or similar affiliation constructs.

The Fremdscham task involves observing and evaluating emotional states rather than studying exchange of social information or communicative behaviors (facial/ non-facial communication production or reception). It does not target communication subconstructs.

Although participants report their own emotional experience, the primary focus is on empathic response to another's predicament (perception of others). The task does not primarily measure self-awareness/self-knowledge or agency per the Perception/Self inclusion criteria.

Fremdscham involves representing and understanding another person's emotional state (embarrassment/misfortune). The analysis directly measures perception and understanding of others' emotions and social states.

The Schadenfreude analysis examines observers' pleasure in response to another's misfortune, a social-emotional response that engages social cognition and appraisal of others. This is a social-related task measuring social processing.
Schadenfreude measures reward-related response to others' misfortune rather than affiliation or attachment processes (no assessment of bonding, kinship, or cooperative/competitive relationship).
The task centers on emotional reactions to observed events, not on the exchange or recognition of communicative signals (facial or non-facial communication) as defined by Social Communication.

Although participants report their subjective schadenfreude intensity, the primary construct is a response to others' outcomes (social reward) rather than a task specifically measuring self-perception, agency, or self-knowledge.

Schadenfreude involves assessing another person's misfortune and inferring social information about that person (their status, actions, or deservingness). The analysis measures representation/understanding of others' situations and emotional states.
The contrast Fremdscham > Schadenfreude compares two social-emotional perspectives on another's misfortune, directly probing differences in social processing (empathy vs reward-related responses).
This contrast tests differences between empathic embarrassment and schadenfreude, not affiliation/attachment processes related to bonding or close relationships.
The contrast addresses differing social-emotional appraisals rather than communication/perception or production of communicative signals; it does not target social communication constructs.
While the contrast reflects changes in observers' reported experience, its conceptual focus is on how observers perceive others (empathy vs pleasure), not on core self-perception or agency measures.

The contrast highlights differences in neural representation and processing of others' states when participants adopt an empathic versus reward-focused stance, thus directly measuring perception and understanding of others' emotional states.

The task contrasts romantic versus neutral images to probe neural responses related to romantic love and bonding, which is a social-related task measuring broad social processing (perception and response to social/affiliative cues).

The contrast (romantic > neutral) targets neural activity associated with romantic bonding/affiliation, directly measuring affiliation and attachment-related processes (analogous to loved one vs neutral), meeting the affiliation/attachment inclusion criterion.
The task involves passive viewing of romantic images rather than exchange or production/reception of communicative signals; it does not measure social communication per the definition.
The contrast does not involve self-reflection, self-judgment, or awareness of one’s own traits/states; it measures responses to romantic stimuli rather than perception/understanding of the self.

Viewing romantic images implicates perception and representation of others’ social/emotional significance (e.g., loved one stimuli) and thus involves processes of perceiving/understanding others, meeting the inclusion criterion.
The romantic > sexual contrast examines neural responses to romantic (affiliative) stimuli versus sexual stimuli, which probes social processing related to romantic bonding and social valuation.
The contrast explicitly isolates romantic (affiliation/attachment-related) stimuli relative to sexual stimuli, directly measuring affiliation/attachment processes (matches I1).

The contrast does not involve self-referential judgments or introspective evaluation of the self; it examines responses to others/romantic content rather than self-perception.

Comparing romantic to sexual images implicates how participants perceive and represent others’ romantic significance and emotional states; this involves perception/understanding of others and meets the inclusion criterion.

The IAT assesses implicit attitudes toward adultery, which is a social construct concerning romantic relationships and monogamy; this meets social processing inclusion (task is social).

The IAT measures implicit attitudes, not the exchange or processing of communicative signals (facial/exchange behaviors); it does not assess social communication per the construct definition.
The contrast indexes implicit attitudes toward adultery rather than self-referential judgments or self-knowledge; it does not target perception/understanding of self.

This contrast reflects implicit attitudes toward behaviors relevant to romantic affiliation and attachment (adultery vs fidelity), satisfying the affiliation/attachment criterion.

Experiment 1 is a movie-watching task manipulating perceived kinship (genetic vs non-genetic) and measures inter-subject correlation of brain activity across viewers; this directly probes social processing (moral/emotional evaluation, social cognition).

The key manipulation is perceived kinship (genetic vs adoptive sister), which is a prototypical affiliation/attachment context; the contrast (genetic>non-genetic) measures how affiliation-related information modulates neural responses.

Subjects view social interactions (a refusal of organ donation between sisters) that convey socially relevant information and require processing of communicative cues and emotions; the analysis contrasts conditions of kinship and thus assesses social communication-related processing.

The task and contrasts focus on observers' neural responses to others and mentalizing about the sisters, not on self-reflection, agency, or self-knowledge. There is no explicit measure of self-related processing in the reported contrasts.

The analysis targets understanding of others (mental states, emotions, moral behavior) by comparing neural synchrony when subjects believe the actors are genetic vs non-genetic sisters; this directly maps onto perception/understanding of others.

Experiment 1 contrast non-genetic>genetic is part of the same social movie-watching paradigm probing social cognition; it measures social processing by assessing condition-dependent inter-subject correlations.

The contrast compares perceived kinship conditions (non-genetic vs genetic), probing effects of affiliation/attachment information on neural responses; thus it measures affiliation/attachment-related processing.

The contrast examines neural responses to the same social interaction under different kinship beliefs, implicating processing of communicative/social cues and associated emotional/mentalizing content.
As above, the contrast addresses perception of others and group-level similarity of responses rather than self-related judgments or agency; no explicit self-perception measures are reported.

The non-genetic>genetic contrast still targets understanding of others’ emotional/moral states and observers’ mentalizing processes; it evaluates perception/understanding of others under different kinship beliefs.
Experiment 2 is a moral dilemma decision task that explicitly probes social/moral cognition in kinship contexts; this directly constitutes social processing.
The moral dilemma decision task involves decisions about kin vs non-kin (sisters), which taps affiliation/attachment influences on moral choices, satisfying affiliation-related inclusion criteria.

Although a decision task, it involves processing socially relevant information about interactions and relationships (kinship) and the communication of moral intent/behavior, thus mapping onto social communication constructs.

The task focuses on judgments about others in moral scenarios (kinship effects) rather than on self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge; no explicit self-related measures are reported for this contrast.

The moral decision task requires representing and evaluating others’ actions, intentions, and moral status (sisters’ refusal of organ donation), directly assessing perception and understanding of others.

Task requires judging social direction (facing toward/away) of biological motion and human-like walkers; this is a social-related task that measures processing of social information (inferring social intentions).
The contrasts compare stimulus type and direction (PLD vs HL, facing toward vs away) and do not assess affiliation, attachment, bonding, or related interpersonal relationships.
Participants infer socially relevant information (social intentions/nonverbal cues) from point-light displays and human-like walkers, which constitutes reception of non-facial social communication.
The task involves perceiving others' motion/direction rather than self-awareness, self-judgment, agency, or self-knowledge.
Judging facing direction and inferring intentions from biological motion directly involves perception and understanding of others (action perception and animacy/intent inference).

The contrast Collaborative > Arbitrary compares collaboratively learned labels to arbitrarily assigned labels; the task involved retrieval and production in a communicative context and the study reports engagement of mentalizing and autobiographical memory regions for collaborative retrieval. This directly measures social processing.
The task involves collaboration and communication but does not measure affiliation or attachment (no measures of bonding, close relationships, or attachment styles).

Participants produced labels aloud during a communicative task; the Collaborative > Arbitrary contrast isolates effects of communication-driven, collaboratively generated labels, so it measures social communication.
The contrast emphasizes understanding others/mentalizing and memory retrieval rather than processes of self-perception, agency, or self-knowledge; the task does not target self-perception measures.

The study reports that collaboratively generated label retrieval engages regions involved in understanding others (mentalizing/theory of mind). The contrast directly taps perception and understanding of others' mental states.

Although the Individual condition reflects non-collaborative encoding, retrieval occurred during a communicative task in the scanner; the contrast Individual > Arbitrary involves a social/communicative retrieval context and thus pertains to social processing broadly.
The contrast does not assess affiliation or attachment-related constructs (no measures of bonding or relationship closeness).

Retrieval and production of labels were performed during a communicative task; the contrast between individually learned and arbitrary labels reflects communication-related processes (production/retrieval in a communicative context).
The contrast does not target self-perception, agency, or self-knowledge processes specifically; it contrasts encoding conditions rather than self-related judgments.

There is no indication that the Individual > Arbitrary contrast isolates processes of reasoning about others' mental states; the main reported effects for perception of others were specific to collaborative encoding contrasts.

Collaborative > Individual directly tests effects of collaborative (social) encoding on retrieval and the study reports engagement of social-cognitive regions; this contrast measures social processing.
The contrast contrasts collaborative vs individual learned information but does not assess affiliation or attachment constructs (no bonding or relationship measures).

The collaborative condition involved producing labels in a communicative context with another person; the contrast isolates effects of socially produced labels and thus measures social communication processes.

Although autobiographical memory is mentioned, the primary reported effects relate to understanding others and social cognition rather than explicit measures of self-perception or self-knowledge targeted by the contrast.

The study specifically reports that Collaborative > Individual engages regions involved in understanding others (mentalizing/theory of mind), so this contrast measures perception and understanding of others' mental states.

Arbitrary > Individual highlights greater activation for arbitrarily assigned labels relative to individually learned ones; this contrast does not specifically measure social processes and the study does not report social-cognitive engagement for this direction.
The contrast does not assess affiliation or attachment constructs.
The contrast does not isolate communication-related social processes; arbitrary labels were learned individually and the comparison does not emphasize social communication.
The contrast does not target self-perception or self-knowledge processes.
There is no evidence this contrast measures understanding of others' mental states; the study's reported perception-of-others effects are tied to collaborative encoding contrasts.

Individual > Collaborative contrasts individual encoding against collaborative; the contrast itself does not index increased social processing (it highlights non-collaborative effects) and the study emphasizes social processing in the collaborative direction.
No measures of affiliation or attachment are assessed by this contrast.
The contrast does not represent enhanced social communication; it favors the individual encoding condition over collaborative, and does not isolate communication processes.
The contrast does not specifically measure self-perception, agency, or self-knowledge.
The contrast does not isolate perception or understanding of others; perception-of-others effects were reported for the collaborative > individual direction, not this one.

Arbitrary > Collaborative highlights greater activation for arbitrary labels versus collaboratively learned ones; this direction does not index social processing and is not reported to tap social-cognitive networks in the study.
The contrast does not assess affiliation or attachment constructs.
This contrast does not emphasize social communication processes; arbitrary labels were learned without collaborative partner generation and the contrast does not isolate communicative exchange.
The contrast does not target self-perception or agency.
There is no indication that Arbitrary > Collaborative measures understanding of others; the study reports perception-of-others effects specifically for collaborative > individual contrasts.

This analysis explicitly involves observation of social interactions and measures processing of social cues (intention, cooperativity vs affectivity). Matches broad Social Processing.
The task includes cooperative social interactions (cooperativity dimension) relevant to affiliation/attachment processes (cooperation vs affectivity).
Observing social interactions with cooperative and affective cues involves exchange of socially relevant information (communication of intentions/affect).
The analysis concerns observation and interpretation of others' interactions, not self-related processing or self-awareness.
The analysis targets understanding others' actions, intentions and affect (mirror and mentalizing systems), directly mapping onto Perception/Understanding of Others.
This contrast isolates cooperativity effects in observed social interactions, clearly a social processing measure.
Cooperativity>affectivity directly targets cooperative social behavior, fitting Affiliation/Attachment (cooperation) constructs.
Cooperation involves exchange of socially relevant cues and shared goals, consistent with Social Communication.
Contrast concerns others' interactions (cooperativity), not self-related judgments or agency.
Cooperativity manipulation concerns perception and understanding of others' actions and intentions (mirror/mentalizing), matching Perception/Understanding of Others.
This contrast isolates affectivity effects in observed social interactions, which is a social processing measure.
Affectivity>cooperativity emphasizes affective/mental state attribution rather than affiliation/cooperation specifically; does not directly measure attachment/affiliation.
Affective aspects of interactions involve communicative signals (emotional/mental state information), fitting Social Communication.
Contrast targets perception of others' affect and mental states rather than self-related processing.
Affectivity manipulation implicates mentalizing and understanding others' emotional/mental states, matching Perception/Understanding of Others.
Unnamed analysis is part of the same study on observed social interactions and effective connectivity; thus it measures Social Processing broadly.
As part of the study’s DCM analyses contrasting cooperativity and affectivity, this analysis likely includes cooperative/affiliation-related effects and thus maps onto Affiliation/Attachment.
Effective connectivity analyses of social interaction conditions reflect processing of communicative social information (cooperative and affective cues).
The study focuses on observing others and their intentions/affect, not on self-perception or self-related judgments.
The DCM analyses target how observers represent and infer others' actions and mental/affective states (mirror and mentalizing systems), matching Perception/Understanding of Others.

The table 'Partnering' describes dyadic physical joint action (partnered dancing/contact), a social interaction paradigm; it measures social processing of joint action and coordination. Fits I1 and I2 (social task and measures social processing).

The partnering condition involves physical contact and coordination but does not operationalize affiliation/attachment (no contrasts of loved-one vs stranger or measures of bonding). Does not meet I1.

Partnered interaction with haptic/motor coupling and role exchanges implies nonverbal social communication (movement/tactile signaling) and thus measures social communication (non-facial, nonverbal). Meets I1.

‘Partnering’ is a broad descriptor of the dyadic task and does not specifically isolate self-related processing or agency judgments; it does not clearly measure perception/understanding of self. Does not meet I1 for self-processing.
Partnered joint-action requires perceiving and tracking the partner’s movements and states (action/perception of other), so it measures perception and understanding of others. Meets I1.

The Leading > Conjunction contrast targets the leader role in a dyadic social interaction; the abstract explicitly frames leading as a self-oriented social role — this is a social-processing contrast. Meets I1 and I2.
The Leading contrast indexes role-related motor and cognitive processes rather than affiliation or attachment per se; no measures of bonding or loved-one vs stranger. Does not meet I1.

Leading in a partnered movement interaction entails sending movement/tactile cues to a partner (production of non-facial, nonverbal communication). The contrast therefore measures social communication aspects. Meets I1.

The paper describes leading as self-oriented and involving motor planning and sequencing, implicating agency and self-monitoring processes; the contrast captures perception/understanding of self (agency). Meets I1.

Leading is characterized in the abstract as primarily self-oriented; while some monitoring of the partner may occur, the contrast emphasizes self-focused planning rather than representation of the other. It does not primarily target perception/understanding of others.
The Following > Conjunction contrast targets the follower role in a dyadic social interaction; the abstract explicitly describes following as externally-oriented social processing. Meets I1 and I2.
Following contrasts index sensory/proprioceptive and social-cognitive tracking rather than affiliation/attachment; no bonding measures. Does not meet I1.
Following depends on perceiving and responding to another’s cues (reception of non-facial, nonverbal communication) and thus engages social communication processes. Meets I1.

The abstract describes following as externally-oriented (sensory, proprioceptive, motion tracking), not primarily self-awareness or agency; the contrast does not primarily measure perception of self. Does not meet I1 for self-processing.

Following explicitly involves tracking the partner’s movements, somatosensation/proprioception and social-cognitive monitoring — this directly maps onto perception and understanding of others (action perception/mental state tracking). Meets I1.
The Mutual > Conjunction contrast examines symmetric, pre-learned joint action with increased mentalizing and social reward — clearly a social-processing contrast. Meets I1 and I2.

Although the mutual condition shows social reward/mentalizing, the study does not operationalize attachment/affiliation constructs (no explicit bonding or loved-one vs stranger contrasts). Does not meet I1 for affiliation/attachment.

Mutual joint action requires coordination and exchange of cues between partners (nonverbal communication) and engages processes related to social interaction; therefore it measures social communication. Meets I1.

The mutual condition is described as minimizing tendencies toward leading or following and instead emphasizes mentalizing and social reward rather than self-oriented agency; it does not primarily measure perception/understanding of self. Does not meet I1 for self-processing.

Mutual activity elicits mentalizing and social cognition, which reflect representation and understanding of the partner’s states and intentions — this maps onto perception/understanding of others. Meets I1.
The Improvisation contrast examines improvised joint actions within the dyadic interaction context; improvisation in a partnered setting implicates social processing. Meets I1 and I2.
Improvisation here probes motor-planning and working memory during joint action, not affiliation/attachment or bonding measures. Does not meet I1 for affiliation/attachment.

The reported improvisation effects emphasize motor-planning and working-memory rather than explicit exchange of social communicative signals; the contrast is primarily about generative motor processes rather than measuring social communication per se. Does not meet I1 for social communication.
Improvisation engages self-generated motor planning, initiation and working memory (agency-related processes); the contrast captures perception/understanding of self (agency components). Meets I1.

The improvisation contrast as described emphasizes motor-planning/working memory and not primarily tracking or representing the partner’s state; thus it does not primarily measure perception/understanding of others. Does not meet I1.
Self-initiation is studied within the context of partnered joint action and addresses who initiates movement in a social interaction, so it is part of social processing. Meets I1 and I2.
Self-initiation relates to agency and initiation of movement rather than measures of affiliation/attachment or bonding. Does not meet I1 for affiliation/attachment.

Self-initiation primarily probes agency/initiatory processes (who starts an action) rather than the exchange/reception of communicative signals; it is not primarily a social-communication contrast. Does not meet I1 for social communication.
Self-initiation directly targets agency and self-related initiation processes (perception/understanding of self). Meets I1.

Although initiation occurs in a social setting, the contrast focuses on self-agency rather than representation of the other’s state or actions; it does not primarily measure perception/understanding of others. Does not meet I1.
Joint improvisation explicitly examines improvised interaction between partners and the coordination between them — a core social-processing task. Meets I1 and I2.

While joint improvisation involves interaction and may be rewarding, the analyses do not operationalize affiliation/attachment constructs or bonding contrasts. Does not meet I1 for affiliation/attachment.
Joint improvisation requires ongoing exchange of nonverbal cues and coordination (reception and production of non-facial, nonverbal communication), so it measures social communication. Meets I1.

The abstract reports that improvisation engages motor-planning and working-memory regions — self-generated, agency-related processes — so joint improvisation also taps perception/understanding of self. Meets I1.
Joint improvisation requires perceiving and adapting to the partner’s actions and intentions (action perception and mentalizing), thus measuring perception/understanding of others. Meets I1.
