The contrast (LIVE > REPLAY) examines real-time mutual eye contact, a social interaction task assessing perception and response to social cues. The study explicitly investigates social processing (mutual interaction, sharing affective/mental states) and reports neural activations related to social interaction, satisfying measurement of social processing.

The task involves mutual eye contact and automatic mimicry but does not assess affiliation or attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, close relationships, cooperation/competition, or loved-one vs stranger contrasts).

Eye contact is a core form of social communication (production and reception of facial/ocular signals). The LIVE vs REPLAY contrast directly measures on-line communicative exchange, meeting the criteria for social communication.

The study hypothesizes involvement of self-awareness and reports activation/connectivity in ACC and AIC, regions implicated in self-related processing. The contrast likely taps self-monitoring/agency aspects during mutual interaction, consistent with perception/understanding of self.

The analysis measures participants' responses to partner eye-blinks and mutual gaze, reflecting perception/action perception and understanding of others' attention/mental states, matching the perception-of-others construct.

Effective connectivity from ACC enhanced in LIVE condition reflects neural mechanisms supporting real-time social interaction (mutual eye contact). This directly measures social processing at the network level.
Connectivity analysis concerns neural dynamics during eye contact but does not target affiliation/attachment constructs or use contrasts related to bonding or relationship closeness.
ACC connectivity changes during LIVE interaction indicate neural substrates of on-line communicative exchange (gaze-based signaling), aligning with social communication processes.

ACC and anterior insula connectivity is implicated in self-awareness and self-monitoring. Enhanced effective connectivity in LIVE condition suggests engagement of self-related processing during mutual gaze.

Changes in ACC-driven connectivity during live eye contact reflect processing about a partner's cues and shared states, indicating perception/understanding of others (action/mental-state representation).
Interbrain synchronization enhanced during LIVE vs REPLAY captures dyadic social processing during mutual eye contact, directly measuring interactive social processes.
While interbrain synchrony reflects coordinated interaction, the analysis does not assess affiliation/attachment per se (no measures of bonding or relationship-specific contrasts).
Interbrain synchronization during real-time gaze indicates coupling related to communicative exchange (mutual eye contact), fitting the social communication construct.

The authors link interbrain effects and limbic mirror system activity to self-awareness; synchronization during mutual gaze likely involves self-monitoring and shared self-other representations, supporting inclusion under perception_self.

Interbrain synchronization reflects shared representation and prediction of the partner's attention/behavior (eye-blinks and gaze), directly indexing perception and understanding of others' actions and states.

Study title/abstract indicate an fMRI socioemotional processing task investigating empathy and anxiety; the task results (Fig.3) therefore reflect social processing broadly.

Empathy and compassion relate to affiliation and concern for others; the socioemotional task likely probes affiliative/attachment-related processes (concern/compassion), so this analysis is relevant to affiliation/attachment.

Socioemotional processing typically requires perception and interpretation of others' affective cues (receptive facial/affective communication); task-based results likely index social communication processes.

Abstract emphasizes self-reflection and internally generated thought linking empathy and anxiety; the socioemotional task likely engages self-related processing (self-awareness, self-monitoring) relevant here.
Empathy fundamentally involves representing and understanding others’ emotional states; task results thus reflect perception and understanding of others.
TEQ regressions examine how trait empathy modulates brain responses during the socioemotional task (Fig.4), therefore probing social processing broadly.
Trait empathy (TEQ) captures concern and compassion for others, which maps onto affiliation/attachment processes; neural regressions with TEQ likely reflect affiliative processing.
TEQ-related neural effects likely index sensitivity to others’ affective cues and affect recognition, core aspects of social communication.
TEQ relates to perspective-taking and self-other representations; regressions may reflect self-referential components (self-related processing) engaged during the task.
TEQ measures trait ability to understand/share others’ emotions; regressions directly index neural representation of others’ mental/emotional states.
STAI regressions assess how anxiety modulates responses during socioemotional processing, implicating social processing mechanisms overall.

The abstract links anxiety to increased concern for others and social sensitivity; anxiety-related neural effects during the socioemotional task may therefore reflect affiliation/attachment-related processing.
Anxiety can modulate perception of social cues and affect recognition; STAI-related neural differences during socioemotional stimuli likely involve social communication processes.
Anxiety involves self-focused processes (worry, monitoring); regressions with STAI may index self-referential processing engaged during the socioemotional task.
Anxiety may alter how others’ emotions are perceived and interpreted; STAI-related brain effects during the task likely relate to understanding others’ emotional states.
PSWQ regressions (worry) relate to how worry modulates socioemotional task responses, engaging social processing broadly.
Worry and generalized anxiety can influence social concern and interpersonal sensitivity; PSWQ-related neural modulation during socioemotional stimuli may touch affiliation/attachment processes.
Chronic worry may impact attention to social cues and affect recognition; PSWQ regressions during socioemotional processing likely implicate social communication mechanisms.
Worry is a self-focused cognitive process; brain-behavior regressions with PSWQ are likely to index self-referential processing during the task.
Worry may also bias interpretation of others’ emotions and intentions during socioemotional processing; PSWQ-related neural effects can reflect perception of others.
RRS regressions assess how rumination/self-focused thought modulates socioemotional task responses, implicating broad social processing.
Rumination may affect social bonds and empathic concern indirectly; neural correlates of rumination during socioemotional processing can relate to affiliation/attachment processes.
Rumination and repetitive negative thought can alter processing of social cues; RRS-related neural modulation during socioemotional stimuli likely involves social communication.
RRS explicitly measures rumination/self-focused repetitive thought; regressions with RRS are directly relevant to perception and understanding of self.
Rumination can bias interpretation of others’ states and interactions; RRS-related neural effects during socioemotional processing may involve understanding others.

The contrast examines neural responses to social exclusion (virtual ball-tossing game) modulated by emotional support vs no support, which is a canonical social task measuring social processing (perception, interpretation and affective response to social interaction).
The manipulation involves support from a friend (emotional support) and tests buffering of exclusion effects, directly probing affiliation/attachment processes and close social bonds.
The task is an interpersonal ball-tossing game (social exchange) where participants interpret others' actions; this falls under social communication / interactive social behavior.

The contrast targets responses to social exclusion and the effect of external support on affect and neural activity, but does not directly measure self-awareness, self-judgment, agency, or self-knowledge as the primary construct.

Exclusion entails assessing others' intentions and behavior (being excluded by others) and the manipulation involves a friend’s supportive behavior, implicating perception/understanding of others' actions and intentions.
This contrast assesses neural responses to social exclusion under appraisal support vs no support, a social task probing social processing and emotional/interpretive responses to social interaction.

Appraisal support from a friend is a form of social support tied to affiliative bonds; the contrast examines how this support modulates exclusion-related processing, addressing affiliation/attachment.

The virtual ball-tossing paradigm is an interactive social task where participants infer communicative intent of others; appraisal support manipulation alters social exchange context and communication-related processing.

Although the contrast measures emotional responses to exclusion and support, it does not explicitly target self-related judgments or self-knowledge mechanisms required for Perception and Understanding of Self.
Participants must interpret others' exclusionary behavior and the friend’s appraisal messages, engaging perception/understanding of others’ actions and intentions.
This contrast compares the reverse exclusion runs under appraisal support vs no support, again probing social processing of exclusion and support effects in a social-interactive task.
Appraisal support (informative text messages from a friend) modulates responses to exclusion, implicating affiliative/attachment processes between participant and friend.
The contrast involves the interpersonal ball-tossing interaction and friend-provided messages, addressing aspects of social communication in an interactive context.
The contrast focuses on affective and neural consequences of exclusion and support, not explicit measures of self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge; thus it does not meet Perception/Self criteria.
The manipulation requires interpreting others’ exclusionary actions and the friend’s appraisal, engaging processes of understanding others’ intentions and actions.

The contrast compares dynamic facial expressions versus mosaics, a social-emotional perceptual task that directly measures social processing (emotion recognition and social cue perception).
The task involves passive observation of facial expressions (anger, happiness) and is not assessing affiliation/attachment, bonding, or relationship-specific processing.
This analysis assesses reception of facial communication (dynamic expressions), fitting the Social Communication construct (facial affect recognition).
The task does not involve self-related judgments, agency, or self-knowledge; it concerns perception of external facial expressions.
The contrast measures perception and understanding of others' emotional states via dynamic facial expressions, directly matching this construct.
This interaction tests expression>mosaic by emotion (anger vs happiness) during observation of dynamic facial expressions, a social processing task probing emotion-related social responses.
The emotion × stimulus interaction focuses on perceptual/emotional responses to expressions rather than affiliation or attachment processes.
Examines reception of facial communication with respect to different emotions (receptive facial communication subconstruct).
No self-referential processing is being measured; analysis concerns perception of others' expressions.
By comparing emotions in dynamic facial expressions vs mosaics, this analysis probes understanding of others' emotional states.
The stimulus type × gender interaction still involves processing dynamic facial expressions (social cues), thus measuring social processing.
The gender interaction pertains to perceptual/emotional responses and is not an affiliation/attachment task.
Involves reception of facial communication (dynamic expressions) and examines modulation by actor gender, which remains within social communication.
No self-related judgments or self-awareness measures are involved; this analysis focuses on perceiving others' expressions.
Analyzes perception/understanding of others' emotional expressions and how this is affected by stimulus gender.
The three-way interaction (stimulus×emotion×gender) still concerns processing of dynamic facial expressions and thus social processing.
This higher-order interaction reflects perceptual/emotional modulation by emotion and gender, not affiliation/attachment constructs.
Examines reception of facial communication with modulation by emotion and gender — squarely within Social Communication (facial reception) domain.
No measures of self-perception or self-referential processing are present in this contrast.
The interaction informs how observers perceive others' emotional expressions depending on emotion and gender, relevant to Understanding Others.
Stimulus type × laterality compares expression-related activity and hemispheric dominance, still assessing social processing of facial expressions.
The laterality analysis addresses hemispheric dominance for expression processing, not affiliation/attachment behavior or bonding.
This contrast investigates lateralization of reception of facial communication (right vs left hemispheric responses), relevant to Social Communication.
The contrast examines lateralized perception of others' expressions rather than self-related processes.
Assesses hemispheric asymmetries in perceiving others' emotional expressions, directly mapping onto Perception and Understanding of Others.
Stimulus type × emotion × laterality probes how emotion-specific expression processing is lateralized — a social processing question about emotion perception in others.
This analysis focuses on emotion-specific lateralization of expression perception, not affiliation/attachment constructs.
Investigates lateralization of receptive facial communication for specific emotions (reception of facial communication subconstruct).
No self-referential or self-perception measures are included; analysis concerns perception of others' emotions and lateralization.
Examines how perception/understanding of others' emotional expressions varies by hemisphere, matching Perception of Others.
Stimulus type × sex × laterality similarly concerns lateralized processing of dynamic facial expressions by actor sex — a social processing measure.
The contrast examines sex-related modulation and lateralization of expression perception, not attachment or affiliation behavior.
Addresses reception of facial communication and how it is modulated by actor sex and hemisphere — within Social Communication domain.
No measures of self-awareness or self-related judgments are present; focus remains on perceiving others' expressions.
Concerns perception and understanding of others' expressions (modulated by sex and hemisphere), fitting Perception of Others.
The four-way interaction includes stimulus type, emotion, sex, and laterality and remains an analysis of dynamic facial-expression processing — a broad social processing measure.
This complex interaction tests perceptual and lateralized differences in expression processing, not affiliation/attachment constructs.
Addresses reception of facial communication under multiple modulatory factors (emotion, sex, laterality), consistent with Social Communication.
No self-related measures are involved; this contrast pertains to perceiving others' expressions under various conditions.
The interaction examines nuanced perception and understanding of others' emotional expressions across conditions and hemispheres, fitting Perception of Others.

The contrast measures neural responses to disfigured faces—a clearly social stimulus involving perception and evaluation of others. The study explicitly tests social biases ('disfigured is bad') and reports social-cognitive interpretations, so this analysis measures broad social processing.

The task is passive/viewing of disfigured faces and assesses social evaluation and bias, not measures of affiliation, attachment, or close-relationship processes (no kinship, cooperation, or attachment paradigms).

Viewing and evaluating faces involves reception of facial communication (facial recognition/affect perception). The contrast reflects processing of facial social signals, satisfying the social communication (reception) construct.
The analysis probes responses to others' faces and social evaluation, not self-related processing, self-awareness, or judgments about one’s own traits or states.
The contrast examines representations and evaluations of other people’s faces and associated social judgments (the ‘disfigured is bad’ bias), matching perception and understanding of others.

This contrast (decreased responses to faces before treatment) reflects neural changes tied to social cognition (e.g., reduced ACC responses linked to empathy/social cognition), so it indexes broad social processing.
Findings concern social evaluation and possible dehumanization/empathy suppression but do not measure affiliation or attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, kinship, or close relationships).

Responses to facial stimuli implicate reception of facial communication; even decreases (e.g., in ACC) relate to processing of social signals from faces, fitting social communication (receptive) criteria.
The contrast concerns responses to others’ faces and changes in social-cognitive neural activity, not self-perception or self-related judgments.
Decreased ACC responses are interpreted as diminished empathy/social cognition toward others; the contrast thus measures perception and understanding of others’ mental/social states.

Analysis 'decision-making' involves participants (patients and controls) playing a prisoners' dilemma during fMRI to assess social behaviour and its neural correlates — a clear social processing task measuring perception, interpretation and responses to social information.

Prisoners' dilemma operationalizes cooperation vs defection (cooperative behaviour and social bonding tendencies), so this analysis measures affiliation/attachment-related processes (cooperation/competition).

The prisoners' dilemma requires exchange of socially relevant information via choices and reciprocal behaviour; it is a cooperation/competition task listed under Social Communication examples, so it measures social communicative interactions.

Decision-making in social games involves self-related processes (agency, monitoring of one’s choices, strategy), and the study assesses self-relevant social decision processes during the task, meeting the Perception/Self construct.

Success in the prisoners' dilemma depends on representing and reasoning about the other player’s intentions and likely moves (mentalizing/understanding others), so this analysis measures Perception and Understanding of Others.

Analysis labelled 'results' summarizes behavioural and neural outcomes from the prisoners' dilemma task, which probes social processing (perception, interpretation and response to social information).
The summarized results concern cooperation/defection patterns and their neural correlates, directly reflecting affiliation/attachment processes measured by the game.

Results pertain to interactive decision behaviour (cooperation/competition) and associated neural activity, aligning with Social Communication constructs (exchange of socially relevant information via behaviour).
Results include measures tied to participants’ own decision-making strategies and self-monitoring during the social game, fitting Perception/Self.
Results address how participants represent and respond to opponents’ behaviour (mentalizing), meeting Perception/Others criteria.
'PATIENTS' per-group analysis examines FLE patients’ performance on the prisoners' dilemma and associated fMRI activation — a direct investigation of social processing in the patient group.
Patient group analysis focuses on cooperation behaviour (reduced cooperation/altered social behaviour), reflecting affiliation/attachment constructs measured by the task.
The patient analysis inspects interactive decision patterns and neural correlates during cooperation/competition, relevant to social communication processes.
Analyses of patients’ decision-making strategies and self-related aspects (e.g., agency, self-monitoring) during the game relate to Perception/Self.
Patient analyses consider how patients represent and reason about partners’ intentions (mentalizing/understanding others), so include Perception/Others.
'CONTROLS' per-group analysis examines healthy controls' behaviour and neural responses during the prisoners' dilemma — a direct social processing assessment for the control group.
Control group analysis evaluates cooperative behaviour and social bonding tendencies in the game, matching Affiliation/Attachment constructs.
Controls’ interactive decision-making and reciprocal behaviour in the prisoners' dilemma map onto Social Communication processes.
Control analyses involve participants’ own strategic choices and self-monitoring during social decision-making, consistent with Perception/Self.
Control group analyses require representing and predicting partners’ choices (mentalizing) and thus measure Perception/Others.

'main effect of group' assesses differences between patients and controls in neural and behavioural measures from the social decision task — this directly addresses social processing differences between groups.
Group effect analysis evaluates differences in cooperative behaviour (affiliation) between patients and controls, so it measures Affiliation/Attachment.
Differences in interactive decision patterns and neural activity across groups reflect differences in Social Communication processes (exchange/reciprocity).
Group differences likely include contrasts of self-related decision-making (strategy/agency) between patients and controls, implicating Perception/Self.
Main effect of group highlights potential differences in mentalizing or understanding others’ intentions between patients and controls, so it meets Perception/Others criteria.
'main effect of condition' examines task conditions within the prisoners' dilemma (e.g., cooperation vs defection) and associated neural responses — this addresses core social processing constructs.
Condition contrasts (such as cooperation vs defection) directly index affiliation/attachment processes inherent in the game.
Condition effects capture variation in interactive social behaviour (communication via choices), aligning with Social Communication.
Condition contrasts involve self-referential decision processes (choice, responsibility, agency) and thus relate to Perception/Self.
Conditions differing in opponents’ behaviour or social context require mentalizing and understanding others, fitting Perception/Others.

'ROI-main effect of group' reports region-of-interest analyses of group differences (e.g., medial prefrontal cortex) linked to social behaviour in the prisoners' dilemma — directly relevant to social processing.
ROI analyses on social brain regions that differ between groups during cooperative behaviour index affiliation/attachment processes measured by the task.
ROI-level group effects in social cognition-related regions during interactive decisions reflect Social Communication processes.
ROI analyses (e.g., medial prefrontal cortex) often index self-related processes; here they are linked to patients’ self-monitoring/agency in social decisions, meeting Perception/Self.
ROI differences in social brain regions during the task indicate altered representation of others’ mental states (mentalizing), so include Perception/Others.

The contrast (ActionOBS–CtrlOBS) tests observation of goal-directed hand actions of others, which falls under social processing (perception and understanding of others). The study explicitly frames action perception as social cognition. Therefore it meets criteria for Social Processing.

The task involves perception of hand actions and kinematics, not measures of affiliation, attachment, bonding, cooperation, or related social-relationship constructs. It does not meet the inclusion criteria for Affiliation and Attachment.

The task is action perception of hand kinematics rather than communicative exchanges (facial or non-facial communication) or production/reception of communicative signals; thus it does not meet Social Communication inclusion criteria.
The contrast examines perception of others' actions, not self-related judgments, agency, or self-knowledge. It does not meet Perception/Self inclusion criteria.

The contrast directly measures Action Perception (a subconstruct of Perception and Understanding of Others) by examining observation of others' hand movements; this clearly satisfies the inclusion criteria.

Experiment 2 uses the same ActionOBS–CtrlOBS contrast (observing goal-directed hand actions of others), which constitutes social processing (perception/understanding of others). It therefore meets the Social Processing criteria.

Experiment 2's task does not probe affiliation, attachment, or relationship-related constructs; it focuses on action observation and kinematics, so it does not meet Affiliation/Attachment inclusion criteria.
The task involves perceiving hand actions rather than communicative signals or exchanges, so it does not meet Social Communication inclusion criteria.
The contrast assesses perception of others' actions, not self-related processes (agency or self-knowledge), so Perception/Self does not apply.
Experiment 2's ActionOBS–CtrlOBS directly measures Action Perception, which is a subconstruct of Perception and Understanding of Others; it therefore satisfies the inclusion criteria.
Experiment 3's ActionOBS–CtrlOBS contrast examines observation of others' goal-directed hand actions, which is a social perceptual process and thus qualifies as Social Processing.
The task in Experiment 3 does not target affiliation, attachment, or bonding measures; it focuses on action kinematics perception and therefore does not meet Affiliation/Attachment criteria.
Experiment 3 involves action observation (kinematics) rather than communicative reception or production (facial/non-facial), so it does not meet Social Communication criteria.
The contrast addresses perception of others' actions rather than self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge; Perception/Self criteria are not met.

The ActionOBS–CtrlOBS contrast in Experiment 3 explicitly probes Action Perception (observing others' hand movements), a core subconstruct of Perception and Understanding of Others, thus satisfying inclusion criteria.
